petition.title: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Federal Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

petition.para: Since May 1992, the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) started a new campaign trying to stamp out the voice of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation (UVBC), which is led by the Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, an Amnesty International's prisoner of conscience since his third arrest by the GOSRV in 1982.

The GOSRV has ignored the UVBC's moderate demands: the restoration of its structure and activities in the country, as clearly stated in the letter signed by Thich Huyen Quang on 25/6/1992 to the Hanoi authorities.

Instead of listening and considering the UVBC's genuine and sound desires, the GOSRV is continuing on their criminal path of repression and persecution: torturing till death Venerable Thich Thien An in late September 1992 in Chi Hoa prison, arresting Venerables Thich Khong Tanh and Thich Tri Luc in 2/10/92, and carrying out other oppressive measures, such as threats, distortion, slander, preventing communication, searching of religious places and private homes, etc of Buddhist monks, nuns and lay people who support the UVBC.

In 1981, the GORSV intervened by creating the Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), a puppet body, with the intent of dispossessing the Buddhist clergy and lay communities. Many clergy have been forced to join VBC, and threatened due to their support to the UVBC.

para.tab: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate make stronger representation to the GOSRV by:

1. Urging that, in order to enjoy good relations with Australia and to receive equitably Australian tax payers' aid, the GOSRV must response, promptly, two Motions passed by the Australian Senate in 24/6/1992 and by the House of Representatives in 20/8/1992 condemning the repressive actions of the GOSRV.

2. Asking the Prime Minister of Australia send his Diplomatic Note to the Prime Minister of the GOSRV, Mr Vo Van Kiet expressing the strongest disapproval of the religious intolerance and intervention and oppression of religious organisations, especially the UVBC.

3. Requesting that the GOSRV restore and recognise the independence of the UVBC's structure and activities; to release, from prison or home custody, the UVBC's clergy, ie. Venerables Huyen Quang, Quang Do, Duc Nhuan, Tue Sy, Tri Sieu, Nguyen Giac, Phuc Vien, Thien Tan, etc, including newly arrested monks Khong Tanh and Tri Luc (in 2/10/92).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

speech.para: BROADCASTING SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1993
This Bill introduces changes to Part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to modify some aspects of the procedures for allocating Satellite Subscription Television Broadcasting Licences A and B.

Let me make clear at the outset that this amendment does not apply to those tenderers who were announced as the highest bidders on 30 April 1993. Those companies' applications are now at the second stage of the established process which will continue to finality. This legislation does not reflect a judgement that either of the current highest bidders is unable to meet its bid, and to ensure that appropriate procedures are in place should such a contingency arise.
The process to allocate these licences, which was determined under Section 93 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, has 3 stages.
The first stage that has just been completed, involves an impartial assessment of complying tenders to identify which delivered the highest bid price.

The second stage involves assessment of the tenderers so identified by the Australian Broadcasting Authority who will need to form a view about the suitability of the applicants under Section 98 of the Act. The ABA will also seek the opinion of the Trade Practices Commission in relation to Part IV of the Trade Practices Act as required under section 93 of the Act.
The third stage involves actual issuance of the licence but only after the ABA and TPC processes have been satisfied, and the full bid price paid.
Under the legislation, Trade Practices Commission consideration could take up to 45 days. Following that, licensees have 30 days within which to pay the bid price.

The interest of the public is that the issuance of pay television licences and the effective commencement of broadcasting services should occur as soon as possible. This has always been the Government's intention.
Until licences A and B are issued, it is not possible for the standard for a digital transmission system to be declared, nor for a third licence to be issued to the ABC.

The legislation before the Senate therefore provides that, in the event that either of the present highest tenderers were not successful, any alternative tenderer who thereby had the opportunity to be assessed as a potential licensee would be required to provide a 5% deposit within 3 days of being given that opportunity.
That deposit would not be refundable if the licence was not subsequently allocated, unless non-allocation was due to an unfavourable report by the Trade Practices Commission.

This amendment will put an additional step in the process after the initial identification of highest bidders—its purpose is to provide an additional indication that those tenderers have the financial capacity to pay the price bid hence justifying continuation of the process through its detailed assessment stages.
Financial Impact
The Bill is not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) BILL 1993

The purpose of the Road Transport Charges (Australian Capital Territory) Bill 1993 is to give effect to the National Road Transport Commission's (NRTC) first determination regarding annual registration charges for vehicles rated above 4.5 tonnes and permit charges for vehicles operating above 125 tonnes. The Bill is vital to the Government's national micro-economic reform agenda for land transport.

For too long the efficiency of Australia's interstate road transport operations has been impeded by a lack of uniformity in regulations and charging. Currently heavy vehicle operating conditions and registration charges vary considerably between nine different jurisdictions and bear little relation to the costs imposed on the road system by various types of vehicles.

The NRTC, which is an independent statutory authority, was established as a result of the Heads of Government Agreement of July 1991 and set up under Commonwealth legislation passed in December 1991. Its purpose is to investigate and make recommendations regarding the establishment of a national registration scheme and uniform road use charges for heavy vehicles, and nationally consistent operating regulations for all vehicles.

The Intergovernmental Agreement, which forms a schedule to The National Road Transport Commission Act 1991, requires the NRTC to recommend charges for heavy vehicles which: achieve full cost recovery; achieve a reasonable balance between administrative simplicity, efficiency and equity; improve the link between pricing and investment decisions; and minimise the incentive for road transport operators to shop around for lower charges.

The Ministerial Council approved the NRTC charging determination on behalf of State and Territory Governments. It is envisaged that each of the States and the Northern Territory will pass legislation in their respective Parliaments which will adopt the legislation passed in respect of the Australian Capital Territory and any Regulations made under it. This will ensure that there is uniform charging for heavy vehicles throughout Australia.

In accordance with the Intergovernmental Agreement, this Bill will require the Government of the Australian Capital Territory, from 1 July 1995 onwards, to fix annual registration charges for vehicles rated above 4.5 tonnes and to fix charges for the granting of permits to operate vehicles with a gross mass exceeding 125 tonnes. Those charges will be fixed in accordance with the schedule to the Bill. The Bill will not affect the existing registration scheme in the Australian Capital Territory other than to fix the charges to be collected when a heavy vehicle is registered. Responsibility for determining registration exemptions or concessional charges will continue to be a matter for the Australian Capital Territory. Revenue from the registration charges will be retained by the Territory.

The charges provided for in the schedule to the Bill may be increased or decreased by regulations under the proposed Act. The amount of increase or decrease is limited to a maximum of 5% per annum. Heads of Government have agreed that the matter of concessional registration charges for particular groups is for each State and Territory to address according to their own priorities, with the cost to revenue being met from their own budgets. In accordance with this decision, the NRTC charging determination does not make recommendations on the level and structure of concessions.

During the process of implementing national charges, the States and Territories will be reviewing the structure of registration concessions in their individual jurisdictions, including those which apply to the rural sector. The charges provided for in this Bill do not include, and the schedule does not preclude, the fixing of fees for administration and other services provided by the Australian Capital Territory.

In this context, it would be contrary to the spirit of the Intergovernmental Agreement for Governments to impose administration or inspection fees that varied greatly across jurisdictions, as road transport operators would see these as part of the total cost of registering a vehicle. This would encourage operators to shop around between the States and Territories. A working group of officials is currently examining the issue of acceptable and uniform levels of administrative charges and inspection fees and is expected to complete its report in the next couple of months.

As in the Australian Capital Territory, revenues from national registration charges received by the States and Northern Territory will be retained by them and will be available for use on roads. The use of those funds, including distribution to local councils, and the determination of road funding needs, will be decided by each jurisdiction.

The passage of this Bill is testimony to the continuing commitment of the Federal Government to implementing the reforms in the road transport industry which have been needed for so long, and which were agreed to by Heads of Government. I expect that Heads of Government will honour their commitment made in the Intergovernmental Agreement and all administrations will implement the reforms by July 1995.

Road transport is an essential part of our land transport system, and approximately 70 per cent of freight which is moved in Australia travels by road at some stage. Australia cannot afford to squander opportunities to bring about workable and acceptable reforms in the road transport industry, and assist in enhancing Australia's international competitiveness. There will be no significant costs, revenues or savings to the Commonwealth arising from the Bill.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

The proposed amendments to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 will provide for a one year extension to the repayment period for the wool industry debt. That debt currently stands at $2.26 billion and is backed by a Government guarantee.

The Government's recently announced package of measures, of which this amendment forms part, is in response to the deteriorating conditions in the wool industry. We have experienced reduced demand for our wool due to the continuing global recession affecting our key markets in Western Europe and Japan and the virtual withdrawal of Russia from the market. In combination with this we are faced with continuing over-production, a 3.9 million bale stockpile and wool prices which are at their lowest level in real terms in over 40 years. The key elements of the recent package provide immediate relief from the short term circumstances facing the industry and set in train a process to address the more fundamental issues in the longer term.

Mr President, as you will be aware, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is charged with the responsibility of managing the stockpile and discharging the industry's debt which was accumulated under the former wool Reserve Price Scheme. It is to undertake this in a manner that is in the best interests of the nation and woolgrowers in particular. The legislation currently requires the Commission to acquit the debt within 7 years or less. The Commission ceases to exist upon the sale or transfer of all assets and repayment of the debt.
This amendment will now give the Commission 8 years, from 1 July 1991, in which to repay the debt and the Government guarantee will also be extended by one year.

In current circumstances it was apparent that the Commission could not retire the debt within the requirements of its current schedule, without an adverse impact on an already deteriorating wool market. The Commission was not in a position to sell significant quantities of its stocks without further depressing the market. At the same time the Government agreed that woolgrowers could not afford increased tax payments to maintain the debt repayment schedule.

In providing an additional year in which to repay the debt, the Government is providing the Commission with the opportunity to be able to meet its objectives, minimising the effect on woolgrowers' incomes, but ensuring that the responsibility for the debt remains with woolgrowers.

As a result of these changes and changes which the Government will shortly be making to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (Performance of Functions) Guidelines, the Commission will not need to sell wool in 1993/94 to meet its obligations. Under the changed Guidelines the Commission will not be required to repay debt in 1993/94 beyond the $118 million funds already in hand for this purpose. This should entirely remove any speculative element that might exist in the market that the Commission will be required to make forced sales.

Mr President, the amendment that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is proposing together with the other elements of the wool industry package recently announced are vital to assist the industry overcome the difficulties currently facing it.
I commend this Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

talk.start.para: —This motion by Senator Faulkner seeks to restrict the speaking time of senators on a second reading debate from 30 minutes to 20 minutes. Some people on the other side of the chamber may find that a good idea. That may be a reflection on how much respect they have for the Senate chamber, but this is an important place and the matters discussed here are important. Senator Patterson moved the amendment to the motion to ensure that if Bills are taken cognately, the 20-minute speaking limit should not apply.

para.tab: That is an eminently sensible proposal. Even the people on the other side would have to recognise that when Bills are taken cognately there are many matters that have to be dealt with by members of the Opposition front bench, who of course have to speak in some cases on behalf of a shadow Minister in the other place and sometimes in their own capacity. It is entirely appropriate that in those circumstances honourable senators be given a full and adequate opportunity to address those issues.

A perfect example of the necessity of having a 30-minute speaking time, at least in so far as a cognate debate is concerned, occurred immediately after this motion was last dealt with by the Senate. We moved to the adjournment debate and Senator Bell raised two matters, both in relation to the State of Tasmania. It took Senator Bell—and I know he was trying to get through it as quickly as possible—almost 30 minutes to deal with the two matters. That is not a criticism of Senator Bell; it merely points out the absurdity of saying that we can deal in the space of 20 minutes with two or more Bills which are being taken together. We cannot do it.

How is this Senate to give adequate consideration to three or four tax Bills which Senator Watson has an obligation to address in detail? How could he deal in a second reading debate with three or four very complex tax Bills if he were given but 20 minutes to discuss them all together? The Senate knows the contribution that Senator Watson has made to the good administration of taxation in this country through the very detailed work that he has done in this chamber, many times—

talk.start.para: —He has fixed up a lot of their messes.

—As Senator Baume says, on many occasions he has fixed the mess that the Government has made of Bills. Senator Watson has the capacity and the diligence to work through the Bills clause by clause. If the Government decides that it wants to consider cognately at the second reading stage four or five taxation amendment Bills covering different matters, there is no way that Senator Watson could deal with each of those Bills if he is allowed four or five minutes per Bill. It is a nonsense.

para.tab: We only have to look at the appalling nature of the Government's taxation legislation in the last parliament to recognise that it does not have a clue about how to run the tax system. I am not talking about issues of policy; I am talking about important issues of detail. Of course, the Government has not thought through the consequences of its legislation. When we have a government that does not think through the consequences of legislation, who is it whose task it is to protect the taxpayer? Who is it whose task it is to protect the community at large? It is the task of the Opposition. To complete that task, to do its duty, the Opposition needs adequate time to consider these Bills properly. We are not a rubber stamp of the Government.

Opposition senators
—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para:
—I thank honourable colleagues. This chamber is not here merely to agree to whatever the Government wants but to give adequate consideration to what is before it.
It is no laughing matter that the House of Representatives is unfortunately unable to do these things. Frequently, we in this chamber jest to some degree about our colleagues in the other place. We do so because we know and they know that the House of Representatives is not capable of giving these matters adequate consideration. In part, one of the reasons why the House of Representatives is incapable of giving these matters adequate representation is that the members in that place have a speaking time of 20 minutes. So do we become like the House of Representatives or do we, as honourable senators, do our duty and work through these Bills properly until our consideration is completed?

para.tab: I see that Senator Sowada has come into the chamber. She has spent a lot of time in this place looking at education issues. She knows, particularly in relation to Austudy, that these are complex matters. She knows that they are not merely in-principle decisions that require a yea or a nay but issues of detail that have to be worked through. How can three or four education Bills taken cognately at the second reading stage be disposed of in a speech of 20 minutes? How can Senator Sowada be expected to give in but 20 minutes the position of her party on a group of Bills that deal with higher education? It cannot be done.

I turn to my friend Senator Harradine. Although he does not speak frequently in this place, he makes speeches of enlightenment which really go to the nub of the issues before the Senate. If the speaking time available to Senator Harradine—who has only one opportunity to express his point of view, who is not part of a team as we are in the Opposition, and who cannot allocate different points to different people if they cannot be dealt with in the course of the time allotted to him—were reduced to 20 minutes, how would he be able to give adequate representation to his State of Tasmania and the people he represents and how would he be able to express the principles he holds true?

Senator Faulkner has said in defence of this proposition—and I say `in defence of this proposition', not `advancing this proposition'—that if one cannot say it in 20 minutes, it is not worth saying. It took him, I hasten to add, between 15 and 18 minutes to advance that very simple proposition. Senator Faulkner got up on his hind legs, thinking he was the new Cicero of the Senate chamber, and gave us a lesson entitled `Do as I say and not as I do'. It was one of the most abjectly boring speeches the Senate has heard in a long time.

talk.start.para: —But typical.

—Typical, except in this case he exceeded even his own outstanding standards. Senator Faulkner lurched from one point to the next, like a drunken sailor on the road of intellectual pursuit on the way back to his sinking ship. Senator Faulkner advanced not one reason why the conduct of business in this place would be improved. He advanced not one reason for us to say, `Yes, the Senate will be able to give better organisation to these Bills'. He could not come before the Senate and say that by cutting back the speaking time from 30 minutes to 20 we are going to give more enlightened discussion. Of course he could not do that; it would be a nonsense. Senator Faulkner well knows what cutting back the speaking time from 30 minutes to 20 will achieve: it will give less enlightened discussion to these matters. Of course, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner has a vested interest in having less enlightened discussion on these matters.

para.tab: It behoves the Senate and it behoves every individual honourable senator to give proper consideration to whether, in the space of a couple of minutes, we are going to vote for a measure which will make it less easy for us to do our job on behalf of our constituents. Very simply, the proposition we will have to decide on in a couple of minutes is this: do we vote to do our job less well than we do it at the moment? Do we vote to give our second-best to our constituents, or do we vote to do the job thoroughly until the job is done? That is the standard we expect of every other Australian and that is the standard we should expect of ourselves.

Of course Senator Faulkner would say, `But most of the second reading speeches that have been given in this chamber over the last three years—some 67 per cent of second reading speeches—have been dealt with in 20 minutes or less'. That is absolutely correct, because honourable senators do not enjoy having to get up and speak for 30 minutes. Speaking for 30 minutes is a hard task, particularly when one has complex matters to deal with. But it is that 24, 25, or 26 per cent of speeches that go over the 20 minutes that are the exception for which we should make provision.

For example, when the 20-minute rule applied at the end of the last session in the lead-up to Christmas, I well recollect how my National Party Senate Leader, Senator Boswell, in speaking on the rural crisis, required an extension of time—which, I am pleased to say, was given to him by the Senate—so that he could outline the concerns of the people of Queensland in relation to the rural crisis, the drought and the effects it had not just on farmers but on people who live in rural communities. Of course, it should not be the case that a leader of a party speaking on an issue which goes right to the core of what that party stands for should be obliged to go on bended knee to the other side of the chamber to beg for another three or four minutes to complete a speech which he had already gutted to try to fit into the 20 minutes.

That should not be what this chamber is about. This chamber should be about freedom of speech; this chamber should be about adequate consideration; and this chamber should be the bastion of the liberties of Australians. How can this chamber complete its obligations in that respect if honourable senators in this place are gagged to 20 minutes because it suits Senator Faulkner and so that Senator Faulkner can get home on time. That is what this is all about: Senator Faulkner getting home on time.

I point out to my colleagues in the Democrats who sit to my left that we in small parties, more so than those in large, need the full 30 minutes to lay down our point of view. In the Democrats there is an arrangement whereby individual senators deal with particular areas of interest. In the National Party we have an informal arrangement where some of us take particular interest in certain matters. For example, Senator Bjelke-Petersen has during her time in the Senate taken a particular interest in family issues and issues affecting women who live outside the capital cities. Therefore, we do not have an array of speakers to deal with particular matters. We cannot throw four or five adequately briefed senators into the debate. In many cases we have but one senator to lay down our point of view. That one senator should be allowed the opportunity to lay down that point of view fully, adequately and thoroughly so that everybody—not just in this Senate chamber but also throughout the community—knows the view of that particular party.

Many times in this chamber I have disagreed with views that honourable senators have put, but I have never disagreed with the right of that senator to put that view. I take as an example the former Senator Vallentine from Western Australia. There perhaps would have been one occasion on which I have agreed with Senator Vallentine on an in principle issue. I remember that on numerous occasions Senator Vallentine would come into the chamber on the adjournment debate, not having been in the chamber all day, and then proceed to give an adjournment speech of 30 minutes which would cover some 20 pages of finely printed text. I know on a couple of occasions that people from either side protested—and in a couple of cases the Senate proceeded to call the quorum on Senator Vallentine on the adjournment.

talk.start.para: —But not you, Bill.

—As Senator Kemp says, I never cooperated with an attempt to count out Senator Vallentine. I know some people may hold that against me as a grudge, but Senator Vallentine had a right to speak. I supported her right to speak. That is why I stand before the Senate today and say that we should not do now what we have been loath to do in the past. We should not further restrict Senate speaking time when adequate speaking time is the hallmark of the enlightened and reasoned debate for which this Senate chamber is justifiably proud and famous, not just in this country but throughout the region. In many countries with which we deal, people say that the Australian Senate is one of the finest chambers of review that one will find anywhere. That is why I ask honourable senators to think carefully about this. I urge them not just to support Senator Patterson's amendment, but also to oppose the proposal that Senator Faulkner has brought before this chamber and overturn this attempt to make us do our job any less well than we possibly can.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —The proposal to reduce speaking time from 30 minutes to 20 minutes for a second reading speech does not have my support. When I first came into this chamber, I am not so sure that there was any time limit on debate.
—One hour.

—Was it an hour then or did it come in as an hour? However, it was at least an hour. Some of the most erudite and intelligent speeches were made during that particular period; some of the most boring that I have heard were made as well. In a debate on the Constitution, which is a very important matter, I well recall Reg Wright in the chamber down in the old Parliament House making an inspired speech. People came in and listened for the duration of his speech.

para.tab: The problem with this chamber—and more particularly with the House of Representatives—is that we do not listen as we should to what other senators are saying in their speeches during second reading debates. It is during their speeches in second reading debates that senators are able to deliver their views on the principles contained in the legislation. I am very concerned about this measure, even though it will not affect me or many others in this chamber very much at all.

I have a document, which I think has not been tabled, prepared by Senate officers which shows the number of senators who took 20 minutes or less to deliver their speeches during second reading debates. In the autumn session of 1990, 63 per cent of speakers took 20 minutes or less. In the Budget session of 1990, 76 per cent of speakers took 20 minutes or less. The figure was 68 per cent for the autumn session of 1991; 78 per cent for the Budget session of 1991; 76 per cent for the autumn session of 1992; and 59 per cent for the Budget session of 1992. Samples of the average time taken to deliver speeches during second reading debates in the 36th Parliament showed that 75 per cent took 20 minutes or less.

What time saving is the Government really going to achieve? As Senator O'Chee has said, those who took more than 20 minutes to deliver their speech obviously decided they had something to say which would take more time. People normally do not get up and speak for the sake of speaking, and one reason for that is that hardly anybody is listening. It is unfortunate that in the other chamber very few members come into the chamber to listen to what people have to say in their speeches during second reading debates about the principles of the Bills that are before them.

On Monday of this week the guillotine came down in the House of Representatives and a government imposed time limit was set for the consideration of Bills in that chamber. As we saw at the end of last session and, sadly, at the end of the session before that—and I think in the session before that—the guillotine came down in this chamber as well.

talk.start.para: —Yes, with the Democrats' help.

—That is the sad part of it. The Democrats agreed with the Government to impose time limits on the debate on particular Bills in this chamber as well. This is the house of review. Admittedly, there are more members in this chamber who come in and listen to second reading debates, but we cannot always be here; therefore, we have the debates broadcast to our offices. I must admit that very often that is where I listen, whilst doing other things, to what other honourable senators are saying in their contributions to second reading debates.
—How many Labor people are listening to you now?
—I hope that they are glued to the television sets in their rooms.
—They are.

—Dare I suggest that they are not looking at this. My point is that, as members of parliament, we have two broad functions in this chamber, which is our house of review. We have our expressive function and we have the function of audit and control over executive government decisions. As to the latter, I am very concerned that this measure will be the first step towards limiting the time for debate in the Committee of the Whole. I have always believed that that debate is a crucial time for clarifying what the government has in mind and for challenging the understanding of the Minister at the table as to what practical effect a Bill will have.

para.tab: The second reading stage of a Bill is very important because it is often in that time that you make up your mind whether a measure ought to be supported. When I say `you', I mean me, the Greens and, presumably, the Democrats, unless the Democrats have it cut and dried before they get into the chamber—unless some sort of arrangement has been made with the Government. That would mean, sadly, that the views of others around this chamber would not be taken account of. The Democrats could say, `It doesn't matter about the views of other people in this chamber'. I suppose that is true, except that those views are really the views of the substantial number of people who have voted for—

talk.start.para: —The electors.

—They are the views of the electors. If the views of the electors as expressed by us here are not taken into account by groups such as the Democrats, then I believe they are not undertaking their correct role in this place. If the Democrats are going to vote with the Government on this matter, I suggest that they have another think about it. It is all very well for them to say that, with seven members, they can truncate debate on the second reading speech to 20 minutes per speaker. They might like to give away their rights, their responsibilities, in respect of their expressive function, but they cannot decide to do that so far as I am concerned.

para.tab: I have my rights in this chamber as an Independent member. Why should they, together with the Government, trample on those rights? Not only are they my rights, they are also the rights of those who elected me to express their views about very important matters, as Senator O'Chee has said. Take, for example, the debate on the Address-in-Reply or the debate on the Budget. Billions of dollars are involved, a whole raft of areas of concern to the electorate and whole areas of ministerial responsibility.

talk.start.para: —It took 60 minutes for the Governor-General's address. We will have to deal with it in 20.
—Senator O'Chee has just made a very interesting point. I think it took the Governor-General over 60 minutes—
—It took 65.

—I felt sorry for him. Somebody should have edited that speech. It took him 65 minutes to deliver the speech, and now we are being told that we will have only 20 minutes to reply to it. Well, egalitarianism has really hit us, has it not? The representative of the Crown can have 65 minutes to speak but a humble senator can have only 20 minutes to reply. That is justice, that is fairness, that is equity, is it not?

speech.para: There are other very important issues coming up. No doubt at some stage a referendum Bill will come before this Parliament. Why should we, in an important issue such as that, be confined to speaking for 20 minutes? Why should we be confined to speaking for 20 minutes on important issues such as unemployment? The sad part about that is that it does not very often come before the Parliament in the form of a Bill. Why should we have to rely on adjournment speeches if we wish to exercise our expressive functions in a particular matter? I say this not because I take half an hour under normal circumstances; I generally attempt to say what I can and sit down and question matters through the Estimates or in the Committee of the Whole.

talk.start.para: —When they let you.

—That is the other point that I come back to. This is what concerns me. Our rights in the areas of audit and control of government actions are gradually being taken away or questioned. I am opposed to this measure. Obviously, the amendment moved by Senator Patterson is an attempt to gain the numbers in this place for some lesser situation.
—A fall-back.

—Yes, a fall-back situation. I am opposed to this measure by the Government because I believe it is part and parcel of an approach to undermine our functions in this Parliament as a house of review and our ability at least at this stage to express the views of our electors in a reasonable time on matters of principle relating to a measure brought before us by the Government.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen C.R.

talk.start.para: —I rise to oppose the motion moved by Senator Faulkner, the Manager of Government Business, to restrict the speaking time of senators. I fully endorse the remarks of Senator Harradine. The question Senator Harradine asked the chamber was: why should the rights of senators be restricted in this way?

speech.para: This is part of a pattern of measures which have come through at the start of this new Parliament which will have the effect of further curtailing the rights of senators to debate Bills and to make governments more accountable. That is a matter of great concern. There is probably no year on record in which the Government has attempted to get more Bills through the Parliament than it did last year. Certainly, a record number of Bills were passed by this chamber. If we are going to fulfil our duties as legislators, it is vitally important that we have every opportunity to make the points that we believe our constituents would wish us to make and to raise questions with the Government.

I have said this before and I will say it again: I think there is a desire in the community for parliaments to function better. There is a need to make executives more accountable to parliaments. Two royal commissions, one in Queensland and one in Western Australia, have made that very point—that it could be argued that the problems which emerged in those States showed that the parliaments were not acting effectively.

para.tab: It could be said that in a sense this motion is a small measure, that we have chopped 10 minutes off the time in which senators can make their contributions, but it is part of a succession of amendments to restrict the speaking rights of senators. Senator Harradine made the point quite effectively that some years ago senators could speak for an hour or so to make the contributions they felt were appropriate.

talk.start.para: —Is a one-third reduction a small measure?
—I said it could be argued that it is a small measure. I do not think it is. That is why I am speaking to this motion. I do not think it is a small measure.

para.tab: We came back into this Parliament reflecting the views of constituents to attempt to make Parliament more effective and governments more accountable. I rather hoped that the Australian Democrats would join with us in considering, in a sensible and balanced manner, the sorts of reforms which would be required to further improve the performance of the Parliament. It is a great pity that, despite the change of leadership that has occurred in the Australian Democrats and the change in numbers that will occur as a result of the election, so far the Australian Democrats under their new leadership have not joined us in this important cause.

We have proposed a number of motions to reform Question Time in a way which I thought was moderate and balanced, but they have been rejected. The Australian Democrats have decided to follow the Government line. There are other motions on the
Notice Paper
regarding changes to the procedures of standing committees which I believe will further have the effect of restricting the rights of senators.

I believe that proposals we have put up to improve the performance of standing committees and Question Time have received very short shrift from the Australian Democrats. That is a great pity. This was a chance to sit down together in a sensible and balanced manner and look at what could be done to improve the performance of this chamber. On many occasions in the last Parliament I spoke to Senator Coulter about the sorts of measures that we thought would improve this Parliament. Senator Coulter gave us very little comfort and tended constantly to buy the Government's line that somehow it was all so vital that the Government's program be rammed through this chamber in the shortest possible time. The guillotine was supported by the Australian Democrats, including Senator Coulter. I acknowledge that there were some changes to impose reasonable restraints on lengthy answers by Ministers, but they certainly were not the changes which I believe would have made a substantial difference.

I fear that a great opportunity has been missed to improve the performance of the Senate and to give a very clear lead to other chambers around the nation about what the elected members and senators of Parliament can do to carry out sensible reforms and make governments more accountable. Senator Faulkner is the new boy in the job and we would all want to give him a reasonable chance to see whether he can perform to make this chamber operate better. I am prepared to reserve judgment on just what sort of performance Senator Faulkner will give in his important new role as Manager of Government Business.

I have to say that there has not been a great start to this Parliament. Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, recently pointed out that no legislation of any substance has been debated in this chamber, despite the fact that we have now been back almost two weeks. In fact, the time of the chamber has been taken up with a whole host of procedural motions that Senator Faulkner seems determined to ram through this chamber without any sensible attempt to get a proper consensus and without any recognition of the need to make some changes. Instead, he has done a deal with the Democrats in an attempt to impose the Government's will on this chamber. It is a great pity that Senator Coulter and his colleagues have cooperated with him.

So the Parliament has resumed. A series of procedural motions have been brought forward before this chamber by Senator Faulkner which I believe will certainly restrict the effectiveness of the Senate. Days and days have been wasted, and I am sure that further days will be wasted. We on this side are committed to sensible reform in the Parliament and will be making it very clear that we are not prepared to concur in a further restriction of the rights of senators.

Senator Faulkner may, with the assistance of the Democrats, win a Pyrrhic victory on this issue and may well get this motion through. But I wonder whether Senator Faulkner has advised his colleagues that senators do have other rights and that any time saved as a result of this motion—I notice from Senator Faulkner's figures that practically no time will be saved on this motion—will be taken up with other procedures that are available to senators. For example, senators will have further time to contribute on second reading amendments. So there are ways around this motion, although they are somewhat untidy, but if this motion is forced through, they will undoubtedly be used.

Senator Faulkner's colleagues may well ask him in the weeks and months to come why he proceeded with this motion, which on his own figures was not needed, and why he insisted on taking up so much time of the chamber to ram it through. When the procedures are available, if senators are so disposed, they will be able to manage to circumvent the intention of the Government.

It is a pity that in a whole series of areas in which we are seeking to make reforms to the Senate chamber the Democrats have chosen not to support us. Once again, they have chosen to follow the Government road, which is again a pity. Senator Coulter will remember one of the least glorious aspects of his parliamentary career as being the Marshall Islands affair. Senator Coulter initially came out with guns blazing on that matter. We were going to have a Senate inquiry, as very important issues were involved. Indeed, the Marshall Islands affair is still occupying columns in newspapers today as new stories break.

Members of the Government spoke to Senator Coulter. They suggested to him that the real issue was not looking at the whole Marshall Islands affair or examining the behaviour of Ministers and public servants in relation to that issue; the real issue was about setting up a code of conduct for Ministers and that we really needed to get a committee together to do this. So we suddenly swung to having an inquiry into an issue of central importance and interest to the public. Who knows what that inquiry could have turned up.

Senator Faulkner—one would have to give him credit for this—spoke to the Democrats and convinced them that the real issue was the code of ethics of Ministers. So we set up a committee, which met four times but produced nothing. I would have thought it would be a most striking lesson to Senator Coulter that it is sometimes dangerous to lie down with the lion. In the end, he and his party were not advantaged by concurring with the Government's proposal on that issue.

As I said, that is just one of many issues in which Senator Coulter has chosen to concur with the view of the Government. At the end of the day, the Government was laughing that he had been conned. The public had not been informed properly as to the nature of those great events in relation to the Marshall Islands. I would have thought that would have been a warning to Senator Coulter and his colleagues.

I conclude by urging the Democrats, once again, to join with us not only in protecting the rights of senators—this Bill, of course, restricts the rights of senators—but in seeking to bring about major reforms to this Parliament. Senator Coulter and his colleagues will have to recognise one day that those reforms must involve making Government Ministers more accountable for their actions, more subject to scrutiny, and that will mean a better Question Time and a more effective committee system. I regret that it will not happen this time. We may have months and years to see how fast these reforms can be brought in.

As I say, I urge the Democrats to think again. The Democrats should not join with the Government in restricting senators' rights; rather, they should join with us in trying to enhance the performance of this Parliament, to ensure that the fundamental right of the public to know what governments are doing is protected, and to ensure that those whom they elect to these parliaments have the ability to ensure proper scrutiny of government actions.

talk.start.para: —This is just another step down the path of the Labor Party to reduce the Senate to impotence. It is not without relevance that the more thoughtful, the more intelligent and the more experienced senators of this chamber are all opposed to this move. I can remember, when I first came into this chamber, being a little concerned about one senator who was speaking. I said to the person sitting beside me, who at the time was Senator Reg Withers, arguably one of the greatest senators ever to have been in this chamber, `Why don't we move that he be no longer heard?'. He said, `Your views are not important. What is important is that every senator has the right to be heard'.

para.tab: One of the fundamental tenets of this chamber is that a senator is entitled to be heard. That cannot be an unlimited right but, as other speakers have said, it was not so many years ago that we had an hour to speak on a Bill. For years after I was elected there was the entitlement to speak for an hour on any Bill. What we are faced with now is not, as my colleague Senator Kemp says, a minimalist reduction from 30 minutes to 20 minutes. We are now in a situation where we have one-third of the entitlement we had when I first came into the chamber—20 minutes as against 60. That is a massive reduction.

The point of all of this is that the business of the chamber, in the eyes of the Labor Party, has to be reduced to the level of impotence that the House of Representatives now enjoys. The Labor Party has never matured in its thinking. It does not understand the exercise of power. It does not understand that power is not unqualified, that the right to exercise power carries with it certain responsibilities, and the most important of those responsibilities is the responsibility of accounting for the exercise of that power.

The accounting of the exercise of power cannot be done on television interviews; it cannot be done in the press. It can only be in the Parliament that the executive government is brought to account. Because of the limitations constitutionally on the House of Representatives, this chamber is the crucial chamber where governments are brought to account. So any move that denies the right of a senator to speak or the access of a senator to speak to some degree circumscribes the matter of accountability of the Government.

Mention has been made of the guillotine. When we were allowed to speak for an hour, the guillotine was rarely used, except by the Labor Party. If one goes through the
Hansards
, one will find that for the years we were in government, even though we granted senators the right of one hour to speak, we very rarely resorted to a guillotine and then only in extreme circumstances. The Labor Party loves the guillotine. I remember the time when Senator Murphy was Leader of the Senate. I think he guillotined 68 Bills through in 20 minutes. I was not here but the notoriety that that earned the Labor Party spread right throughout Australia. We have had the incredible situation where right at the start of this session the Labor Party has already introduced the guillotine in the House of Representatives, where it has absolute power.

Another manifestation of this same avoidance of accountability has been the marked deterioration of the committee system in the Senate. The committees are very dear to the proper functioning of the Senate. We have seen a marked reluctance on the part of the Labor Party to allow those committees to operate properly. Nothing demonstrates that better than the estimates committees, which are sitting at present. Mr Deputy President, how many times do you walk into an estimates committee and see only Liberal or National Party senators around the table forming the quorum?

talk.start.para: —That was the case on Monday night.

—Absolutely, and that has been true all the time I have been in this chamber. One of the new Labor senators said to me, `You only go to estimates committees because you are in Opposition and it advantages you'. This is not true. I do not doubt that that is part of the mythology the Labor Party indoctrinates into its new, gullible and foolish senators, but I reminded the honourable senator that that is not true at all. When we were in government, the most penetrating questions and the great majority of questions came from the Liberal and National parties inquiring of their Ministers and their public servants what happened.

—He's only got to read the
Hansards
.

—As Senator Walters says—and it is a very good point—we only have to open a
Hansard
. We can look at the
Hansards
for the last 10 years and we would probably find that about one per cent of the questions at estimates committees came from Labor Party senators. They simply do not use the system. They prefer the secret backroom deal of the Caucus committees. This is ultimately what is behind the whole of the republican movement for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is a naked grab for power of a Prime Minister who wants to take unto himself a new Constitution which puts greater powers in the hands of the party of the day governing the country. This is promoted by a Prime Minister who knows that at present he has absolute and total control over Caucus, so he is answerable to no-one.

para.tab: The other very upsetting manifestation of committees at present is not only the lack of cooperation of the Labor Party but also the arrogance of the chairmen of the committees and of the Ministers at the table to control and restrict the flow of questions to those committees. Unless we can have an honest answer or frank explanation from a public servant as to where money is proposed to be spent, we simply cannot have an examination at the level we need to assure the Senate that the Government is spending its funds properly. The incident last night where Senator Collins once more reverted to his characteristics, which I compared once to a dying wounded buffalo in the Northern Territory, and steadfastly refused to answer questions or allow questions to be answered is really a very serious assault on the committee system.

The matter we have before us this morning is not, with the greatest of respect to some of the speakers, a small reduction in time; it is a significant reduction in time, but it is part and parcel of a coordinated plan to reduce the powers of the Senate. If that happens, the whole of the democratic system in Australia falls into disrepair.

This matter of accountability cannot be overemphasised. We live in a society where compliance with the law is essential. If we do not comply with the law, society ends up in a state of anarchy. But compliance with that law is a voluntary matter. In general, people comply with the laws because they accept they are for the common good. One of the laws involves paying money. A lot of us in this country pay taxes. We pay those voluntarily—certainly, we can be pursued by the tax commissioner, but 99 per cent of the community pay their taxes voluntarily and on time. The reciprocal obligation on the Government of those taxing powers is to account for the expenditure of money. One of the principal ways of bringing the Government to account for that is in this chamber. I am implacably opposed to anything that restricts or diminishes the powers of the Senate to inquire into the proper workings of the Government. I therefore oppose this motion.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I congratulate you on taking the chair of the Senate for the first time in your role of assisting the President and Deputy President. I oppose the Government's motion that there be a restriction of 20 minutes placed on speeches by honourable senators in second reading debates. The principal argument that I put to the chamber is that the Senate is a precious, essential element of the Australian democracy and to restrict its powers is to undermine the ability of the Senate to fulfil its objective to represent the Australian people in ensuring—by scrutiny; by questioning; and by putting forward views, particularly contrary views—that there is a proper examination of all matters that come before this Parliament.

para.tab: It is with great regret that for a long time, especially in the last 10 years, we have seen legislative debate become all the more concentrated in the Senate. I believe it is tragic that the legislative scrutiny of this Parliament has now been virtually vacated by the House of Representatives. In saying that, I do not wish to show any disrespect for the other place—of course, it is against our Standing Orders to show any such disrespect—but I speak plainly when I say that the Senate is the only chamber where there is careful scrutiny of government legislation and, indeed, even of a large number of other areas such as government reports and inquiries by Senate committees.

The Government wants to put in place this fortnight a number of measures that will restrict the powers of honourable senators. It is in the spirit of opposing those measures that I speak against this measure. In concert with this proposal to reduce speaking time to 20 minutes we have a reduction of the powers of honourable senators to raise matters in the Committee of the Whole after estimates committee debates and the lamentable proposal, which is the next item of business today, to reduce the number of Senate committees from nine to seven. I am opposed to that and ready to speak on that matter as soon as we get onto it later this morning.

I am very much opposed to the restrictions that the Government is putting forward. Why is it doing it? The Government is the main proposer of legislation in the Parliament—indeed, it is the elected government that ought to be the main proposer of legislation—and it would suit it to have its proposals go through with the minimum of restraint, as they currently do in the House of Representatives.

It is a scandal that yesterday, the fourth day of sitting, a guillotine was introduced into the House of Representatives for 30 Bills to be handled with often only 20 minutes allocated to each Bill. That is the kind of intention that the Government can impose upon the House of Representatives because it has a majority there. Against whatever protests are put forward by Liberal and National party members of the House of Representatives, or by the two independent members, the Government has its way. Its way is achieved by its iron majority in the House of Representatives. So, because of what happened yesterday, 30 Bills are to be adopted, regardless of contrary view and regardless of debate. These Bills are all to be determined according to the Government's wish; that is, the Bills are not to be amended or varied in any way.

There has even grown an assumption by Government members that in practice any debate, any variation, any amendment—even any good amendment—any improvement of legislation and any channel through which the public can put a view about a proposal must happen in the Senate. The Government does not have a majority in the Senate. Also, we have a continuing tradition of examining every matter carefully and debating legislation at the second reading and committee stages. I point out that, had we been successful in March, on coming to government we would not have proposed such a reduction. We are not hypocritical in this matter: we treasure the powers of the Senate, and in government we would not have proposed this restriction.

Let me say to the Democrats that I believe former Senator Chipp and former Senator Mason, the first two Democrats who came here—they happened to be elected at the same time as Senator MacGibbon and I, in the 1977 election—would not in their hearts have supported any move by the Democrats to join, as they appear to be doing on this occasion, with the Government and vote in favour of this restriction. When we put together all of the restrictions that the Government—it appears with Democrat support—is proposing for this Senate, I believe Senator Chipp and Senator Mason, and even Senator Haines, would be very angry.

The earliest tradition of the Australian Democrats was to give proper regard to the Senate as a place of scrutiny, a place of debate, a place of argument, a place of bona fide examination of every proposal, a place of keeping everybody honest and a place of exposing through that scrutiny the views of the Australian public. It is a sad day to see restriction on restriction being proposed by a government and supported by the Democrats. I do not wish to labour this point, but I appeal to Senator Coulter, who is in the chamber, and to other Democrat senators watching the debate on television, to reconsider their position.

I want to make one thing very clear: I believe that on most occasions a 20-minute speech is better than a 30-minute speech. I believe that restricting a speech to 20 minutes is best achieved by self-restraint and self-discipline, not by such a restriction being placed in the Standing Orders of the Senate. I think there are times when honourable senators need 30 minutes to express properly their views on a particular Bill or even a series of Bills. I support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague Senator Patterson to except from the proposed 20-minute restriction speeches made on two or more Bills that are being debated cognately.

Let me give a practical example in support of Senator Patterson's proposition. I have for many years handled education Bills at the second reading stage for my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties. On one occasion I was summing up the views of these parties with regard to five education Bills. I remember that there was $10 billion involved in the Bills that were being considered by the Parliament. Even when such legislation comes up each six months, it contains a great complexity of new measures.

In trying to deal with five Bills in 30 minutes, I have on a couple of occasions asked for an extension of five minutes so that I could give proper weight to the five Bills over a 35-minute period. That is from a person who tries to limit speaking to the minimum that is required to put a view clearly and persuasively.

I put to the Senate that if this motion is carried with Democrat support for the Government's proposition, it will be able to be evaded. There is no such time restriction on speeches at the first reading or third reading stages and, as we know, 15 minutes is allowed to speakers on any matter at the committee stage. Under our current procedure there are occasions—for instance, the consideration of finance Bills—that allow for a speech on any topic. This opportunity has not been taken up in recent years as much as it was 12 or 15 years ago, when I was first here. If restrictions are imposed in this way, the Senate has its own way of getting around them. Any view a senator needs to express could be expressed through such alternative means—even including during the adjournment debate. I happen to think that a five-minute speech on the adjournment is an admirable self-restraint, but I have, along with others, spoken for 30 minutes on the adjournment on a few occasions. I believe, in retrospect, that the length of time I took on those occasions was justified because there was a need to speak comprehensively.

I put it to members of the Government and the Democrats that the ideal of 20 minutes or less that we all could be persuaded to accept is best achieved by self-restraint and not by the restriction that is now being placed on us. I give only one other example—the two-day special sitting in late January 1991 to debate the Gulf war. I regard it as one of the high points of the Senate in terms of the contributions of the approximately 50 senators to the debate on one motion. That one matter was before us for the two days and we spoke, as many will recall, until 3 and 4 o'clock in the morning to give everyone an appropriate turn. Many senators rightly spoke for 30 minutes. It is appropriate, when there is need for a full expression of view on a matter of major import to this country, that the Senate should allow that.

I conclude by urging colleagues among the Democrats and Independent senators to agree with Senator Harradine and to agree with the Liberal and National Party senators that we should not place restrictions such as that now proposed on the speaking time of senators. I urge that it at least be conceded that in cognate debates there ought not to be that restriction and that Senator Patterson's amendment should therefore be supported.

talk.start.para: —I think it is worth while, particularly as this debate is being broadcast, to remind everybody what the debate is about. It is about limiting senators' speaking time in the second reading stage of consideration of legislation to 20 minutes rather than the present 30 minutes. We also have before us an amendment which provides that, in the case of several Bills being debated cognately, the limitation of 20 minutes be removed and that we remain with the 30-minute allowance.

para.tab: The speeches I have heard so far from those in the Opposition have ranged very widely away from that particular point. I was rather intrigued by Senator Kemp's mention of the Marshall Islands. I was a little unsure as to how the debates that went on during the so-called Marshall Islands affair relate to the matter of speech time limits. The Senate may well be aware that there is a parliamentary delegation going to a number of South Sea Island countries. I am hoping to be a member of that delegation, which I believe might be leaving in June. I might, for the edification of senators, be approaching Senator Richardson for a reference to give to a few people over there or perhaps an introduction to people to see whether I could set up a suitable immigration scam! That seemed to me to be the only relevance of Senator Kemp's comments to the debate this morning.

The point that really needs to be stressed was made by Senator Baden Teague; that is, it is true that, since no party has had the numbers in the Senate to ram legislation through on numbers alone, it is in this chamber that legislation has been properly considered. There is no doubt about that at all. That is not a function of the speaking times; it is a function of the way the numbers fall in this chamber.

To pick up the assertion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and assert the opposite, I remind everybody that, under the unrepresentative system of election of the House of Representatives, it is possible for a party with just over 12 per cent of the vote to gain government. It is in the Senate, with its proportional representation system, that we have a properly representative chamber. I see Senator Watson looking puzzled. I would invite him to do the numbers on just three parties seeking election and to recognise that the party that wins government has to win only 25 per cent of the votes plus one vote in 50 per cent of the seats plus one seat. That adds up to just over 12 per cent of the vote. So the House of Representatives is a very unrepresentative House.

I observe the hypocrisy of the Opposition in that during the recent election it was claiming very vociferously that, had it won government, we the Democrats should simply lie down and agree with most of what was in its Fightback package. We went to the electors with an undertaking to oppose certain elements, such as the goods and services tax, and we had a mandate from our supporters to come back, if the Opposition had won government, and carry that view. We had a responsibility to carry that view into this chamber and if the numbers had prevailed then, in relation to the point Senator Baden Teague made about government scrutiny, the boot would have been on the other foot. If the coalition had won government it would not—as the present government has done—have done so with over 50 per cent of the vote.

This chamber is the proper chamber of the people where proper scrutiny of legislation, government and every aspect of administration occurs simply because of the numbers and because no party—neither government nor opposition—has the numbers to ram anything through this chamber without the support of at least one other group. I think that point needs to be stressed. Senator Baden Teague was quite correct in pointing to the important role of the Senate, but I think his diagnosis went astray when he tried to link that with the length of time allowed for speeches in second reading debates.

I come back to a more specific example—a debate we have only just recently had in this chamber. During the last session, in December, legislation was passed, as other senators know, which removed from pensioners some of their entitlements if their shares gained in value, and that would come in in September. The Opposition supported that legislation introduced by the Government. It has now changed its position. Are Opposition senators suggesting for a moment that, had they each had half an hour to debate that matter back in December, they might have taken a different position? Of course, that is absolute nonsense. They had made up their minds on that position. It took them from December to May to change their minds, and now they have decided to support what we supported back in December.

Are they suggesting that they should have had a second reading debate from December to May so that they might, in the course of it, change their minds? Of course not. They came in here with a position; they supported the Government; and they denied the pensioners of this country the proper scrutiny of that legislation. They were too quick with their economic rationalist line to recognise that justice was far more important than adherence to an abstract economic ideology. Fortunately, now they have changed their minds.

I raise that point also because even this morning's
Sydney Morning Herald
has got it wrong and, again, is accusing the Democrats of not opposing that legislation in December. It was the Opposition which supported the Government on that occasion and denied proper scrutiny of that piece of legislation. It had whatsoever nothing to do—and this is the point—with whether there is half an hour or 20 minutes or any other time limit set on speeches at the second reading stage.

Senator Teague also made the very significant point that in the committee stage of the debate senators can speak for up to 15 minutes as many times as they like. It is at the committee stage of the debate—and I stress that word `debate'—that true debates occur. That is where we get into the nitty-gritty of legislation; that is where we change the legislation; that is where we move amendments to legislation. As I say, if one feels strongly about a particular amendment, provided there is objection to it—and presumably there is objection if one has to debate it—one can get up and continue to make points with respect to that amendment, and there is no limitation on that debate.

It is at the second reading stage, which is improperly called a debate, that each party states its general philosophical position with respect to that legislation. As Senator Harradine has pointed out, from statistical evidence, between two-thirds and three-quarters of speeches are 20 minutes or less, and he gave an account of that over several sessions of this Parliament.

The question then arises: how much more useful were the one-quarter to one-third of speeches which actually went over that 20-minute time limit? I suggest that the majority of them, as Senator Teague suggested, probably could easily, with great benefit, have been reduced to the 20-minute limit. The detailed points that need to be raised, particularly if they lead to an amendment and a change to the legislation, can be dealt with in the committee stage.

I pick up a point here that Senator O'Chee made. On several occasions it has been quite clear that senators in this place have spoken for 20 minutes, half-an-hour or whatever the limit at that time happened to be; they clearly have been in need of additional time, have sought leave and, to my knowledge, that leave has not been refused. I would disagree with Senator O'Chee when he rather pejoratively suggested that Senator Boswell had to get on bended knee and go to the Government to get that leave. I would suggest that most of us in this chamber would recognise that if a speaker was making valid points, clearly in continuation of some argument, and then sought leave, that leave would be granted. That mechanism would not be needed very often. The Opposition has many members in this chamber and it can put two or three speakers on. It can easily cover the philosophical aspects of a piece of legislation over the course of an hour by putting on three speakers. So there is not, in that sense, a limitation.

Somebody remarked along the way that the Governor-General's speech should have been edited. I could not agree more with that statement. I think it is clear that various government departments simply threw together their particular pieces in the speech. The speech was often repetitive. It looked almost as though it dealt with points in alphabetical order because women came well down on the list. I hope that does not indicate the low—

talk.start.para: —It was long and boring; a bit like this one.

—I agree with Senator Macdonald; it was an extremely boring speech. The guts of what the Government was on about could easily have been dealt with, I believe, in a 20-minute speech. It would have been crisper; it would have been to the point. Again, what we are looking at in that speech is a declaration of the philosophical direction, the general direction, which the Government is taking—not the detail. The detail is dealt with elsewhere.

para.tab: It is for those reasons that we are supporting the Government on this motion. I simply stress that the so-called second reading debates are not debates; they are statements of position for which, in our view, 20 minutes is quite adequate. We would certainly resist—and strongly resist—any limitation on the committee stage of the debate. We certainly would not object if leave were sought for an extension of time if a speaker clearly needed an extra few minutes to complete a speech; I would hope that the Government would also extend that courtesy to any speaker.

talk.start.para: —We have the situation where yesterday Senator Evans, down in the members' hall, had a bit of a dig at the Senate for not yet having got any Bills through. We are now debating procedural motions. I do not think anybody today—even the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner)—has said that this motion is urgent and that we must look at it today. We have two and a half weeks left of this sitting. We have not had a Bill presented to us. We have the Government looking for things to put before the Senate to keep us occupied, and one of the things is this procedural motion for debate.

para.tab: We must not let the Government come to the Senate at the end of May and ask for the guillotine to get Bills through. We on this side of the chamber would not assist in any way—and I would be surprised if the Democrats would. Senator Coulter has not said in his speech that this is urgent; that we must debate it today; that this is something so important that government Bills will be set aside to make time for this debate. So I hope at the end of May, when, no doubt, the Government will be trying to make us go through umpteen Bills in a day, that the Democrats will not support the Government in trying to gag debate on the Bills coming before the Senate. That would be a complete and utter injustice.

talk.start.para: —What if they want to go home?

—We will not go into that one. Let us have a look at what this is all about, and deal first with what the Government has said. The Government has said that 30 minutes is too long. The Government also has said that an hour is too long. It has cut speeches from an hour down to half an hour. The Government then said that half an hour is too long, that we ought to be able to say all we have to say in 20 minutes and that there is no reason for a speech in a second reading debate to take half an hour.

para.tab: Let us have a look how the Government treats its own members. Look at them over there: not one of them has stood in this place and supported the Minister. Not one backbench government member has stood and supported the Government. When we were in government we matched them speaker for speaker.

talk.start.para: —That was a long time ago now, Shirley.

—That was a long time ago, but we conducted the Senate in true democratic fashion. We believed in the debate in this place. The government members and the Democrats do not believe in the debate in the Senate. As I said, the Minister stood up and said what the Government is going to do, and nobody was permitted to speak to support him. All government members are there for, all they are sitting in their seats for, is the vote.
—Because we are the Government.

—That is not true, and it is not the way that government members should approach debate in the Senate. As I said, when we were in government we kept matching them speaker for speaker on every occasion on every Bill and on every procedural motion that came up before us. There was none of this, `You don't talk. You sit back. Don't debate it in the Senate. You are only there to vote and nothing else'. It is typical of how the Government believes democracy works.

para.tab: We have had lots of experience of the Labor Party form of government. We know how the Labor Party conducts its Caucus meetings. I know that the students in the gallery will understand that a secret ballot is meant to be that. You are meant to be able to vote and that vote is meant to have nothing do with anyone else. It is your decision alone. Your ballot is secret. But when the Labor Party Caucus has a secret ballot, what do Caucus members have to do? Immediately they make their ballot they have to show it to one of their factional members. Good democracy! The way this Government conducts democracy is to have a so-called secret ballot, where a member voting must show his vote to another factional member—because they do not trust each other—who will check up on him and make sure that he is doing the right thing. That is the way the Government believes democracy ought to be run.

Let us come to the second reason why the Government is indulging in this proposal. For years and years the policy of the Government, the policy of the Labor Party, was to abolish the Senate. That was written into its policy.

talk.start.para: —It wasn't.

—It is no use Senator Schacht saying that it was not. It was written into Labor Party policy, into its platform. We all knew about it—it was front page in the newspapers—when Senator Evans came in here and said, `Look, it's not good public relations to have it written into the policy. Let us take it out of the written part of the policy. I am going in there and I will white-ant it from within'. He said so unashamedly. His maiden speech denigrated the Senate. Senator Coates is another good example; he has always said that the Senate should not be here.

para.tab: What does the Leader of the Labor Party call us? The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, called the Senate `unrepresentative swill'. That is the true opinion of the Government regarding the Senate. So, naturally, the way it carries out its policy is to downgrade on every occasion possible the rights of senators in this place. Government senators have already done it in regard to the allocation of time for speeches and, with the Democrats' support, they will do it again.

The Government has whittled away the rights of the estimates committees, so we had the shameful debacle last night of Senator Collins refusing to allow his bureaucrats to answer the questions rightfully put by the Opposition senators. In other committees the Government would not allow senators to ask questions except on a particular line of expenditure. Last night we had a most shameful situation in the estimates committees, another attempt to undermine the powers of the Senate estimates committees. I do not understand the Democrats, frankly. The Senate is the only place the Democrats have any say. They do not have any members in the House of Representatives. Yet they are supporting the Government in gradually whittling away the powers of the individual senators.

Straight after the debate on the downgrading of the time allocated for speeches from half an hour to 20 minutes was adjourned, Senator Bell got up on the adjournment debate and spoke for 29 minutes—nearly 30 minutes. He had previously said—and you say, Mr Acting Deputy President—that anyone who cannot make a speech in only 20 minutes should not be allowed to make a speech. He got up and could not use 20 minutes; he took just on 30 minutes. The hypocrisy of that is unbelievable. If Senator Bell, who is a Democrat and who believes that he should have been able to fit his speech into 20 minutes, found that he could not and took just on 30 minutes, then surely to heavens the vote in that situation would be nothing but hypocrisy.

As Senator Harradine said, some time in the next couple of years—in this next three-year period no doubt—the Senate will have debates on the Constitution, perhaps on the referendum the Prime Minister is proposing on whether we retain the monarchy or become a republic. I believe that everyone in the Senate will have personal views on that. Of course, Labor Party members will not speak; the Minister will, but no-one else will be allowed.
