On this side of the chamber we will be wanting to speak. I am sure that the Democrats will be wanting to speak. Therefore, I believe that they will be wanting at least 30 minutes each. Senator Coulter has said that the Democrats will not deny any senator who wants an extension of time so long as the Democrats believe that it is just for that to happen.

talk.start.para: —But you do not need leave from the whole Senate. One person can stop you.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne said, it really does not matter what the Democrats want, any senator can stop a speaker having additional time. But is that the whole point of it? Is it not, as Senator MacGibbon said, the right of all senators to make that speech, be heard, represent their State and take the full 30 minutes because they believe that what they are saying is important? It does not really matter what Senator Coulter believes is important, as far as other senators are concerned. They believe they have something to say that represents their particular State and is important for their State. It does not matter a fig what the Democrats think, the Labor Party thinks or, indeed—vice versa—what we think if one of the Democrats wants to get up and speak for half an hour. It is, and has been, the right of every senator to be able to do that.

para.tab: The Government realises that it will no longer have the numbers in the new Parliament. It has lost an additional two seats in the Senate. After 30 June the Labor Party will have only 30 senators in this place; the coalition will have 36; the Democrats will have seven; and there will be Senator Harradine and two Greens. The Senate will be a very interesting spot—a very sensible spot. It will be very interesting to see the Government making deals with the Greens that it has not had to do in the past; it has only had to do deals with the Democrats. The Government will be offering the Greens all sorts of things, too, in compensation for their vote. It will be very interesting to see how the Government goes on that.

We now have the Government attempting to downgrade the Senate to the same situation that is presently occurring in the House of Representatives. The rights of senators here are so much greater than those of members of the House of Representatives. Because the Government does not believe in the Senate, it is trying to downgrade the Senate to the same level as the House of Representatives so that it can control the Senate.

In the House of Representatives at the moment, Bills come in that never reach the committee stage. Members do not look at the committee stage; they are not allowed to because the Bills are guillotined. Everything is pushed through like a sausage machine. That cannot happen in the Senate unless the Government controls it, and we are far away from that situation. We rely on the Democrats who, in the past, have said that they will not apply the guillotine. Last year, in the lead-up to Christmas, to do them justice, they said, `No, we will not apply the guillotine in the same fashion'.

A little chat will be going on now between the Minister and Senator Coulter. I am not quite sure where that will lead to, but we can guess. A vote will be taken in a little while after we have heard from a few more speakers on our side.

Today Senator Coulter said that we supported the Government on pensioner investment. The Government and the Democrats know that the reason we did that was that it was included in a Bill in which the pensioners were to receive certain benefits which we believed they should receive. So we supported the Bill in total—bearing in mind, of course, that that Bill was put through with the guillotine in the House of Representatives—purely for that reason only. Even in the House of Representatives we said that we would review that in government. Because we are not in government, we are now saying we will review it and we are doing it, and Senator Patterson has already moved an amendment.

For Senator Coulter to say that the Democrats convinced us and talked us into it is a lot of rubbish; absolute rot. In the House of Representatives before Christmas we said that we would review it in government, and because we are not in government we are reviewing it now. We put that Bill through originally because there were certain benefits that the pensioners needed, and we had to do that.

talk.start.para: —You supported the amendments; be honest about it.

—Senator Coulter did not listen because he was chatting to Senator Faulkner. What I said was that we decided that we would review it in government; we said that in the House of Representatives. We did not attain government at the election but we now have reviewed it and no doubt we will be putting it through this Senate later.

para.tab: I was absolutely staggered to hear Senator Coulter say that debate is not important in this chamber. Let me quote his exact words. He said, `All it is in this chamber is how the numbers fall'. Debate does not matter. We have had the Democrats saying to the public at large, `Our policy is that anyone who comes into the Parliament in our party has the right to vote as they think. They will not be caucused. We will listen to the debate and we will vote the way we believe we should'. That is what the Democrats told the Australian people; that is what they tell their constituents; and that is what they tell their party members. But today we have heard Senator Coulter say that debate is not important; it is how the numbers fall. That, I think, is a travesty of their whole credibility and we will see what happens as a result of it. The Democrats have always told this place and the Australian people that their senators are not caucused and that they are permitted to vote as they think.
Once again, I am totally opposed to the whittling away of individual senators' powers in this place. We will certainly be voting against the Government's motion.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the Opposition to oppose the motion moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, to restrict speaking time to 20 minutes. On this side of the chamber, the Liberal and National parties side, we are appalled at this motion by the Government, and we are even more appalled by the attitude of the Australian Democrats.

para.tab: The Senate forms an integral part of the accountability chain; an accountability that sits very uneasily with the Labor Government. From time to time newspaper editors are rung up and abused by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when they take a contrary view to that of the Government. At present we have the fiasco of the special deals in relation to communications.

The Senate is not the favourite chamber of the Labor Party. We have had unsavoury comments from the Prime Minister about senators and the role of the Senate. Why? Because the Senate chamber is part of a very important link within our democratic system—a system of checks and balances and of accountability. In a democratic society accountability is very important.

One of the important links in the chain is the role of the Auditor-General. Why were the Auditor-General's funds restricted so that he could not fully discharge his responsibilities as Auditor-General? The way in which the Auditor-General has managed his task draws admiration from a wide spectrum of Australian society. He adheres to the highest standards. I think that, in his role as Auditor-General, John Taylor has raised the status of auditing. He has done that because he has fearlessly supported the need for accountability and the need for checks and balances. One of our roles in this place is to ensure proper scrutiny and proper accountability.

I remind the Senate that accountability is not just a matter of counting the dollars and cents. Last night we saw a very unfortunate situation arise when the Government believed that the accountability of the tax office in terms of the estimates committee debates was just a matter of dollars and cents. The Government ignored the very special responsibility of the Australian Taxation Office in discharging its obligations to administer tax law in a fair and impartial way to ensure that our tax laws are fair and equitable. These issues were going to be challenged last night during the estimates committee hearings but those challenges were not allowed. What has the tax office got to hide?

The proposal to limit speeches in second reading debates to 20 minutes is more than just a matter of limiting speaking time; it is a matter of putting a further check or limitation on this accountability, important though that be. This 20-minute limit on speaking time is restricted further by the Government's practice of grouping Bills together and debating them cognately. Last year in the tax area we had something like three to four minutes per Bill to thrash out the important issues.

Within the next fortnight this chamber will be debating three tax Bills: two taxation laws amendment Bills and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. If this motion is passed, contributions to the debate on those Bills will be limited to 20 minutes. Therefore, we will have less than seven minutes to debate each of those important Bills.

The second reading stage of a Bill is very important because it sends messages to the Australian people telling them what issues they should be contacting us on. But if senators do not have the opportunity of sending out those signals and messages through this Parliament, then we are taking away from the Parliament the very responsibilities that we were elected here to carry out—to debate, to challenge and to put alternative positions. If those responsibilities are taken away from us we will have to rely on networks other than this Parliament to send our messages to the Australian public. I think that is unfortunate.

Let us see how that is reflected in regard to administration. The taxation office—an area for which I have particular responsibility—is becoming subject to less and less parliamentary scrutiny. The office seems to be more concerned about dealing with its own groups that it has set up outside the control of this Parliament and as a result is devoting less time to the Parliament. It is making determinations and rulings which cannot possibly come through the Senate. For those people who do not have the opportunity or money to challenge those rulings—and challenges to a ruling must go before a court and the court system is so expensive that they cannot afford it—where is the justice? Taxation justice in this country depends on how much money one has and, as some witnesses suggested, on how much influence one personally has with the taxation office.

When I first entered this Parliament the time allowed for a contribution to a second reading debate was one hour. I can recall Ministers, including the present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, taking up every minute of the 60 minutes to debate a Bill.

talk.start.para: —I am glad I wasn't here.

—That was tolerated by the Liberal Party at the time. I say to Senator Schacht that the Labor Government is now denying the Opposition the opportunity for adequate debate by further restricting time at the second reading stage.

para.tab: I am concerned about the role of the Australian Democrats in relation to this motion. The Democrats will side with the Government and because of their numbers—the numbers being more important than the logic of the argument—they will sway the vote. For Senator Coulter to say that the numbers are important and the debate is unimportant betrays the ideals on which the Australian Democrats as a party were founded.

I hope that those comments that were made today will be overruled by the Democrats' new leader, Senator Kernot. I believe Senator Kernot knows the value of debate in this place. Senator Coulter may not recall, but Senator Kernot certainly would, that last year when we were debating certain sales tax amendments it was the logic of certain proposals put forward by Senator Kernot that encouraged the Opposition to support a number of those motions. At that time a number of commentators, including representatives from the Democrats, said, `This is the way that the Senate should always work'.
To the Democrats' credit, in the past the reverse has been true and, because of the sheer logic and strength of the argument in a debate, the Democrats have supported the coalition's point of view.

If we limit debate at the second reading stage, the opportunity for such important decisions to be taken, based on the logic and force of the argument, would be lost. If a person who has been a successor to some of the great leaders of the Democrats, including former Senators Chipp and Haines, comes into this place and indicates that the debate is not important, it makes me wonder where that person stands in relation to the Democrats' original philosophy of selling to the Australian people its philosophy of keeping the bastards honest. If it is just the numbers that are important, debate is therefore unimportant.

I would hope that, in the light of this debate, Senator Coulter may be persuaded to change his point of view and support the coalition so that we retain the 30-minute time limit. The 20-minute time limit is a further restriction and what will happen is that in time we will have a further whittling away of opportunities.

From the point of view of the Opposition, this measure is just another link in the chain of taking away the rights of parliamentarians, particularly senators, to debate and challenge issues. It is a sad day for democracy. This measure will diminish the important role of this Senate. If that is on the Labor Party agenda, let every Australian take note because democracy is at risk in this country while the Labor Party pursues such a line.

talk.start.para:
—Mr Deputy President, if we were to rely upon the House of Representatives to debate and scrutinise actions of the Executive, we may as well shut down this Parliament now. As it is, the House of Representatives will be meeting for perhaps 10 days in the first seven months of this year. That really shows the Government's concern for democracy, for debate and for scrutiny of government actions. If we were to rely on the House of Representatives, we might as well give it away now.
Already in the other chamber, the guillotine has been introduced to curtail any debate, any investigation, any scrutiny of some of the Bills the Government is bringing in—some fairly important Bills.

para.tab: I heard this morning that Dr Blewett has been appointed to look at ways of improving the House of Representatives procedures. That seems to me a bit like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank, because Mr Blewett is quoted as saying that he is not terribly interested in the Senate procedures because the Senate procedures seem to take too long; people talk too much; they investigate too much. Of course, the Government does not want that. The Government does not wants its legislation scrutinised at all.

The Labor Party has a proud record of wanting to get rid of the Senate, wanting to downgrade its importance, wanting to restrict its power. It is not the Senate that holds up government legislation; the Senate scrutinises and amends it where appropriate. It is simply atrocious management by retrospective managers of government business and the current Manager of Government Business (Senator Faulkner). In years past, for weeks and weeks at a time, the Government simply has not had its program ready; it has not had any legislation here for us to debate.

The Labor Party's view on the Senate is well known. As my colleagues have mentioned, Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, wanted to get rid of the Senate and made that quite clear in his early speeches to this chamber. We know that the Labor Party is intent on downgrading the Senate and that the House of Representatives has little power of function to scrutinise government works. That is pretty clear.

Let us have a look at the Democrats. Where do they stand on this matter? They were formed to keep the Government honest. They were formed to make sure the incumbent government was kept on the straight and narrow. What has their record been? Have they done that? The Australian public does not think they have. In the last election the vote for the Democrats fell from about 12 per cent to 5.3 per cent. That shows what the people of Australia think about the way the Democrats have simply rolled over for the Labor Party every time some proposal is put up to curtail speech in this Senate, to interfere with the Senate's scrutiny and to oppose reform. Every time we propose matters to make things better in the Senate, to allow the Senate to operate more effectively, to scrutinise the Government more, the Democrats roll over, go with the Government and agree with it.

We have this terrible spectacle of the new Leader of the Democrats (Senator Kernot) urging the Government to break a promise. I simply find that incredible. We had hoped that things might change with the change of leadership in the Australian Democrats. We thought that the Australian Democrats might have learnt their lesson from the drubbing they got in the polls and that they might have done something different, changed their ways. But what have we seen? We have seen a fairly inauspicious start from the new Leader of the Australian Democrats.

I am somewhat embarrassed and concerned that the new Leader of the Democrats, a Queensland senator, is urging in her proposals for the operations of Parliament and our Constitution the abolition of States. If that is not anti-Queensland, I do not know what is. It is probably a capitulation to the greater number of Australian Democrat voters for the leadership in the more populous south-east States of Australia. But it certainly does nothing for the less populous States. Here is Senator Kernot, a senator for Queensland, wanting to get rid of States, wanting to throw all power into the Sydney-Melbourne axis. I find that quite incredible.

talk.start.para: —Absolutely untrue.

—What does the new leader do? She immediately joins with the Government in opposing sensible reforms, opposing measures that would improve the operation of the Senate and urging the Government to be dishonest. This comes from the party which was formed to keep the Government honest. Here is the new leader immediately urging the Government to break a promise on taxes—absolutely incredible stuff. I can assure Senator Coulter, who is present in the chamber, that the Government will not need any urging on that. It has little regard at all for promises it makes.

para.tab: The arrogance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is fairly well documented. It will be worse on this occasion. At least in the last Parliament the Prime Minister knew that his numbers were very, very tight. He occasionally paid lip-service to Caucus decisions. Of course, now—and it has been demonstrated in many ways, particularly with the appointment of the frontbench—the Prime Minister is not even going to take any notice of the Labor Party Caucus anymore, let alone the Australian public. He has no concern for those sorts of things. Where we might have hoped that, at some stage, the excesses of the Government could be curtailed, we have a group—a very small group and getting smaller, I might say—in the Australian parliamentary system, the Australian Democrats, who seem determined to do everything possible to allow this Government to ride roughshod over the wishes of the Australian public.

We hoped that the Australian Democrats might have learnt their lesson. It is pretty obvious that they have not. Their vote fell to 5.3 per cent at the last election. However, I see there is good news for them under their new leadership. A few weeks ago the polls indicated that their vote had fallen to 3 per cent; I see it is now up to 4 per cent—a 25 per cent increase. Just who do the Democrats represent in this Parliament? Is it the odd sort of groups around who are determined to do away with our form of parliamentary democracy? By supporting the motion before us now, the Democrats continue in their role of trying to curtail proper scrutiny and debate on Bills.

When Senator Faulkner spoke about this measure, we had the spectacle of his promoting some figures—which I think are same ones Senator Harradine cited today—which show that not many senators exercise the opportunity of speaking for 30 minutes in any case. If that is the case—and certainly the figures Senator Harradine mentioned today show that that is the case—why bother restricting it? We heard the terribly illogical argument from Senator Coulter that, if someone is making a good speech which is making a point, after 20 minutes the Democrats will give leave for that person to continue for an extra five or 10 minutes. Who do they represent to give leave? What is the point of it?

Very few people at the moment speak for longer than 20 minutes. I might say that occasionally very good speeches are made in this place. I make particular reference to an excellent speech made earlier by Senator Walters. I wish that speech had gone on for longer than 30 minutes, it was so telling, so forceful and so compelling. In cases like that, even 30 minutes is not long enough.

Most senators speak for less than 20 minutes and, in that event, why is there a need for this proposal to reduce compulsorily the speaking time to 20 minutes? There is no logic in the proposal; it is simply another step in the Labor Party's long-term strategy to get rid of the Senate so that the Prime Minister can have his way and introduce legislation for which he has no mandate at all. His only mandate from the election was to oppose new taxes. We are all waiting anxiously to see which of those opposite will succeed in getting new taxes brought in during the Budget session.

The Government is desperate. It has to get money from somewhere and there will be new taxes, although the mandate of the Australian people to this Government, if it has any mandate at all, is simply not to impose new taxes. But the Prime Minister will not worry about that. Labor Party senators will not worry about that. I can predict with every confidence that the Australian Democrats will not worry about that, either. When the Government introduces some of these outrageous Bills for which it has no mandate whatsoever, we can be assured that the Australian Democrats, in tune with their normal practices, again will simply roll over to the Government.

I also want to say a word to Senator Chamarette. I hope to mention her name a number of times so that if she happens to be near a TV set she might listen to me. I know that Senator Chamarette and her predecessor representing the Greens would often speak for more than 20 minutes. I must confess that I have never really listened to her because the first couple of times I tried to do so, it just got completely beyond me. But that does not mean that Senator Chamarette might not be convincing someone. She may well have—although I doubt it—a point that is of relevance to Australia and to the people she represents. But her speaking time will be curtailed, along with that of everyone else.

I ask Senator Chamarette and the new senator who will join her after 1 July to seriously consider these matters. I think it is appropriate at this time for Senator Chamarette to think about these matters—not just come into this chamber, see where the Democrats are sitting and go and sit with them. Senator Chamarette should look at this legislation and take a stand now. She should tell the Government and the Democrats that, come 1 July, the Greens may well join with us in reversing this proposal if it goes through.

I urge Senator Chamarette, particularly, as one who has—and whose predecessor has—availed herself of this opportunity to speak for 30 minutes in the past, to think very seriously about it. The Greens should realise that they will have a more important role in the Senate after 1 July. They should make a statement at this time and tell the Government that it is not going to be able to rely on their vote almost 100 per cent of the time, as I think happened before.

The Greens will have to appreciate that they have this responsibility to consider the wider aspects of government in Australia and the wider operations of this Parliament. They have a responsibility to think about the sorts of things that are being proposed and say to the Government, `Enough is enough. We don't agree with this. We are going to exercise our judgment independently. We are going to ensure that the Senate forever continues its originally contemplated role of a States house, a house where checks and balances can come into play and a house of review'. That is very important. The Greens should not take any action which will lessen the Senate's opportunity of properly reviewing the excesses of the Government. I hope that the Greens, Senator Chamarette in particular, will make a statement at this time and tell the Government that they are not going to be ridden roughshod over in these matters and join with us in that action.

Senator Chamarette may well have some influence on the Democrats, because the Democrats' vote is falling everywhere and the Greens' vote seems to be increasing. I suspect, certainly after the next election when there are five Democrats up for re-election, that very few, if any, of them will be re-elected and there may be one or two additional Greens. The Democrats realise that they are on the way out. On that basis maybe Senator Chamarette has some influence on the current few Democrat senators. I urge Senator Chamarette to talk to them and suggest that they should not support these proposals. They should not continue to take these actions which result in a lessening of the importance and the powers of the Senate. I urge Senator Chamarette to take that action, as I urge the Senate generally to oppose these proposals by the Government.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know, as a proud Tasmanian, I do not get on my feet and speak for 30 minutes at a time, perhaps not even for 20 minutes at a time in most cases. But I respect the right of my colleagues to speak for 30 minutes when they need to. We have had plenty of evidence in the debate this morning, particularly from Senator Watson and Senator MacGibbon, about the fact that there are times when there is a definite need to speak for 30 minutes.

para.tab: The reason I felt moved to come in here and say a few words was that I have only been in this place for six years, but all I have seen happening over that six years is the gradual erosion of the powers of this place. The other House has the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the guillotine. The Government has already applied the guillotine in this new Parliament. The only hope the Australian people have is this Senate. We are the only people who can scrutinise, correct and fix up all these Bills. We should think of the number of Bills that have come from the House of Representatives that have had to be changed or amended. Last year there were 148 amendments to one particular Bill. They were all agreed to by the Government. It was in such a rush to shove all its legislation through that it made an absolute mess of it.

We as a Senate have a duty to amend those Bills, to change them and to make them workable so that the government of the day can enact its legislation. But I think it is a disgrace to the whole parliamentary system of Australia to continually try to erode the powers of this Senate, which has a duty on behalf of the people of Australia to ensure that the government of the day does not get away with murder in its legislation. It is getting away with murder. What is it frightened of? In 1993 the House of Representatives will sit for 42 days. It is trying to escape scrutiny.

It has been said on dozens of occasions in the debate this morning that the Democrats are the ones who have been spouting for years about how they are going to keep the bastards honest and help to scrutinise the government of the day, yet the first thing they do is run away and say, `We'll agree with the Government on reducing speeches to 20 minutes'. How is that helping scrutiny?

Last Thursday night in the adjournment debate one of the Democrats, my colleague from Tasmania Senator Bell, spoke for 29 1/2 minutes about the rental car industry and the use of sprays in the Lorinna area. If he is going to vote with the Government and reduce speaking time to 20 minutes, it will reduce his effectiveness to speak on those matters that he feels so dearly about.

talk.start.para: —But will the 20 minutes apply to the adjournment debate?
—Senator Lewis has asked a good question.
—The Government Whip is saying no, and the Opposition Whip is saying yes.

—It seems that the adjournment speeches will be reduced although, as Senator Lewis would know, adjournment speeches are normally less than 30 minutes, according to an unwritten rule amongst honourable senators. But sometimes people forget about that. There is no doubt in my mind that this whole change to the Standing Orders and this attempt to reduce time limits is a further erosion of senators' rights and an attempt by the Government to escape further scrutiny by this Senate. I do not need to remind the chamber that it is this Senate that has been responsible for the dismissal of at least two Ministers. You never know, there might be another one coming up shortly. Anything that will reduce our powers and scrutinising abilities should be opposed. I am very disappointed to see that the Democrats have once more thrown away their principles in order to support the Government in this matter.
—Mr Acting Deputy President—
—I remember the time of your predecessor. She spoke for 30 minutes every single day.

—I have been reminded by my colleague that Senator Vallentine used to take full advantage of the adjournment debate and often spoke for 30 minutes. She had the right to do that. I have never done it. However, I am happy to say that this motion has nothing to do with curtailing the length of adjournment speeches, which is still intended to remain at 30 minutes; it is to do with reducing the time limit for speeches on second reading debates to 20 minutes.
—She used to do it on the second reading all the time.

—I am sure. If that is what she wished to do, that is okay. But at this time, the purpose of the motion should be taken into consideration. There is a large amount of business in hand. In order to do it justice and to maximise the number of speakers who wish to address a topic, it could well be in our interests to curtail the time for speeches to 20 minutes. It will assist us to present our arguments with clarity and brevity, and that would be to the credit of this chamber. If it is the case, as Senator Macdonald said, that people do not need more than 20 minutes now, we should accept the motion. I certainly will take that position.

para.tab: It has been pointed out that after July I will be joined by a fellow Green senator. At that point we can assess whether this improvement has been effective. I assure honourable senators that if I think this measure has diminished the ability of senators to address an argument or to exercise their community voice, I will not support it. However, at this time I do wish to support it. I hope that it will encourage us all to conduct ourselves with more clarity and brevity than we do at present so that we can get on with the business of the day.

talk.start.para: —I want to raise a couple of issues in connection with this motion to limit speeches during second reading debates to 20 minutes. I am very serious about the nature of debate which takes place in the chamber. When I first came into this chamber, I could not make a speech for more than eight minutes. For about the first 10 speeches I made, at the end of eight minutes, I could not think of another word to say. But as one gets more knowledgeable—not more voluble—about what is happening in government, one needs to be able to develop a speech.

para.tab: Apparently, the other night Senator Bell felt he needed 29 1/2 minutes to develop an argument. As Senator Chamarette said, former Senator Vallentine used to come in here and talk for 30 minutes—not to fill up 30 minutes but because she felt she needed 30 minutes to develop an argument. I am all in favour of senators being able to develop an argument. Believe me, if Reg Wright or John Wheeldon were still in this Parliament, I would have give them an hour to develop an argument because both those speakers were so good that people who heard them on the radio would come in to listen to the points that they were making.

talk.start.para: —From miles around.

—Senator Crowley does not remember Senator Wheeldon, but believe me, when Senator Wheeldon started to make a major speech in this place on any aspect of foreign affairs, the place would fill up. He was so good. Unfortunately, that ability has fallen away. I understand that the Democrats have a great deal of difficulty because there is only a limited number of them and they shadow all the government portfolios. That means that one Democrat might have six or seven portfolios.
—The way we are going, we will get it down to about three.

—Senator Coulter thinks that they will get it down to three. I think that they will end up with about 18 because after the next election there might be only two Democrats here. I understand that each Democrat senator has to shadow a lot of portfolios. That means that, in effect, their so-called speeches—they are not really speeches; they are essays—are prepared by staffers. I understand that. Like Ministers who make second reading speeches, in effect, they come in and read a written speech into the
Hansard
.

para.tab:
I make the following proposition very seriously to the committee that deals with the Standing Orders: we ought to stand by standing order 187, that senators shall not read speeches. We ought to stick to that firmly. In the case of a Minister or a shadow Minister, we would allow them to incorporate in
Hansard
a document which, in effect, contains an essay on the subject or, if you like, what could be called a speech—although I think it is wrong to call it a speech when it is being incorporated in
Hansard
.

There would need to be some caution. The shadow Minister or the Minister would need to be able to let both sides read the document first so that we could make sure there was nothing improper in the speech. That is what is wrong with incorporated speeches; someone could incorporate in a speech something which is highly improper and to which objection would be taken in the Senate. If that problem could be overcome by allowing people to see the speeches, we would enable the Minister and the shadow Minister simply to incorporate their speeches.

We then might get the Minister, the shadow Minister or whoever saying, `The points of this document that I have just incorporated include one, two and three', or whatever they are. They might actually speak to the points which are in the document that they have just incorporated. There would then be proper debate in the Senate. We would be able to go back and insist upon standing order 187 being acted upon, and people would not be able to read speeches. It would make debate in this chamber so much better.

I see Senator Faulkner nodding in agreement. I have seen Senator Faulkner, as a relative newcomer to this place, making speeches with just a handful of notes in front of him. Another senator on his side is Senator Schacht, who frequently comes into this place and makes excellent speeches. I certainly do not like some of the things that he says, but they are excellent speeches. He directs his mind articulately to the subject and people enjoy listening to him, although we might not enjoy some of the things he says, especially when he makes outrageous, unfair and unreasonable attacks on me and my colleagues on this side of the chamber.

If senators did not read speeches, they would really start to debate issues properly. We might then get debates which only take three or four minutes. When senators started to read speeches, someone would be able to object and the whole Senate would uphold the objection that they are not allowed to read them; not even Ministers would be allowed to read them. Once we did that, we would not have to worry about whether there were 20-minute speeches or 30-minute speeches. The whole thing would flow and the Senate would be a much more exciting chamber in which to be present.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Don't you read your speech, Noel!
—Two relevant things have happened in my life, Senator Lewis—I could not read my mother's writing and I cannot read my own!

para.tab:
This proposal really reduces the debate in this chamber to an absolute farce. It takes us to the situation that applies in the House of Representatives where the members do not make a significant contribution in the chamber; they are simply but numbers for the Government. The members get to speak but rarely and when they do speak they are entitled to do so for 10 minutes. From time to time when I have flipped through the
Hansards
of the House of Representatives, looking for some intellectual argument that is put by the Government or the Opposition in respect of any piece of legislation, I find them bankrupt. In 10-minute speeches there is no intellectual debate developed; they invariably consist of simple cliches that in no way persuade, educate or inform people of the legislation before them.

The fundamental premise upon which a parliament functions in a democratic system is that there shall be two fundamental rights. The first is the right to freedom of speech and the right to speak. The second premise upon which a parliamentary system is based in a democracy is the freedom to vote. The Government proposes to abolish the former. In my view, any limitations on people's right to speak in this chamber is an infringement on that right, and to reduce the speaking time adds to that infringement.

Very often in these debates when we argue about the amount of time that should be necessary a great deal of mirth comes from the other side. The tragedy is that democracy is a very fragile thing. It may be clumsy and it may be inconvenient, but it is the very best system that has yet been devised to protect the rights and the responsibilities of individuals in Australian society. Yet, millions of people have died seeking the rights that we take for granted, but we are now having those rights taken from us.

I believe it is the intrinsic obligation and responsibility of members of parliament when they are elected by their constituents to represent their constituents to the best of their ability. The Government proposes to place some caveat on their capacity and their ability to represent their constituents. The Government is saying, in its wisdom, it will decide to what extent members and senators will be able to represent their constituents.

What an impertinence it is for the Government to make judgments about the amount of time it takes for members or senators to represent their constituents. What an impertinence it is for the Government to claim that what a member or senator is saying is irrelevant. Who is the Government to dictate to any of us how well and to what extent a senator may represent his or her constituents?

The truth of the matter is that this debate is all about the Government's incapacity to manage the business of the Parliament. Senator Faulkner's solution to that, to the bottleneck at the end of the year, is to no doubt continue to use the guillotine, but in the meantime to limit the period of debate. It logically follows that, if we are going to limit the time of debate, we might as well simply give Independents, the minor parties and the coalition a global amount of time—in other words, formalise the system of a guillotine and say, `The Opposition has got three hours for this debate. We do not much care whether Opposition senators take an hour each to speak and there are three of them'—
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Minister's letter dated 11 May which he tabled yesterday. Is it a fact that it claims that the secretary to the Minister's department had had discussions with Professor Pearce about the pay television tender inquiry's terms of reference prior to 7 May? Is it not the case that in fact Professor Pearce was not approached about the inquiry until 8 May?
—This is devastating stuff.

—It really is desperate stuff. If Senator Alston had put this question to me last night during about six hours of Senate estimates committees, the proceedings of which had nothing to do with the supplementary estimates, I would have answered him. Senator Alston should stop looking for conspiracy theories. The only bad faith in this debate is on the Opposition side of this chamber.
—Why don't you answer the question?
—Why don't you go back to Tasmania, Shirley? I am counting the days. There are, what, nine to go?
—Eight.

—Eight? The situation is that Mr Evans sent a copy of the draft terms of reference to me on Friday, 7 May. The corporate management division of DOTAC was also provided with draft terms of reference by Mr Evans. Consultation on those draft terms of reference was held with the department of the Attorney-General. Following this consultation with the Attorney-General's Department, a copy of the draft terms of reference and a large number of documents relating to this issue were sent to Professor Pearce on Saturday morning.
—When?
—Let me answer. On Saturday morning—
—That is the eighth.

—It can count too. Professor Pearce has to do a great deal of work in a very short time. I understand that that is well under way. He has already spoken to quite a number of departmental officers. The draft terms of reference were given to him on Saturday morning with a large number of documents, I am told—several large boxes—relating to this issue. The reason for that was so that over the weekend Professor Pearce could read the paper, get across the paperwork, and determine whether in his view the terms of reference were appropriate to the inquiry—a perfectly reasonable thing to do, I would have thought. On Monday morning the secretary to the department contacted him and asked him for his view. Professor Pearce said that in his view the terms of reference were appropriate to the inquiry and he did not wish to make any amendments to them.

para.tab: I was given those draft terms of reference as well. I was told by Mr Evans that Professor Pearce did find them appropriate and did not want to make changes to them. I said that that was my view also and that they did not require amendment. I found it interesting to get the questions in the Senate estimates committee last night because I was referring to the terms of reference as the questions were being asked. I was not asked a single question on this central issue last night that was not covered by one of those terms of reference.

question.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister has just confirmed that Professor Pearce—
—What is your question?
—Don't be a clown all your life. The Minister has just confirmed that Professor Pearce was not given the documentation until 8 May. I therefore ask why the Minister's letter said:

question.para: Thank you for your letter of 7 May in which you provided draft terms of reference for the inquiry following your discussions with Professor Pearce.

Is that not manifestly untrue, in the same way that the Minister said in the Parliament on 10 May that he did not draw up the terms of reference; that Professor Pearce did? Is the fact of the matter that the Minister is simply prepared to say or do anything to get himself off the hook?

talk.start.para: —Why would Mr Evans need to send me a second letter when there was absolutely no change to the terms of reference? I will go through it slowly for Senator Alston. I got a letter on Friday, 7 May. Here is the letter. It has the terms of reference on it. So I have the letter and it has the terms of reference on it. The terms of reference were then given to Professor Pearce on the Saturday, with a big pile of documents. I have still got the letter of 7 May with the terms of reference. This is my letter. Professor Pearce reads all the documents, looks at the terms of reference, decides they are appropriate—and I still have the letter; it is still there.

para.tab:
Senator Alston and Senator Faulkner interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Alston! Senator Faulkner!
—I am doing all right, John.
—Well, you are not, because your time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of a report which found that 82 per cent of women were dissatisfied with the service they were receiving from Australia's financial institutions?

—I thank Senator Giles for her question. Yes, I am aware of the report by Mattingly and Partners. I have it here. It claims that nearly all women have a horror story to tell about poor or patronising treatment they have received from banks or financial institutions, in particular from bank managers—most of whom are men. Over one-half of the 1,000 women from Australia and New Zealand who were surveyed believe that banks and financial institutions do not take them seriously. As Senator Giles said in her question, 82 per cent said that the attitudes to women in the financial area need to be improved. Worse than that, 46 per cent said that they had actually moved their financial business to another institution because of the bad service.

para.tab: What most banks have failed to recognise is that women at home have large control of the household finances. The report showed something that most women know: in most households women do the banking, pay the bills, buy the insurance and make very many of the household financial decisions. They also have a very strong influence on the financial decisions that their husbands or partners make.

In 1975 I went to Broken Hill as part of the International Year of the Family celebrations. One of the people who were there as part of those celebrations was a woman under the nom de plume of Elizabeth Martin. She had been placed in a bank on the corner of Elizabeth Street and Martin Place, as I remember it. I do not know the name of the bank.

talk.start.para: —What has Martin Place got to do with Mount Isa?

—If Senator Macdonald would listen, he would find out. One of the things that the banks discovered with Elizabeth Martin was that women then were enormously pleased to find in a financial institution or a bank, firstly, a person who took them seriously and, secondly, a person who had a sympathy with their views.

para.tab: I remember her saying that the banks were quite surprised when women arrived with up to six figures to invest. Banks had just been missing business. This report is evidence that banks and financial institutions are very slow learners. I remind people that Elizabeth Martin was around in 1975.

The report makes very good reading. It also contains some very simple and explicit instructions to people in the financial area—in particular, not to treat women as mental defectives; and that it is not a good idea, if you are talking to a woman about financial matters, to ask to speak to her husband. I sincerely hope that people in financial institutions will read the report and take it seriously because there is financial business out there to be done, provided the institutions are sensitive to the needs of women. Also, if they are serious about good business and they recognise that 46 per cent of women will move their business because of poor service, they might take heed.

This Government does its bit. It makes a huge number of payments directly to the parent involved with the care of children, the majority of whom are women. Over $3 billion per year is paid usually to women on behalf of 1.93 million families. If the Government appreciates the responsibility and ability of women, maybe it is time the financial institutions learned to do the same.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Did the Minister tell the Federal Court on 21 April that he relied on legal advice from his department as to whether his direction to the ABA regarding MDS was lawful and that he was told that it was? Is it not a fact that the only written advice which he received from the principal departmental legal adviser, Mr John Doherty, was advice which was absolutely to the contrary?
—I am happy to discuss that matter. I did receive advice that I had power to issue the direction.
—Oral advice.
—No. As a matter of—
—Not worth the paper it is written on.

—I think Senator Alston really should read that court list. As I said to him last night, before he gives documents to any more journalists, have a look at it. Senator Alston will see the advice I got if he reads the list. He is a lawyer. That was the problem, Senator Alston. Before he signed the document off to Fia Cumming he should have read the determination—every line of it. It was tabled in the Federal Court. The paragraph begins, `You have the express power', et cetera. If I had not been told that that was lawful, I would never have made it.

para.tab: I did receive subsequent legal advice, but I do not want to go any further into that because, as Senator O'Chee should know full well, that is a matter still before the Federal Court. It has not yet been determined and I think it would be most improper of me to continue to discuss the evidence that was given in court—

Opposition senators—
Oh!

talk.start.para: —We have this thing in here called sub judice, which I take a bit seriously. So I have answered the question. The specific answer to the question is yes, I received specific written advice that I had the power to issue that direction.
—Not from Doherty, you didn't.

—Do you want me to finish the letter story, Richard? It is the same letter, you see. It did not change over the weekend; it is the same letter. The advice that I received was subject to some very serious charges made in the Federal Court by the applicant, Australis. Those matters are now being heard by the Federal Court and that was the third part of the action that was taken. I am happy to await the court's decision on it. The Federal Court, at the appropriate time, will bring down a determination which will indicate—and these things happen all the time—whether the legal advice I got was right or wrong. Lawyers live off that stuff.

question.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I direct Senator Collins to the fact that he told a judge of the Federal Court of Australia that his intention was to preserve the legislation as passed by parliament, and also that he said, `I relied on the legal advice of my department as to whether in their view that direction was lawful and I was told it was'. I also remind him that that advice said, amongst other things:

question.para: The ABA does not seem to have a legitimate basis to adopt the approach of rejecting all applications put before it for subscription TV broadcasting licences via MDS.
This is in direct conflict to what he said. Further, it says:
A direction not to grant MDS licences for subscription television broadcasting services seems to cut across the objectives of the legislation.
Why did Senator Collins, in sworn evidence as a Minister of the Government, directly and blatantly mislead the Federal Court of Australia?

talk.start.para: —I will bet Senator O'Chee was the dux of gesture school. Senator O'Chee has just read at length from a transcript of the sworn evidence that I gave in the Federal Court, which is currently being considered by a judge of that court. It is outrageous to suggest that now that that matter is being considered I would recanvass the matter here in the Senate. I am happy to rely on the Federal Court rather than Mr Justice Willy O'Chee.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Is the Minister able to provide any details on the announcement from the food technology conference held last week in Adelaide regarding new CSIRO technology which has resulted in a $20 million export boost for Australia's beef export industry?

—This is another good news story for CSIRO and the beef industry, which I am sure honourable senators opposite, particularly those in the National Party, would be very pleased to hear. In fact, I am able to report that the winner of the 1993 food industry innovation award at the 26th national food horizon conference held in Adelaide last week was a scanner marketed as Emscan MQ-27. I know honourable senators opposite, including those in the National Party, may wonder what a scanner has to do with the beef industry.
—Do you know?

—I am about to give the Senate the information. The Emscan MQ-27—and I have to say that that number is higher than Senator Crane's IQ level—is an on-line electromagnetic scanner which measures the amount of fat in cartoned beef immediately after packing. This could increase earnings for Australia's beef exports by between $20 million and $50 million a year by reducing waste in export packing procedures.
—This was announced in the papers a few weeks ago.
—I thought Senator Brownhill, a National Party senator from a beef growing area of New South Wales, would want to know about this because it is helping—
—We knew about it.
—Order! There are too many interjections and I would ask the Minister to ignore them.
—Why does Senator Brownhill want to stop the rest of Australia hearing about it?
—They have read about it already!

—I suspect that Senator Brownhill may have heard about it on the grapevine, but most people have not. The technology was developed from an existing medical diagnostic instrument by a consortium comprising Australian Meat Holdings, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation—that is probably where Senator Brownhill heard about it—the electronics firm Cambut Holdings and the CSIRO meat research laboratory.

para.tab: This is just another example of the important role played by CSIRO in helping develop innovative technology for our food exports. It shows that we do have the research and development capacity to enhance our export drive. We are hopeful that with this breakthrough and this development we can find other ways to use this technology to further enhance other food exports. Honourable senators opposite, who claim to represent rural constituents, will see the benefit for their constituents of enhancing exports. This is a very significant development and one that CSIRO should be proud of.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to comments made over the past few days by both the present Minister and the former Minister for Social Security that a high level of long-term unemployment will remain a feature of the Australian economy for some time. I ask: firstly, will the Government seriously consider Dr Blewett's proposal to raise taxes and direct the revenue towards alleviating the plight of the long-term unemployed; secondly, will the Government seriously consider a welfare or jobs levy, such as that proposed by the Australian Democrats; thirdly, will the Government reconsider its commitment to further tax cuts in light of the increasing long-term unemployment; and, finally, if none of these measures are to be seriously considered by the Government, can the Minister explain why the Government refuses to appeal to the fair-mindedness of those Australians who have jobs and ask them to contribute a little more towards the welfare of those who do not?

—There is no doubt that the question of long-term unemployment is probably the most difficult, intractable and serious of the economic difficulties we confront as a nation. We are acutely conscious of that. We are acutely conscious not only of the need to have effective safety nets to deal with the current implications of that problem, but also, of course, of the need to have proper training programs in place so that long-term unemployed can get back into the work force when economic circumstances permit, and we are conscious of the need to do everything we possibly can to generate faster economic growth so as to make it easier to address those objectives.

para.tab: As to the particular strategies that we will employ to get there, a number of suggestions have been made, going to the revenue side of the budgetary equation as well as to other possible strategies. All I can say about Dr Blewett's suggestion, the Australian Democrats' suggestion or any other suggestion that might be made, is that the issues raised by those suggestions will be squarely in front of the Government during its consideration of budgetary strategy over the next couple of months. I can assure the honourable senator that every aspect of the available alternative policy paths we can pursue, consistent with what we have said in the past, will be pursued. Beyond that, I simply cannot be more specific.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the recent report by the Bureau of Industry Economics on international performance indicators for the waterfront industry. I ask: what steps is the Government taking to further improve waterfront performance in light of the report's findings that, while stevedoring is making significant gains in reliability and productivity, other sectors, particularly port authorities, still lag behind?

—I advised the Senate yesterday of the addition to the Australian shipping fleet of an LNG tanker as a direct result of the success of the Australian Government's shipping reform program. Indeed, crewing levels on that tanker are significantly below those of similar Japanese and British flag vessels.

para.tab: The bureau report referred to by Senator Burns provides further confirmation that there have been major improvements in operating efficiency at our container ports. It concludes that, in some cases, Australian performance levels are approaching observed best practice in similar sized overseas ports. In grain and coal handling, it concludes that the operating efficiency in Australia of relevant ports now approaches or is at world best practice. It will be recalled that stevedoring reforms in grain handling were an important element in the Government's waterfront reforms.

However, this level of improvement has not been uniform across all waterfront sectors. The bureau found that government and port authority charges in Australia were substantially higher than those observed for similar cargoes and ships overseas. This clearly emphasises, as I have been saying now for some three years, that there is scope for further efficiencies to be achieved in the port sector. Indeed, one of the major reasons why the changes were made in this portfolio, after discussions that I had with the Prime Minister last year, to incorporate all of the transport responsibilities under the control of one Minister, was to address this question of developing a cohesive and mutually supportive transport system for Australia where resources were not duplicated or wasted on alternative transport.

The Government will be canvassing with the States the scope for further reform following the release of the Industry Commission's final report into port authority services and activities which is due at the end of this month. Already, the Government is pursuing improved competition in waterfront industries through the activities of the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Trade Practices Commission.

It is interesting to see that the shadow Minister for transport is criticising the Government for not pursuing port reform with the States. He makes the extremely novel suggestion that the Government should progress these issues with the States in the ministerial forum of the Australian Transport Advisory Council. It may come as some surprise for the shadow Minister to learn that this is precisely what I have been doing for the past three years.

Already, reforms of port authorities have seen their work forces reduced by 35 per cent since 1989. However, again, these reforms have not been uniform across all ports, as indicated in the report. The Government's reforms have successfully created a more competitive and efficient stevedoring industry, with ongoing performance improvement and record low levels of industrial disputation. The focus is now moving more fully to the port authority sector and to improving the efficiency of the sea-land interface.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given the Minster's answer to Senator Ferguson yesterday that a Minister is always provided with a written brief from the department, was the vital ministerial determination for the satellite pay TV tender, which was sent to his office for signature in January, accompanied by a brief or any other documentation?

—Senator Tambling will be able to examine all of those matters at length very shortly because, as I told the Senate estimates committee last night—and I am not quite sure how much faster we can do it—we will be bringing a report into this place prior to the last week of sittings, with all of the papers surrounding the matter.

para.tab: In the last two weeks of sittings—and I must make this observation—I have seen something very comforting for this Government: this Opposition is no different now from the Opposition that we had before the federal election.

question.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is obvious that the Minister is ducking and weaving and attempting to camouflage and hide. He did not answer my question, which was: was the determination accompanied by a brief? I am not going to wait three, six or 10 weeks for some report to come back in order to find out whether or not he had the capacity to read a brief. Can I remind the Minister of what he said yesterday to Senator Ferguson:

question.para: The issues are first canvassed on paper. So even if it were an oral briefing, there will be a piece of paper in the department that was sent over prior to that briefing indicating the issues that will be canvassed and their background.
Why does the Minister not now admit that he either did not read it, did not act on it, or did not have it; and why did he sign without such a briefing?

talk.start.para: —I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer to recent media reports on Japanese organised crime and, in particular, to recent media speculation about the threat from Japanese organised crime in Australia. I ask the Minister whether he could inform the Senate as to the real situation facing Australian authorities.
—I thank Senator Jones for his question. In doing so, I also want to acknowledge the genuine concern that the media and media reports have generated on this particular issue.

para.tab: The Minister for Justice has sought advice from the commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in respect of this issue. As a consequence of that advice, I am advised that the AFP has in fact been monitoring Japanese organised crime trends and activities for a number of years. I am also advised that the AFP has an excellent working relationship with the Japanese national police. There is high level liaison between the two agencies and, in fact, the AFP's assistant commissioner for investigations recently visited Tokyo for further discussions with relevant Japanese authorities. This sort of liaison has enhanced the AFP's understanding of the level of the threat to Australia of Japanese organised crime.

There has been some success achieved by agencies, particularly the AFP, in the monitoring of this issue. In fact, in 1991 several alleged members of Japanese gangs were visiting Australia and were detected as violating immigration laws. They then admitted to having failed to declare their past criminal records and, as a consequence, underwent supervised departures from Australia.

From the immigration perspective, AFP's close liaison with authorities has enhanced our immigration controls in this area. There has been media speculation in recent days, particularly in Queensland. That speculation has named specific persons. I do not think it is appropriate for me in my capacity as Minister representing the police Minister to comment directly on much of that speculation. We do, of course, have a responsibility not to prejudice investigative methods and we also have a responsibility not to unduly violate individuals' privacy by unproven allegations.

What I will say, though, is that I have asked my department, the immigration department, to investigate the allegations as they affect immigration laws. I have asked for an urgent brief on that. I do know that the person involved holds a multiple visa. That visa, I am informed, was issued at a time when he had no criminal records. The last time he entered Australia was January 1992, on the advice I have. As I said, I have asked for an urgent brief on this to see what the implications are for immigration laws and what capacity I have to intervene in this matter.

So I acknowledge that there are genuine concerns about the matter. In conclusion, I want to place on record the advice from the commissioner of the AFP—the assurance that we have had as a government that resources are devoted to this area at a level which will enable an effective response to any threat posed by Japanese organised crime in any part of Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Are the Minister and her Government satisfied with the outcome in Longman's case and with the degree to which it is or is not being followed?
—Mr President, I am afraid that I do not know what that refers to; so I will take it on notice and get a briefing for the honourable senator as soon as I can.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister and her Government have made much recently of an admirable concern about gender bias in the law.
—How can you ask a supplementary question?
—The question is coming. The Minister swans around purporting to know something about this. She comments here, there and everywhere on what judges ought to say. Is she telling me—
—I take a point of order, Mr President.
—This is the question—
—This is not a question; it is an editorial assertion of a peculiarly offensive kind. Mr President, I ask you to rule her out of order.
—Order! Ask the supplementary.

—The question is: is the Minister telling me that as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, she does not know about the most recent High Court authority on what it is and is not acceptable for judges to say—despite the fact that she is happy to spout off about it? The Minister does not give a tinker's damn about whether that case is followed. What is she doing in the job if she does not know the basis of it?
—Mr President—
—Order!
—Thirty seconds to go, Rosemary.

—Yes, that is quite right, and if honourable senators opposite keep talking and braying there will be nothing further to say. Senator Vanstone accuses me of mouthing off about a whole lot of issues of which I know nothing. My policy is to speak only about what I have been briefed about.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the sale by tender of the opalised skeleton of an ancient reptile, a plysoran, known colloquially as Eric, and presently located at the Australian Museum in Sydney. Mr Alex Ritchie of the Australian Museum is quoted in an advertisement in the
Australian Financial Review
as saying that the skeleton is one of the most important scientific specimens of its kind ever discovered in Australia. He describes it as a national treasure. In view of the cultural importance of the fossil, I ask the Minister: has the museum notified his department of the intended sale? Will the Minister notify the museum that the Government considers that the permanent export of the fossil would significantly diminish the nation's cultural heritage and, as such, would be refused a permanent export permit?

—This issue arises because the company that owns this particular exhibit is in provisional liquidation. Therefore, the receiver has called for sale by tender, which in the normal course he would, of this fossil as an asset of the company in provisional liquidation. But the concern is that a number of prominent experts are very concerned that this opalised skeleton is of such unique value that it should not be allowed to be exported. It comes before the Commonwealth Government, although it is in the custody of a New South Wales Government establishment, the Australian Museum, because of the Protection of Moveable Cultural Heritage Act. Anybody who purchases the fossil, if wishing to remove it from Australia, will have to apply to my department in accordance with that Act for a permit to export it.

para.tab: The Labor Government introduced that legislation to prevent the removal of significant cultural items from Australia, and I think it is important. There seems to be little doubt about this fossil's significance to Australia's cultural heritage. As far as I can tell, that is a matter not in dispute. It is clearly something of significant commercial value also.

No application for export has been received by the department until now. If an application is received, the advice of expert examiners would be sought and that advice would be referred to the National Cultural Heritage Committee. Although no application has been received, because of the obvious and well-known significance of this particular fossil and the publicity surrounding it, which has drawn it to public attention, the department is already seeking advice from expert examiners appointed under the Act to ascertain whether they would be likely to recommend or refuse a permit, so that if any decision is made—because tenders for this sale close on Friday—we will be in a position to make a prompt decision in response to any application that might be made about the export of Eric.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of internal investigations by Telecom's Protective Services Unit into alleged travelling allowance rorts by Telecom employees involving millions of dollars of taxpayers' money? Is the Minister further aware of allegations that such investigations have been thwarted by high level Telecom officers who themselves are involved in the rorts? Does the Minister consider it justice that the only individual who appears to have been charged by Telecom to date regarding travelling allowance rorts is an individual who, in fact, had turned whistleblower on the basis that he would receive reasonable protection?
—No, I have no advice on that specific issue which, I must say, I am not surprised about. I will follow up the matter and provide Senator Calvert with an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the Victorian Sentencing (Amendment) Bill 1993 and the Victorian Crimes (Amendment) Bill 1993 and ask the Minister: is he aware that these Bills propose to introduce indefinite sentences of imprisonment for a large number of offences, permit fingerprinting of adults and young people 15 years of age and over without court order and whether or not they have been charged with an offence, and abolish the right of citizens to contest a police application for a court order permitting the taking of body samples? Secondly, does the Minister agree that these provisions contravene articles 12 and 40 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and articles 9, 10, 17 and 24 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to both of which Australia is a signatory? Will the Minister refer the Bills—
—Order! Time has expired.

—I am advised by the Attorney-General that he is aware of the Bills, both from extensive press reports about them and also from a number of letters that have been sent to him by community groups. The Attorney-General recognises that the community is concerned on the one hand that it be provided with effective law enforcement. However, he believes that there are serious questions as to whether the Bills in fact strike the appropriate balance between the need to take a strong stand on crime and the need to meet our international obligations in respect of those two instruments to which Senator Spindler refers.

para.tab: I am informed that the Attorney-General has not as yet seen copies of both Bills, and he has not reached a conclusive view on whether the provisions of the Bills breach those two particular conventions. However, in view of his responsibilities as Commonwealth Attorney-General, particularly the responsibility to ensure that Australia complies with its international treaty obligations, he wrote to the Victorian Attorney-General on 7 May about these Bills.

In that letter Mr Lavarch asked for copies of the Bills and referred to the fact that the human rights commissioner had written to Mrs Wade informing her of his intention to examine the Bills in the light of his functions and responsibilities in monitoring Australia's compliance with a number of international instruments. Mr Lavarch also put to Mrs Wade some of the concerns that had been raised with him about possible human rights breaches arising from provisions in the Victorian Crimes (Amendment) Bill and invited her to respond with her views on those concerns.

Finally, in view of the importance of ensuring that the Bills do not breach Australia's international obligations, Mr Lavarch also asked Mrs Wade to allow further time for him, as well as interested members of the public, to consider and make productive comments on the Bills before they are enacted.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. When will the Government give adequate resources for research into the cause and treatment of breast cancer?

—Yesterday I had a meeting with Professors Alan Coates and John Forbes who, as Senator Reid may know, in recent weeks have talked to a number of conferences about the need to increase resources going into the detection and treatment of breast cancer. As a result of the models that they presented to me yesterday, I will be presenting to the States—Senator Reid will appreciate that any program which the Commonwealth would like to enter into will have to be done with the States—at the health Ministers meeting, which I think from memory is in the first week of July, a suggestion on how we might make a national campaign on breast cancer the first trial for the national health policy.

para.tab: From newspaper reports Senator Reid may recall that the health summit that took place in Sydney a couple of weeks ago decided on four areas in the health portfolio that we would concentrate on for the national health policy. One of them was cancer. I think breast cancer provides us with the best opportunity to get some sort of national approach. Inevitably, if a national approach is to be achieved it will involve extra money.

When we announced our intention of having a national health policy, which took us 90 years to achieve, all the health Ministers agreed that we want to demonstrate progress by March of next year. The test that I give myself on this matter is to make sure that by March of next year I can announce that not only have increased funds been spent on a problem that kills some six women a day, but hopefully I can also announce that it is part of a national program and a coordinated approach.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that 2,513 women died of breast cancer in 1992, while 481 died of AIDS in the same year. How is the answer that the Minister has given adequate, given that $9.8 million was spent on AIDS in 1990-91 and only $1.5 million will be spent on research into breast cancer in 1993? When is the Minister really going to do something about this issue?
—It is the power of the lobby.

—It is not a question of the power of the lobby at all. If one goes through the areas of research and looks at the spending that Australia puts into it—for instance, where the NHMRC puts its $100 million or where the private industry puts its—one can see a difficulty in that there is competition between a whole range of health prerogatives for research funding.

para.tab: In the past couple of weeks I have had a case advanced to me that we are not spending enough on cardiovascular research and that it ought to be given a higher priority over other areas. When one talks to the experts in the field they mount convincing cases, as they do with breast cancer. The truth is that medical research in Australia needs to be upgraded overall. We simply do not spend enough on it. One of the promises that the Prime Minister made in the election campaign, which is of vital and fundamental importance, is the promise to increase the percentage of spending on research. Hopefully we will be able to announce a program to do that after the Budget.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. The Minister will be aware of reports that in the current economic climate there has been an increase in the demands on voluntary organisations and community groups assisting people with serious financial problems. Has the Government taken any steps to support the efforts of these groups?

—Yes. The Government does have an emergency relief program that is directed towards providing grants to non-government welfare agencies as emergency cash assistance. In these tough economic times there has certainly been a demand for emergency relief. Last year the Government agreed to match dollar for dollar all dollars raised in the Christmas appeals of the major welfare organisations. That amounted to a further $8.7 million that the Government was able to provide to assist those agencies from the money raised in those Christmas appeals. It is now coming on winter and about a week ago I launched—
—Did they tell you about that in the brief?

—Senator Patterson is a merry little thing. A week ago in Adelaide I launched the winter appeal for St Vincent de Paul. I am a bit surprised at the flippancy of those opposite, given the heart-bleeding and heart-rending accounts that I have heard from them on these matters. Indeed, I thought those opposite were the ones who wanted to privatise all of this. They wanted to put all welfare through these organisations. Members of the Opposition are the ones who, not less than 12 months ago, were arguing for privatising welfare. It is surprising that they are not interested in this kind of concern at this time of the year.
—Are you going to allocate the money for next Christmas, too?
