—I understand from Senator Macdonald's interjection that he is not interested in emergency relief. He would not want to assist people who might be in some sort of need. That is quite contrary to the Government's position. The Government is interested in working in association with the non-government welfare organisations. Their credibility and their capacity on the ground to get close to the people in need and to know how best to provide that emergency relief to them are some of the things that make those organisations so invaluable. There should be nobody in this place who would object to the work done by St Vincent de Paul; to the work done by the Salvation Army, which I noticed in today's paper was launching its appeal with Mr Kennett; or the Brotherhood of St Laurence, to name just three of our major agencies.

para.tab: The Government is very committed to providing emergency relief assistance as cash to these major non-government welfare organisations, precisely because that arrangement of government assistance and non-government agencies provides the very best care for people in financial or emergency need. I think it is a matter of celebration that the Government sees fit to support people in need through this emergency relief funding.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Auditor-General's report in which he cited abuse of credit cards by officers of the taxation department who used them for the purchase of such things as chocolates, horse riding lessons, dance studio lessons and Christmas goods.
—You asked this at the estimates committee.

—That is all right. I ask the Minister: what actions has he taken to deal with the offending officers and why does the Government not demand the same high degree of honesty of the tax department as it does of ordinary taxpayers?

—We set out fairly carefully to explain the nature of Senator Panizza's misunderstanding last night in the estimates committee. As that explanation did not work, I refer him to the
Hansard
.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister does demand the same degree of honesty, and considering that the Auditor-General has reported what happened, how many officers have been charged or dismissed as a result of these incidents, just as an ordinary person who may take a little bit more in social security than he is entitled to would be charged?

—I can only reiterate that the supplementary question reinforces the impression created by the original question that Senator Panizza did not understand the debate that went on last night, nor the answers that were given to him.
—I understand what is in the report. Stop hiding it.

—The significant point is that Senator Panizza does not understand. It is not that I would in any way pretend that what took place in the tax office which was outlined last night was satisfactory, nor does it meet the description that Senator Panizza gives it. It was unsatisfactory and the Auditor-General was correct to draw attention to it. But if Senator Panizza had understood what went on last night he would not have asked the question today.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the evident support which Tasmanians gave to the Medicare program, as demonstrated by their casting of votes in the general election on 13 March.
—How many did you get?

—I got 90 per cent of the votes of Bridgewater. I ask the Minister: when can Tasmanians expect to see funds flowing under the Medicare agreement to the great public hospitals of Tasmania to ensure that they continue to provide an enhanced service to the Tasmanian people?

—I am sure Senator Tate would be aware that Medicare agreements have been signed with most States, including Tasmania, with the exception of Western Australia. I am scheduled to go to Western Australia on Friday of next week to talk to the Minister. Our officials are meeting as we speak and hopefully we can come to some agreement. Under the Medicare agreement signed with Tasmania an extra $29 million will be provided to that State for public hospitals.
—Annually?

—That is the first figure and it gets greater over time. While we were losing those two seats that Senator Macdonald referred to earlier in an interjection, the people of Australia—and certainly of Tasmania—were interested in the fact that they would have lost $35 million under Fightback if that had been approved. I do not know about those two seats; I do know that Labor won three seats in Tasmania. Is that correct?
—Three.
—I think that was a pretty spectacular performance.
—How many did you win in the Senate?

—We have not got as many seats as the Opposition in the Senate, but I bet Senator Macdonald wishes the position was reversed. I bet even Senator Macdonald is bright enough to work out this: it is better to have the numbers down there, old son. I withdraw that; I am sorry.

para.tab: The funding arrangements under those agreements will mean pretty significant benefits for patients and for public hospitals. The way in which the agreements work means that those States which reduce public access do suffer penalties under the agreement and those States that can do even better do gain access to bonuses. I am sure that some States will be trying very hard to do that. My meetings with the Tasmanian Government so far have been fairly positive in that respect.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciated the occasional rhetorical flourish in the Minister's answer, but I do want to know when that money will start to flow.

—I shall not attempt to avoid this question; I shall be direct. The first payment to the States and Territories, including Tasmania, under the new agreements, will be received on the morning of Tuesday, 6 July 1993.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, refers to the Prime Minister's promise to buy 10,000 beds in private hospitals in an attempt to shorten waiting lists in the public hospitals. I ask: was that promise made after full consultation with the private hospitals? If so, what was the result of those consultations? Is it a fact that that particular promise is now another promise made by the Government that is being broken?

—The actual promise was to provide $100 million over four years for the purchase of beds in private hospitals for public patients. A number of private hospitals had indicated to the Government that they would be interested in pursuing that kind of arrangement.
—Which ones?

—I was asked that question at the estimates committee hearing the other night and I said then that I do not intend to answer that question. I could, but I do not intend to do so. What hospitals wish to indicate to governments in private ought to be kept private. Those hospitals need to understand that governments can be discreet in dealing with what are private concerns.

para.tab: What I have said since the election is that, while I would like to make sure that we retain the $100 million over four years, because the real need is to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals, as small as they are, if anyone is suffering on a waiting list it is the duty of governments to do something about it, and so we shall. I have said, though, that if we can be convinced that there are other ways to spend the money—different ways but nonetheless ways that will contribute to reducing those waiting lists—then we will certainly look at them. Every penny that the Government promised to reduce waiting lists will be spent.

I am scheduling meetings with the private hospital groups in the first two weeks of June to discuss with them just how we might go about purchasing those beds. I will be very happy to report to the Senate in the next session about the progress of those arrangements.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not answered my question. I asked what consultation had taken place and what the result of that consultation was. The Minister has just said that some private hospitals indicated their interest. Did the Minister get a promise of 10,000 bed days from the private hospitals before the promise was made?
—I cannot say that I am aware of all the details of the consultation. I am aware that people in the industry indicated an interest in pursuing the proposal.
—Can the Minister for Transport and Communications detail the effect deregulation of the airline industry has had on Queensland's tourism industry.

—I am delighted to inform the Senate that the level of Australia's domestic aviation activity continued to increase significantly to new overall record levels for the March quarter. The news is also very good for Queensland. Activity in the March quarter 1993 was the highest on record for any March quarter to date, with 4.7 million passengers carried. This was boosted by the presence of Qantas carrying domestic passengers.

para.tab: The availability of seat capacity in the March quarter was also at record levels. On an annual basis the airlines carried over 18.3 million passengers in the year ended 31 March 1993. That is another record for a 12-month period ending in March. Given these record levels, the Department of Transport and Communications notes that the domestic market may well stabilise over the next few reporting periods.

There was especially goods news for Queensland in these figures, with some significant increases compared with the March 1992 quarter results. Increased passenger movements in March 1993 compared with March 1992 were achieved at the following Queensland destinations: Cairns, an increase of 44 per cent; Proserpine, up 38 per cent; Townsville, up 33 per cent; Maroochydore, up 30 per cent; Mackay, up 17 per cent; Rockhampton, up 11 per cent; and Brisbane, up 11 per cent.

Mr President, if I might be parochial for a minute, I note that the March 1993 results compared with the March 1992 results also indicated very encouraging growth at Yulara, with an increase in traffic of 37 per cent, and at Alice Springs, with an increase of 13 per cent. These results are a clear demonstration that the Government's decision to deregulate domestic aviation has been a major contributor to the development of the many holiday destinations in Australia and the economic benefits which continue to flow from the tourism industry. I might add, with some satisfaction, that it is a policy which has no added GST.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to questions without notice asked by Senators Alston, O'Chee and Tambling this day, relating to the tendering process for subscription television licences.

The answers given by Senator Collins today were a classic trifecta because he simply refused to answer each question he was asked. That goes a long way to explaining why every journalist who has examined this issue over the last two or three weeks has come to the unanimous conclusion that Senator Collins ought to go. They have reached that conclusion for the reason that he manifestly cannot handle the issues; he ducks and weaves; and, on almost every occasion, he says whatever suits him if he thinks it will get him off the hook. Today there were two instances in which Senator Collins made statements which were demonstrably untrue. In neither instance was he prepared to concede or to back down; he simply chose to tough it out. That is, I would have thought, a contempt of the Senate.

It is worth examining the answers given by Senator Collins because there is probably some greater significance to the reason for his behaviour than simply sheer pig-headedness or stupidity. The first question that Senator Collins was asked today related to the statement contained in his letter to the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications dated 11 May. That is four days after he received the letter from the secretary dated 7 May. So the Minister's reply was not dashed off on the spur of the moment. He said:

speech.para: Thank you for your letter of 7 May in which you provided draft terms of reference for the inquiry into the Pay Television tender process following your discussions with Professor Pearce.

In other words, the discussions with Professor Pearce must have occurred prior to 7 May. Yet today the Minister told the Senate that Professor Pearce was first briefed on this matter on the morning of 8 May. In other words, Professor Pearce played no part in the drafting of the terms of reference.

para.tab: That fact is also dealt with very specifically by the answer Senator Collins gave to a question asked by Senator McKiernan in Question Time the other day about how the terms of reference came to be determined. Senator Collins talked about the terms of reference being settled between the secretary to the department and Professor Pearce. `Settled', of course, is not the appropriate term. They were simply presented to Professor Pearce as a fait accompli. More importantly, if that is true, Senator Collins clearly got it wrong when he said, `I did not draw up these terms of reference, Professor Pearce did'.

Senator Collins ought to acknowledge that that is clearly incorrect and at least have the grace to back down and apologise to the Senate for that statement. If he wants to say, for example, `Well, I said it in the heat of the moment. It was simply because of Senator Hill interjecting and I got it wrong. I did not really mean that. What I meant to say was that he was consulted or that he settled', that would be one thing. He was given the opportunity to say that today and he did not take it. Therefore, we are entitled to ask why it is that we have this obvious obtuseness on the part of the Minister to the point where he is deliberately trying to run an agenda.

I think the answer is that he is trying to invest Professor Pearce with some high degree of involvement in the drafting of the terms of reference to create the impression that this is somehow objective, somehow above a grubby little exercise of trying to divert attention from his own manifest lack of responsibility. He is trying to suggest that somehow Professor Pearce is the one who ought to be given the credit for these terms of reference. That is outrageous. The Minister ought to apologise to Professor Pearce for using or misusing him twice in the way that he has, and he ought to apologise to the Senate and explain that the statements that he made and that are on the record simply cannot stand up.

We know, for example, from today's
Australian Financial Review
—and again Senator Collins did not take any opportunity to dispute it and merely confirmed it—that Professor Pearce was first approached on 8 May to head the pay TV inquiry. So how can it possibly be that the terms of reference drafted by the secretary on the seventh were, in any shape or form, discussed with Professor Pearce prior to their being provided to the Minister? One can look not only at that answer, but also at the Minister's clear determination to hide behind the coat-tails of the Federal Court and basically plead the last refuge of a failed law student, that is, that this matter is sub judice. Senator O'Chee made it clear that the evidence was proving beyond doubt that the only written advice provided and made available to Senator Collins was very much against the direction that he was moving in and the banning of the ABA from involvement in the process. He simply said to the court, `I did have other advice'. That other advice would seem to have been oral advice.

talk.start.para: —That is not what I said. Read the transcript.

—I have read the transcript. Senator O'Chee read portions of the transcript today. His Honour, in due course, will stitch the Minister right up. It is obvious to all concerned that the only advice he had in writing told him not to do what he was determined to do. The reality is that he was not particularly keen on doing it, anyway. It was only as a result of a severe bout of arm twisting from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that both he and his department were dragged screaming to his agenda. We can understand his reluctance, but to somehow suggest, as I presume he must, that he talked Mr Doherty out of his written opinion so that he got him to the point where he had positive oral advice in favour of the Minister's actions is a manifest absurdity. Therefore, we have those two examples of Senator Collins simply refusing to provide any coherent explanation.

para.tab: Senator Tambling can deal more precisely with the answer that he was given. The end result is that, after about two weeks, we still do not have a Minister prepared to accept responsibility, or to face up to the basic proposition, which is: why did the Minister not read that document before he signed it? Why is he engaged in this elaborate smokescreen of setting up a bureaucratic witch-hunt to divert attention from his own shortcomings? Why did he appear before the estimates committee until 3 a.m.—

talk.start.para: —Because you kept me there.

—Indeed; because he refused to answer any question on the basis that, somehow, his hand-picked inquiry into the activities of poor, hapless bureaucrats has precedence over the Senate. The fact is that the Senate estimates committee has absolute jurisdiction in the matter, as the Minister well knows. He conceded last night that there was nothing in law or convention that entitled him to do what he did. It was simply his preferred course of action. In other words, he was in political damage control mode. He was frantically determined to avoid responsibility to this Senate. He is wanting to put the matter off as long as possible, to hand it over to Professor Pearce as an objective outsider. From the very outset, the Minister has been trying to pretend that these terms of reference are Professor Pearce's, not his. It is about time he faced up to where true responsibility in the matter lies.

—I wish to explain why there is confusion in Senator Alston's mind. This conspiracy theory is an outrageous slur on Professor Pearce—hand-picked; two assumptions. It is disgraceful that Senator Alston is getting down to this level. Professor Pearce is an acknowledged Australian expert on administrative law. He is dean of the law school at the ANU and a former Commonwealth ombudsman. Senator Alston has put forward this extraordinary proposition that because I wrote a letter—I will go through it again; honourable senators should listen to this—saying, `Thank you for your letter of the seventh', it was impossible for Professor Pearce to have seen it.

para.tab: I can explain it. It was a trick letter. I will tell honourable senators what the trick was. This letter was designed to distinguish between idiots and cretins. Idiots could see the trick; cretins could not. I will take Senator Alston through it; this is the test. A letter arrives on 7 May—is he following this?—addressed to me, laying out the terms of reference of the inquiry. Has he got it? On Saturday a copy of this same letter—I still have mine—goes to Professor Pearce with a bundle of documents. Professor Pearce received that letter—I have explained all this twice and Senator Alston still did not get the trick, so it is pretty clear which category he is in—and reads the papers to determine whether he thinks that the terms of reference are appropriate.

Saturday passes and I have still have my letter of 7 May. Sunday passes and I still have my letter of 7 May. Monday comes. Mr Evans telephones Professor Pearce—I still have my letter of 7 May—and says to Professor Pearce—

talk.start.para: —This is appalling.

—It astonishes me; I have said this three times and Senator Alston cannot see it. I still have the same letter of 7 May; is Senator Alston following this? Mr Evans says to Professor Pearce, `Are you satisfied?'. Professor Pearce says, `Yes, I've read the papers. I think that the terms of reference are appropriate'. Okay?

para.tab: I still have the letter of 7 May. The phone rings. I pick it up. I answer the phone—I still have the same letter—and say, `Hello'. The caller says, `Minister?'. I say, `Yes, Mr Evans'. The letter does not move. He says, `I have spoken to Professor Pearce. He is satisfied that the terms of reference are appropriate'. I said, `Thank you'. He said, `Have you read the terms of reference?'. I said yes.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Under the relevant standing order you have the power to keep control of this place. I suggest that the little stunt that is now being engaged in is a piece of theatre that does nothing but demean the Senate. If you allow this to go on, you will have people bringing in cornflakes boxes and spilling them out on the table and God knows where we will go. We cannot have stunts in this place; he should be made to sit down or at least address the chamber seriously and not engage in some stupid stunt.

—That is pretty cute coming from someone who walked into the chamber with a bunch of pornographic videos. I will conclude, so that Senator Alston does not lose the drift. I then say to Mr Evans, `No, I do not want to change the terms of reference'. Mr Evans has already told me that Professor Pearce does not—and I still have the letter of 7 May. So there has been no change to this letter. I then write back and say, `Thank you for your letter of 7 May'. `After you have settled these matters with Professor Pearce'—this is when I am on the phone on the Monday—`I will approve it'.

para.tab: I cannot explain it any more simply than that. I am sorry that I did not ask the Secretary to my department to send me a fresh copy of the same letter on that day so that Senator Alston could work it out.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask that the Minister table his letter of 11 May and at the same time—
—It was tabled yesterday.

—Could he just put it on the desk in front of him and at the same time explain how he can possibly come to the conclusion he just has when the letter says, `Thank you for your letter of 7 May . . . following your discussions with Professor Pearce' when no discussions took place with Professor Pearce until the 8th?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have to make a confession. This is not actually the letter of 7 May; it is a prop. The letter has already been tabled in the House.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: —Today, in one of the answers which form the subject of this motion, Senator Collins carried on while not providing the appropriate information. Yesterday Senator Ferguson raised some very important issues that needed to be addressed. Yet Senator Collins says one thing in this place and another thing to the Northern Territory media. It is that issue to which I would like to refer. Yesterday when Senator Ferguson asked the question about what Senator Collins had read before he signed the documentation, Senator Collins made the statement that he always received a brief. Today when I requested information as to whether or not he had received a brief, I was told that I had to wait until the Pearce report was finalised and brought back to this chamber.

para.tab:
It is a matter of Senator Collins saying one thing in this place, where he has full proper ministerial and parliamentary responsibility, and another thing in the electorate—currying favour with the electorate; I wonder why. I wish to refer to the
Sunday Territorian
coverage of this TV fiasco—TV row issue—that was given good electorate coverage by a journalist in an opinion piece, obviously very sympathetic to Senator Collins. It is obvious from the article, because of the direct quotes of Senator Collins, that he had a hand in preparing that article by Mr John Loizou. The first quote was:
"I accept responsibility for the fact that the submission which should have been checked by my communications adviser was not because he was on leave," Senator Collins said.

speech.para: A further quote was:
"I didn't ensure that he was either recalled or replaced.
And I accept the responsibility for not taking a more interventionist role in the tender process myself.
He did not tell us anything like that here in the last few days. But he has given it to a journalist to put into a Northern Territory newspaper. In the article Mr Loizou says:

para.tab: The admittance by Senator Collins that he did not examine the terms of the tendering process prepared by his department for the granting of the licences has not helped.

speech.para: This is a matter of real, extreme and major concern to this chamber. Senator Collins is prepared to say one thing to his journalist mate in the Northern Territory and withhold the same information from this chamber. He ought to have been just as open and honest with us in here. Obviously, not only is he prepared to say those sorts of things differently and exercise his ministerial responsibility differently, but also, again, he tends to camouflage and hide behind his staff. In the quote that I just read, he referred to the checking by his communications adviser. Further on in the article Senator Collins is directly quoted as saying:

para.tab: " But I've made arrangements with my principal private secretary to ensure that only if I'm on my death bed or the third world war arrives is such a situation to arise again.

speech.para: Again, he does not have the fortitude, the intelligence or the strength to stand by his own decisions. He has put the onus back to his principal private secretary—to ensure that his staff has to hang around for this type of advice. This is very much a matter of the Minister passing the buck to others, as he continually seeks to do. Where is the doctrine of ministerial responsibility? He has obviously divorced himself from it. He continues to insult the intelligence of not only the Parliament and the media but also the electorate.

talk.start.para: —I am appalled at the information which has just come forward from Senator Tambling. I am very concerned to think that we have a Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who is not prepared to be accountable either to the Senate estimates committee or to this chamber, which is, after all, his first responsibility as a Minister. As a part of the Executive of this nation, he is accountable to the Parliament and the people of this country. He obviously has a totally different standard of accountability when it comes to the people of the Northern Territory.

para.tab: I therefore ask that Senator Tambling consider giving the evidence he has just stated in this debate to Professor Pearce, who is conducting this inquiry, in order that the full story can be known. I am concerned that, apparently judging by the public record of Senator Collins in Canberra, a fairly limited amount of information will be given on behalf of the Minister to the inquiry. Clearly Professor Pearce needs to have his attention drawn to this material which so far has been available only to people in the Northern Territory. Therefore, I ask that Senator Tambling make every effort to see that Professor Pearce gets a copy of the material to which he has referred in his speech.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —This debate is about decency. It is about the standards that are expected by the community of parliamentarians and the standards that parliamentarians expect of each other. Most importantly, the highest standards of all are the standards that the Parliament expects of the Ministry. That is what this debate is all about. It is about whether we have, in the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), a Minister who accepts that those standards must apply to him as they do to everybody else and whether he is willing to discharge his duty in relation to those standards.

para.tab: We have already seen that Senator Collins quite clearly does not believe that he has an obligation to answer to this chamber. He has set up an inquiry which has no standing under the rules of this Parliament or the conventions under which this Parliament runs. Yet every time he is asked a question here, in the chamber where he is expected to answer, his response is always, `Well, I've set up an inquiry so you shouldn't ask me about those things'. That is a grave slight on this Senate. It shows, first and foremost, that Senator Collins lacks the respect and the decency to recognise that it is here in this chamber, amongst his colleagues and the elected representatives of the people, that he must answer for his manifest failures. That is Senator Collins's first grave mistake.

Secondly, we have a Minister who seems to have misled the Federal Court of Australia on two separate matters in sworn evidence. First, he told the Federal Court that he received legal advice from his department's senior legal adviser to the effect that he could rule out the MDS-pay TV option. Secondly, he told a judge of the Federal Court of Australia that he was doing it to preserve the intent of the legislation. When we read the legal advice that was provided to him by his department's senior legal adviser, what does it say?

The advice is quite the contrary to what Senator Collins has said. Instead of saying, `You are absolutely right, Senator Collins. What are you going to do will preserve the extent of the legislation', the advice says:

speech.para: The ABA does not seem to have a legitimate basis to adopt the approach of rejecting all applications put before it for subscription TV broadcasting licences via MDS.
Senator Collins is wrong. It goes on to say:
A direction not to grant MDS licences for subscription television broadcasting services seems to cut across the objectives of the legislation.

Senator Collins is wrong again. The problem is that these clearly misleading statements that he made were made under oath in the Federal Court of Australia. He is a Minister of the Crown. As a Minister in this Government, he is expected to have a standard of decency and honesty that is elevated to a sufficient degree so that he will tell the truth. But unfortunately he will not do it.

para.tab: Finally, we find the situation that Senator Tambling has shown the Senate today where Senator Collins has one standard for when he is in the electorate and another for when he is here. If this chamber is to maintain any relevance or to uphold the principles on which good government in this country is based, Senator Collins must at least do the Senate the courtesy of maintaining in this place the same standards and code of behaviour that he seems to reserve for his electorate in the Northern Territory.

We clearly see Senator Collins time and again flouting both the rules by which government is run in this country and the rules of this chamber. If Senator Collins cannot tell the truth to a court or to us, and if he will not let the Senate hear the whole story so that he can be judged, he is guilty by default. Quite simply, under the rules of this place, it is a hanging offence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to an Audit Office report on the use of Government credit cards by officers of the Australian Taxation Office.

speech.para:
I briefly want to address the question that I asked Senator McMullan during Question Time, which involved the matter of the abuse of credit cards by officers of the Australian Taxation Office. I will read from Auditor-General's report No. 29 of 1992-93 entitled
Aggregate and Departmental Financial Statements 1991-92
on how the inquiry into the matter took place. The Auditor-General qualified his comments in the report in this way:
The Commissioner's Direction on the Use of the Australian Government Credit Card specifies requirements in relation to the administration and the use of credit cards.
20.4.116 There was a number of unsatisfactory matters relating to credit cards including non-compliance with aspects of the Commissioner's Direction. These included:
.some card holders had no approval or agreement indicating their duties and responsibilities
.there were inadequate descriptions on sales vouchers which prevented verification of items purchased
.cash advances were obtained contrary to the Finance Regulations, and
.cards were used for purchasing goods and services normally considered to be of a private nature.

20.4.117 The ATO advised that action was taken by the relevant Deputy Commissioner to reduce the number of credit cards on issue and to counsel officers, bringing the appropriate instructions to their attention.

I would have thought that anyone who had use of a government credit card knew what responsibilities they had, what may and may not be purchased on that card and for what purposes they produced the card. The report continues:
The instruction for the use of credit cards are being reviewed and a code of ethics has been issued.

20.4.118 Expenditure at one branch office included the provision of lunches and refreshments to ATO staff, flowers, chocolates, horse riding, a dance seminar and the purchase of Christmas goods. Most of this expenditure was incurred through credit cards with purchases ranging from $12 to $1600. The ANAO considered that this type of expenditure would normally be of a private nature, and sought clarification from the branch office regarding the necessity and relevance of this expenditure to meet ATO activities.
20.4.119 The branch office investigated the cases referred by the ANAO and concluded that:

`After considering explanations offered by the relevant officers, and bearing in mind the major culture change pressures at the time, the Deputy Commissioner has formed the view that no budget holder sought personal gain from any expenditure, nor had any improper intent, nor deliberately set out to breach the rules. On the contrary, we think that at worst there were instances of over-enthusiastic efforts to embrace the thrust of change and to lead staff into their new environment'.

I would like Senator McMullan to explain to me, as he refused to listen last night at the estimates committee, what is meant by the change of environment, the fact that there was no personal gain and the major cultural change pressures.

para.tab: Within the group of the one million unemployed around Australia there are very many unfortunate people who have had many social pressures on them after they or their spouses have lost their jobs. There have been various instances around Australia of social security fraud, entailing only amounts of a few hundred dollars or less in some cases, that have come to the notice of the social security department. People have certainly been fined, and in the bigger cases gaoled, for that offence, which is the very same offence that has been committed in this case.

Do not tell me that there are no cultural and social pressures on people who cannot find a job or who have lost their jobs. Yet here we have well-paid officers of the Australian Taxation Office blaming social and cultural pressures. I can understand an officer paying $12-odd for a box of chocolates for someone, but I cannot see that riding lessons or dancing lessons are not a personal gain. If one gains knowledge, that is a personal gain. Whether or not one can ride a horse or dance has little to do with how to operate the tax office, so it must be a personal gain. The report went on to say:

speech.para: The ANAO was concerned that there was a lack of clear written instructions on hospitality expenditure, and that public monies had been spent with insufficient regard to the probity and propriety of such expenditure.
20.4.121 The ATO advised that:

para.tab: `. . . it has been decided that the thrust of our remedial action should be to move in the direction of clarifying current roles, expectations and authorities, and to endeavour to ensure that they remain clear in the future'.

speech.para: These unfortunate people around Australia who have had to resort to a bit of petty thieving because of the position they are in and because of the impositions of the social security department have found no such sympathy. They have been dealt with by the courts, and justifiably so, and put into gaol, in most cases justifiably. Yet here we have a whitewash of the tax office. The report continues:

This response incorporates the ANAO
recommendation
that clear guidelines should be issued, particularly with regard to working lunches and the purchase of goods and refreshments for ATO staff.

I wish Senator Walsh were in the chamber. Going back over the last 10 years, when he was Minister for Finance he pointed out the abuse of the free lunches, the free trips, the free accommodation that seemed to be available to the high-fliers of the business community in the roaring 198Os. As a Minister, through the Parliament and through his department, he put an end to those practices. But today the taxation office, which demands the highest standard of honesty of everyone in Australia, cannot apply that to itself.

para.tab: I could go on and deal with other things, such as the lack of substantiation. For instance, there was a certain amount of property bought for which there were no original invoices. What happens when we file a tax return? We have self-assessment these days, which means that substantiation must be available if one is audited, and there are a few audits around. The tax office does not listen to excuses, so why should this Minister listen to these sorts of excuses from the tax office? The report goes on:

speech.para: There were some instances where proposals to spend public moneys under Finance Regulation 44A and/or Section 64 of the Constitution had been approved by officers in excess of their authorised limit.
Once again, there is a limit and an officer goes over it. The report continues:
The ATO advised that the responsibilities of officers with financial authorisations and delegations are being emphasised through the Managing in the Nineties training program.

Is that opportunity offered to some poor housewife who has been picked up for the petty thieving of a $3.50 lipstick when she goes to court? Sometimes the magistrate takes social pressures into consideration and dismisses the charges against these people as first offenders. But here we have officers of the Australian Taxation Office, who expect the highest standard of honesty from taxpayers, who are not willing to apply that standard to themselves. That is a total disgrace. I believe that in this case the Minister for Finance has an obligation to come clean about what has been going on, to have a thorough investigation of what happened, and to report back to Parliament on actions he has taken in relation to wrongdoers in the ATO.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day, relating to the entry into Australia of a person allegedly involved in organised crime.

speech.para:
Senator Bolkus responded today to a question from Senator Jones following revelations in recent days. The
Courier-Mail
of last weekend reported that one of the most powerful crime bosses in the world had purchased for $800,000 a unit on the Gold Coast. The person referred to was Mr Masaru Takumi, who is the second-in-charge of Japan's largest organised crime group, the Yamaguchi-Gumi. That Yakuza gang, the Yamaguchi-Gumi, is said to have 37,200 members. It rakes in more than $8 billion a year, mainly from extortion, prostitution, drugs, gambling, money laundering, protection rackets and fraud. Mr Takumi is not unknown in Australia. It is reported that he has visited Queensland five times—twice in 1987, twice in 1988 and once last year.

para.tab:
This matter was brought to the Senate initially by my colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff, Mrs Sullivan, whose electorate encompasses the Gold Coast, where the purchase took place. She asked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) a question about this on Monday of this week and made a very interesting and important speech on the matter in debate in the House of Representatives on Monday night. I refer the Senate to that important speech by Mrs Sullivan, which appears on page 477 of Monday's
Hansard
. I will not go into all the details and repeat the facts she outlined there, but she raised the question: how is it that a person such as Mr Takumi, one of the known crime bosses of the world, can apparently visit Australia at will and outlay hundreds of thousands of dollars on purchasing residential property in Australia? In the answer Senator Bolkus gave today to Senator Jones about this matter—and I thank the Minister for his answer—he raised more questions than he answered.

Senator Bolkus talked about the fact that for years now the Australian Federal Police has been monitoring the entry into Australia of organised criminals and organised crime—including from Japan but from many other countries as well. He said that the AFP has a good link and liaison with the Japanese police and that, as a result of that, in 1991 some of the members of these crime gangs were identified and deported.

In relation to the person at issue in my comments today, Mr Takumi—although my comments do have wider application—Senator Bolkus said that Mr Takumi was entering Australia on a multiple visa which had been issued before he had a criminal record. That is a very interesting point. One does not get to be No. 2 boss of pretty well the largest criminal organisation in the world overnight. Obviously that is a situation that has built up over a period of time.

I am told that until recently people in Japan who had been convicted of criminal activities and had served their term had their conviction expunged from the public record. Once they had done their time, there was no further record of it. To talk about criminal records of Japanese individuals can therefore be misleading, as Mrs Sullivan pointed out earlier in the week, because there may be information beyond that which now appears on the public record.

I hope that Minister Bolkus will give the Parliament more information about this matter because the present situation raises more questions than those he answered today. For example, what sort of multiple visa does Mr Takumi hold? Is it a tourist visa? Is it a visitors visa? Is it a business visa? If it is a business visa, given that his past activities are now known to the authorities in Australia, including the AFP, what sort of business is he carrying on? Above all else, why is it that that visa has not been cancelled, and was not cancelled when his activities and his criminal background were first discovered? That must be some time ago, given his very senior role in the crime organisation of which he is No. 2 at the moment.

There are a lot of questions in this connection regarding immigration that need to be answered in this matter. I will not go into them in any further detail at this stage. I hope the Minister will respond at an appropriate—and very early—time because it is a matter of urgency. We know now about Mr Takumi, but how many other Mr Takumis are out there doing the same thing, entering Australia seemingly at will? What is the scope now for organised crime from other countries to enter Australia seemingly unhindered?

The other issue that I find quite staggering is how a person with that record is allowed to purchase residential property in Australia when under our administration and policy all applications for the purchase of residential property are required to go to and be vetted by the Foreign Investment Review Board. What is the relationship between the AFP's knowledge of matters and criminals such as these and the Foreign Investment Review Board? What is the knowledge of the immigration department about these persons? Is there any arrangement whereby the Foreign Investment Review Board automatically checks out these people, at least in a standardised way, with our law enforcement and other agencies?

I think that most Australians would find it extraordinary to discover that it is possible for a major foreign criminal to buy property in this country seemingly with impunity. I repeat that the Australian Federal Police is well aware—and has been for some time—of Mr Takumi's background and interests. I will not take up any more of the Senate's time.

talk.start.para: —How was he allowed into Australia in the first place?

—As Senator Walters says, how is it that to date this man has been allowed to visit seemingly at will, and seemingly with impunity? What action is the Government taking to ensure that that does not happen again? What are the consequences of that for Mr Takumi's real estate purchase? The list of questions that comes to mind is endless.

para.tab: This is a very urgent matter. I am glad it has been drawn to the attention of the Senate, by both Mrs Sullivan and Senator Jones. These issues require urgent consideration and advice to the Senate as to what action will be taken to prevent this sort of thing happening—not just now in relation to Mr Takumi but in relation to all the potential organised crime elements around the world that could make Australia a very fertile place for such crime.

speech.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister and the Senate. I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone this day, relating to a High Court judgment and alleged bias against women by the judiciary.

speech.para: Senator Crowley was asked what view her Government had with respect to the outcome in Longman's case and whether her Government was happy or unhappy with the degree to which it was being followed or not followed. Ordinarily one would not expect any honourable senator in this chamber to be full bottle on every case in the community; it simply would not be possible. But that is not the situation Senator Crowley found herself in.

para.tab: As I recall, Senator Crowley first raised the matter of gender bias in the judiciary in October of last year in this place. She did so by quite specifically raising some remarks made by a South Australian Supreme Court judge, Justice Bollen. Clearly she was unhappy with those remarks, she believed that they were inappropriate and that something should be done about it. Nothing was done about it for a while. As I understand it, it was in January sometime that the Director of Public Prosecutions in South Australia referred certain matters within Justice Bollen's summing-up to the Full Court of the Supreme Court for a ruling. Justice Bollen, in effect, lost on each of those matters.

Senator Crowley then made some remarks about gender bias in the law and she has made remarks since then in this place, and on radio here, there and everywhere, before, during and after the election. So on that subject we would expect her to know something, especially since she and her Government purport to have thought about this matter seriously enough to come up with what they say is the best way of alleviating this problem.

The suggestion the Government has come up with is some funding to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration for that institute to develop some gender bias curricula and to offer courses on a voluntary basis to the judiciary. So some attention has been given to this matter. One would expect, therefore, that not only the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, who has had so much to say about this matter, but the Government—the Public Service, for example—would be familiar with what the High Court says judges can and cannot say when summing up in sexual offence matters.

This development in the law is not something new; it is not something that happened last year. Senator Crowley was not caught on the hop by something that happened in December or February and she did not know about it. This High Court case was decided in 1989. Anyone who was seriously interested in the substance of the matter—that is, gender bias reflected in judicial remarks—would have been looking at the extent to which that case was being followed or not followed.

Quite clearly, when I asked Senator Crowley about Longman's case I might as well have asked her whether she knew how to walk to the moon in a day. She did not have a clue; she did not have even the vaguest idea about the subject matter. Worse still, when a supplementary question was asked to give her a hint about the subject matter, she still did not have any idea what the High Court might or might not have said about those things.

We have a Minister coming into this place and making remarks about the adequacy or otherwise of what judges say and about what judges ought to learn and ought not learn. However, she clearly has not even bothered to make any assessment about what judges can and cannot say in these matters. She has not given the slightest bit of attention to the question of whether the High Court decision on this matter is being followed by the lower courts. My understanding is that an unfortunately large proportion of the judiciary takes no notice, or insufficient notice, of Longman's case, and that is the problem.

If it wanted to, the Government could raise this problem publicly via debates in this place. The Government could say, `The High Court says that blah, blah and blah ought to happen; clearly this is not being followed'. The Government could say that it is concerned about this matter. It could look to asking, for example, the attorneys-general of the relevant States to change the law. So it is not as if it is impossible to do anything substantive about this problem.

The Government's idea of funding the AIJA is not the only idea around in this area. I have prepared a brief for the Minister, since she clearly speaks only on her briefs. I look forward to her assessment in later ministerial life, however short that might be, on whether she wants to comment only on matters on which she is briefed or whether she will be like Senator Collins, who says that he does not need to look at his briefs, that he wants to keep his distance from them.

As Senator Crowley is not here, for the benefit of other senators who may be interested in this matter let me take up a few more minutes to outline what the High Court has said about this matter, because it is a serious problem affecting a large number of people in the community. To the extent that there is a perception of gender bias in the judiciary, it is a problem for all of us. It is something we should all be interested in and watch as the problem slowly but surely is eradicated. The High Court has said that in a number of States it used to be, and it still is in some States—

talk.start.para: —Is this your learned view?

—I would not say it is my learned view; it is my view, though. In a number of States it used to be the case, and it still is in some States, that a judge in summing up a case involving a victim of a sexual offence was required to warn the jury of the dangers of relying on the alleged victim's uncorroborated evidence. For years and years, alleged victims of sexual offences thought the need to have their evidence corroborated more than that of anyone else was a bit rough. The picture generated by this rule basically was that one could not trust women who make allegations that a sexual offence has been perpetrated against them.

para.tab: Some States have had the foresight to change the situation and say that they no longer regard victims of sexual offences as being so unreliable that a warning must be given about them. Why is a warning not given in the case of the evidence of a victim of a bank robbery, if that witness happened to be the only person behind the counter? Why is a warning not given about such evidence? Why is not a warning given about everyone else who gives uncorroborated evidence? Why are victims of sexual offences treated differently from victims who give uncorroborated evidence in other cases involving only two people?

South Australia, Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have changed that requirement, and I am grateful that they have done so. They now say that if a judge thinks it is appropriate to warn about a particular witness and the particular circumstances of a particular case, the judge is obviously free to do so. But, in effect, they have taken away the requirement to warn. So in those States judges do not have to give a warning about the need for corroboration of the evidence of alleged victims of sexual offences—and that is a good thing—but they are free to do so if they believe that that is appropriate.

The High Court had a serious look at this matter in 1989 and it said—I think this is correct, and in fact I am sure it is correct; I give that caveat for the benefit of Senator Cook, who seems doubtful that I would know anything about this matter—that in circumstances where parliament no longer considers victims of sexual offences to be so unreliable that a warning must be given about their evidence, judges can give a warning but only in respect of the particular case. So, for example, if there were an allegation that Senator Cook had perpetrated a sexual offence against someone—

talk.start.para: —Thanks very much!

—I said `if'—and I have not singled Senator Cook out for any particular reason other than that he is in my line of sight. It may be appropriate for a judge, in the circumstances, to say to the jury that, for certain reasons attached to this particular case, it may not believe the person who alleges whatever it is that Senator Cook has done. That would be okay. It would be okay for the judge to say that for certain reasons the jury may believe or disbelieve whatever Senator Cook has to say. That would relate to the particular case. What it is no longer acceptable for a judge to do is to say, `Well, of course, you have to be very careful about relying on the evidence of alleged victims of sexual offences, especially when it is uncorroborated. These charges are easy to make and difficult to prove'. That is just out. It is no longer acceptable for a judge to make those remarks, to treat victims of sexual offences as belonging to an entire class.

para.tab: I conclude by drawing attention to the remarks of Justice Deane of the High Court. When referring to the fact that it is no longer acceptable to use this `easy charge to make, difficult to prove' allegation, he said:

speech.para: The distress and even humiliation to which a complainant in a sexual case is commonly subjected seem to me to make that explanation inappropriate.

I would have thought that a government that purports to have a substantive concern about this problem would have had some idea of what Australia's High Court has had to say about it and would have had some interest in whether that case is being followed in the supreme courts and in the district courts, to the extent that they handle sexual offences. It is a disgrace that the Minister who purports to have the greatest interest in this matter has nothing to say about it. She does not know anything about it.

talk.start.para: —I want to bring to a conclusion the taking note of answers given during Question Time today. The tendency is to run Question Time again and for people to say what they meant to say in a question or to try to colour the answers given to make a political point. Therefore, I will be very brief.

para.tab: In deference to my colleague Senator Crowley, something should be said about the remarks that have just been made. We are dealing here with a sensitive and important issue in terms of Australian justice and in terms of the perception of gender bias in Australian courts. In the most recent speech we have heard on this subject, an aura of principle was used to cloak a snide political point. Senator Crowley was asked a particular narrow, technical question to which she did not respond. From that point on the issue was raised in order to get a horse laugh from the Opposition, and perhaps the wider community, at Senator Crowley's expense.

This is a serious issue and not one that we ought to be exploiting for the purposes of what gallery tittle-tattle we can generate. I remember just recently a Victorian judge said in a sexual offence trial that when women say no they often mean yes which, taken in the broader context, is approval to proceed in circumstances of sexual harassment. In a recent South Australian case, a judge opined that it was permissible to hand out a bit of rough treatment in the matrimonial arrangement between a husband and a wife. These are just a couple of notorious examples in the public debate of where the judiciary has expressed views well and truly out of step with what is reasonable, fair and objective—views that have a tone of misogynism about them and views which ought to be taken as entirely inappropriate for people on a bench making judicial judgments about human conduct on matters sexual.

Senator Crowley for her part, and this Government for its part, believe that something ought to be done about that. I would have thought that is an unexceptional and quite appropriate thing for a government to say.

talk.start.para: —But they should know what the High Court says about it.

—Indeed, Senator Vanstone has now joined us in this clamour, saying that there are other things and other authorities that we should take note of in doing something about it. The effort of the Opposition is to undermine the best intentions and good efforts of the Minster—who in this case is Senator Crowley, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women—to try to change a misogynist perception in some of the judiciary in Australia, so that women who are victims of sexual offences and have those sexual offences before the courts can be properly treated. I would have thought there would be unity in this chamber in helping Senator Crowley to achieve that instead of trying to undermine her efforts by, at her expense, making a simple, narrow, technical foray in order to get a horse laugh.

para.tab: Nothing in politics surprises me any more—I have seen it all and I guess I will see it all again—but it is a pity that human spirit in this chamber has not risen to a higher level than it has done on this occasion. It is sad, but I guess that is life. Meanwhile, the Government will press on and see what it can do about ensuring that we have a much more enlightened judiciary, and one that can approach sexual offences from the point of view of all parties and from a reasonable point of view from which it treats the rights of women on those occasions properly.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, under standing order 191, I seek leave to make an explanation of my remarks on the basis that Senator Cook has misunderstood what I have said. I will not be long.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)
—Senator Vanstone, are you claiming to have been misrepresented?

talk.start.para: —I do not want to make a personal explanation; I want to use standing order 191.
—We will accept a personal explanation.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)
—Senator Vanstone, you can explain where you have been misrepresented without leave.

talk.start.para: —That is exactly what I want to do. Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. The extent to which I believe I have been misrepresented by Senator Cook is that he has purported to say to the chamber that my remarks today are such as to undermine any bipartisan effort and to undermine Senator Crowley. That is not the purpose of the remarks, and I think it misrepresents me to say that my remarks are in that context. I will not go into the substance of the matter again, but my remarks were nothing other than in the sense of an opposition's responsibility to highlight that which the Executive is and is not doing well.

para.tab: In this matter, as Senator Cook pointed out following what I said, there are a number of ways to look at the problem of gender bias in the judiciary. I simply wanted to make the point that the Government seems to be making a lot of noise about one way and, when put to a simple test as to whether it has any understanding about the other ways in which this could be done, it failed. That has nothing at all to do with whether we all agree that something ought to be done. It was simply a test as to the Government's competence, which the Minister failed.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak only for a brief moment on this motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Crowley. I do not want to undermine in any sense the gravity of the issue which has been raised by Senator Vanstone. Indeed, following Justice Bollen's remarks in the South Australian court, one of my South Australian colleagues, Ms Sandra Kanck, collected many thousands of signatures on a petition which, incidentally, I understand the Government of South Australia refused to accept on a very narrow technicality.

para.tab: I want to raise one slight technical point, because I am sure this debate will arise again, and that is the use of the word `sex' and the use of the word `gender'. I looked at these words in the dictionary and found that gender is appropriately applied to words. It is not well developed in English, but in German `der, die, das' is gender. I would be showing gender bias, for instance, if I described Senator Vanstone as `der frau' rather than `die frau'. Gender is not appropriately applied to Senator Vanstone as a woman; she is of the female sex, not of the female gender. I just wonder, if that dictionary definition is correct, whether we might use the words `sexual bias' rather than `gender bias'.

speech.para: In this report the Higher Education Council looks at the funding principles for the 1993-95 triennium and the funds allocated to higher education institutions. Before I comment on this document, I want to point out to the Senate the disgraceful situation we have today where, under government documents, we have 10 documents on education presented in one day. We have 30 minutes to discuss these documents. If I wanted to speak on each of those education documents, it would take me 50 minutes, and there are only 30. That would not provide any time for anyone to speak on this or any other matter.

para.tab: It is very timely, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are in the chair in your other role, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I think this matter should be referred to that committee. We should be asking NBEET why it needs to present 10 documents on one day. My feeling is that what it is doing—

talk.start.para: —If you actually got on with it and spoke to the document you would not be wasting time, as you are now.

—This situation comes about time and time again. I think it is worthwhile drawing it to the attention of the committee. We have already had today examples of the Government trying to restrict the powers of the Senate by a number of changes it is proposing to the Standing Orders and procedures of this Senate to allow less scrutiny. We had the case last night of Minister Collins making a joke of the procedures of estimates. He not only did not allow the questions through to the department; he also took the questions and then refused to answer them for three hours, claiming that there was another committee looking into it. That really took away our time and our role of scrutiny. It brings the work of this Parliament into disrepute if this sort of thing continues to happen. This again is another example—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. My point of order is quite simple. This is not the matter before the Chair, and Senator Tierney protesting about the proceedings, which are well established and which have been going on for the 10 years I have been in this place, in order to prevent himself from speaking to the merit of the subject, is a funny way of criticising the Government. I accept that that is the way Senator Tierney has chosen, but he is not relevant, and he should be made relevant, to the issues before the chamber.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)
—There is no point of order, but I will ask Senator Tierney to move to the point which relates to the noting of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training report.

talk.start.para: —I was about to move on to the substance of the report before the interjection from the Minister. I was responding to the interjection of the Minister. I would also like to point out to him that these procedures have not been going on for 10 years. We were proposing to change the Standing Orders this morning. That is not 10 years. What Senator Collins did last night was unprecedented in this Parliament. That has not been going on for 10 years, either. Some of these practices should be put a stop to. This is another such practice.
—You have got to actually speak to the paper.

—Let me speak to the paper. The Minister is anxious for me to draw out a number of points that have been made by NBEET. The Higher Education Council has pointed out that the channels by which students may enter higher education are changing rapidly. In particular, credit transfer arrangements are being improved. However, it is pointless for institutions to develop extensive transfer arrangements only to find that there are not sufficient places because of overcrowding. The Prime Minister's engineered recession has forced the higher education sector to hide more than 30 per cent of the unemployed youth in our higher education institutions. This is making entry to universities through other methods, such as credit transfer, very difficult. The report points out that there has been a shift from undergraduate to postgraduate studies. This is causing concern because of the reduction in opportunities for school leavers and other commencing students.

The Government is, therefore, proposing that the open learning program can be provided at a cost per student equivalent to the HECS charges. This is clearly absurd, and it is an issue which the Government urgently needs to address. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

debate.sub1.title: National Board of Employment, Education and Training--Australian Research Council Evaluation Program

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of document.

speech.para: The report by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on the Australian Research Council's evaluation program in relation to grants for ecological research is an important one because increasingly people are recognising the importance of ecological research if we are really going to be effective in moving towards a pattern of ecologically sustainable development. The report notes that Australian ecologists are at the centre stage of world research and that in this country's universities we have many people of very high repute doing absolutely excellent work.

para.tab: However, the level of support which is given to those people and, indeed, to much scientific research in Australia is totally inadequate. The report notes that only 20 per cent of applicants for ARC grants were successful and some 80 per cent of grant applicants failed to get grants. While some of those grant applications may have been of poor quality, undoubtedly among that 80 per cent would have been many applicants of quite high quality who would have failed to get a grant because the amount of government support is totally inadequate. Indeed, under `Principal Findings', the committee also reports that its members were puzzled by apparently arbitrary and sizeable cuts in seemingly reasonable requests. It may well be that in many of those requests the arbitrary cuts meant that the work was inadequately performed.

The report also says that, by comparison with equivalent Canadian, British and American funding bodies, the ARC funding for top ecological research would have to be regarded as niggardly. So while Australia, at least in terms of rhetoric, has taken some lead in relation to ecologically sustainable development, the research which is necessary to underpin that move and which will have to be extended over the next several decades is, according to this report, niggardly.

The report also goes on to note that the great majority of successful applicants expressed dissatisfaction with the level of funding. So while the work which was being done within that 20 per cent was of high quality, nonetheless those people felt constrained by the shortage of funds. They also felt very constrained by the need to supplement their niggardly funds from government sources with additional funds from private sources. This bears on a matter which I raised with Senator Button some time ago by way of a question in relation to the requirement for CSIRO to obtain 30 per cent of its funds from private sources. Senators may recall that the substance of my question was how much time was spent by researchers applying for, and writing reports in relation to, grants.

Senator Button pointed out that some 20 to 25 per cent of scientists' time was now being spent on applying for and reporting back to grantors on grants. In his answer to my question he said that he thought that was a good thing because it helped to set the direction of the research. While that may be true—it may be advantageous with respect to some research in the narrow industrial area—I believe that in the ecological area it is extremely dangerous because much of what ecologists will be researching is likely to be seen initially as inimical to the interests of industry. Under these circumstances they will find it even harder to get money from private sources. Indeed, that is referred to in this report. Given that circumstance, the type of research which they can take on board, the more fundamental type of research, the research which perhaps is going to be critical of some aspects of industry, is not likely to attract funding. The work of ecologists will be even further inhibited.

That matter was raised yesterday by Professor Ian Lowe in a lecture at CSIRO. I believe there is a great deal of concern throughout the scientific community about the direction which this Government has taken with respect to that requirement for private funding for ecological research as well as research of a more general nature.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

para.tab:
On 19 January 1993, Mr Richard Lippiatt wrote to the Committee of Privileges enclosing a final submission under resolution 5 of the privilege resolutions of 25 February 1988 which refers to remarks made by Senator Bell in the Senate during the adjournment debates on 3 June and 13 October 1992. Mr Lippiatt had initially written to the committee concerning remarks made on 3 June and, with the concurrence of the President of the Senate, the committee decided to treat that correspondence as a submission under resolution 5, and agreed to consider it. Having had further correspondence and consultation with Mr Lippiatt, the committee recommends that a response agreed to by Mr Lippiatt and the committee be incorporated in
Hansard
.

In the present case, Mr Lippiatt was inhibited in the matters to which he could appropriately refer because of considerations of the privacy of the other person involved, and his response reflects these inhibitions. The committee's observations on the question of secrecy and privacy provisions are included in the report to which the response is an appendix.
I commend the report and the recommendation to the Senate.

speech.para: RESPONSE BY MR RICHARD LIPPIATT AGREED TO BY MR LIPPIATT AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(B) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988
