talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That Standing Order 25 be amended as follows:

para.tab: Paragraph (2), omit the following:

speech.para: "(e)The Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade;
(f)The Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology;
(g)The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs;
(i)The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.
After paragraph 2(d), insert the following:
"(e)The Standing Committee on Industrial Development;
(f)The Standing Committee on Legal, Constitutional and External Affairs;

This proposal relates to reducing the number of standing committees from nine to seven. I am going to be absolutely honest—and I think many senators know that this is the situation—and lay the politics out before them. This proposal was not the Government's preferred option in relation to the standing committees. The Opposition and the Democrats know that at one stage we tried hard to see whether the existing Standing Orders, which have six senators serving on each legislative and general purpose standing committee, could operate for this Parliament.

para.tab: After considerable negotiation on this issue, it became clear that the Australian Democrats were keen to protect the position that had been enshrined over recent years in relation to their serving on these standing committees. After discussion, in order to achieve a similar result, the Government amended that original proposition and is now moving to reduce the number of committees.

Also, as we will debate at a later stage, we are very serious about trying to ensure that the workload across the committees is even. I think that is very important. Many senators know that one or two of these standing committees have really borne the brunt of the committee stage work of the Senate and a number of others have not had anything like that overwhelming workload. It is worth while seeing whether we can balance the workload and have a more equitable spread of work across the committees.

It is important to outline briefly the Government's view on the issue of Chairs of these committees because I understand that Senator Hill will be moving an amendment at a later stage to see the Chairs of the committees shared between the Government, the Opposition and the minor parties and Independent senators who are represented in the chamber.

I believe it is worth recalling the way in which these committees have operated in the past. I think the nature of the committee system and the way it has evolved certainly does reinforce the need for the Government to have the capacity to nominate a Chair for these committees, given the important role the Chairs play. Certainly, having a government Chair on legislative and general purpose standing committees has been accepted as a longstanding convention. Even Odgers, on page 468 of the fifth edition, indicates without any equivocation at all that this is certainly the case. Odgers states:

speech.para: The Senate's committee system is possibly unique in that the party composition of standing and select committees does not necessarily reflect voting strength in the Senate. It is a long-standing convention that the Government provides the chairmen of committees and enjoys a majority of votes in committees, even if the Government may be in a minority on the floor of the Senate.
The convention probably grew out of the early concept that is still valid today—that committees are fact-finding and advisory and do not aspire to decision-making.
It goes on:
As a result, committees have been remarkably non-partisan in their activities.

I do not know whether the latter part of that quote from Odgers is true, but I thought that if I did not provide a fulsome quotation from Odgers I would hear any number of Opposition senators giving me one later in this debate. I think that is indicative of the principle that has been established for a long time—the convention that has worked in this chamber for a long time—and it is one that it is essential to retain. I personally believe that this suggestion from the Opposition is tantamount to its accepting that it is going to be a permanent opposition in this chamber. No fair dinkum alternative government would want to see the Government lose the chairmanship of committees.

para.tab: I have also been honest previously in saying quite clearly that the Government has difficulty in staffing the committees because of the number of frontbenchers that we have. We have 10 Ministers and a Parliamentary Secretary in this chamber. We all know how the mathematics add up. Most of us who can do simple arithmetic—I would not put Senator Walters in that category—understand that. It may as well be on the table that it is a difficulty for Government backbench senators to cover the committee workload—and it is enormous. The Opposition has an advantage in that any number of frontbenchers and all the shadow Parliamentary Secretaries, which I think amount to five or six, can serve on these committees. That is not a luxury the Government has and it causes, obviously, very significant logistical difficulties for us as we look to staff these committees.

It is important for honourable senators to recognise the legislative role that these committees now have in terms of the committee stage of Bills. It is important for the Senate to recognise that the Government was re-elected with an increased majority at the last election, and I think in all conscience the Opposition ought to be taking into account the resources the Government has lost in terms of staffing these committees, simply because we won the last election.

There has been a genuine attempt on the part of the Government to come to a conclusion on this issue that will see these committees work effectively in the next Parliament. We are committed as a government to ensuring that the committees do work effectively and we believe that the only way that can occur is for the number of committees to be reduced so that the remaining committees get an absolutely full commitment from all senators. That is the intention of this motion, and I believe it will work well.

One of the committees the Government proposes to have omitted from the Standing Orders and hence, in effect, abolished, is the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I make the point that that committee was chosen because of the role of the joint committee, which I think most senators and members, both Opposition and Government, would accept plays a very important role in this Parliament and does contribute to the standing of this Parliament.

The other changes that have been made along with that I believe will add to this chamber's capacity to work effectively and to see our committee system work with maximum attention. Those changes will enable honourable senators to give full commitment to their committee work. I believe that this is yet another reform the Government is proposing which will assist the Senate itself and individual senators to give attention to their important work.

talk.start.para: —It seems to me that there are three separate issues in this debate. The first is that the Government is seeking—and apparently in so doing has the agreement of the Australian Democrats—to abolish two of the standing committees of the Australian Senate. Basically, the Government is seeking to abolish both the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

para.tab: It seems that the Government is seeking to abolish these committees simply because of its low numbers in this chamber after the last election. No case has been made out on the merits for abolition of the committees. It is simply a matter of fact that, now that the Government has fewer members and more Ministers in this chamber, it has decided that its backbench cannot adequately service the current committee structure of the Senate.

The abolition of these committees is convenient for the Australian Democrats because they do not have enough senators to service all legislative and general purposes committees unless some of them service more than one. So when the Government went to the Australian Democrats and said, `We propose to cut back the existing Senate committees', that was received positively by the Australian Democrats because it suits their low numbers in this chamber.

The sad aspect of this is that these committees are not committees of the Government; they are committees of the Senate, and their record has been good. I want to speak briefly on the one I know best, and that is the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Although I have never been a member of the Senate committee, I am well acquainted with its high public standing. I think some of my colleagues who have served on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure will express their concerns about the abolition of that particular committee.

The Senate foreign affairs committee in fact received its first reference in 1971, so it has existed for over 20 years. As I have said, it is held in high regard by practitioners in foreign affairs in this country and it is also well known internationally. In my observation, certainly some of the work it has done in recent years has been up with the best it has produced in that long period—work which, I am prepared to acknowledge, has been done largely under the chairmanship of Senator Maguire, whom I hope will later enter this debate and put his view about the abolition of a committee he has so well chaired in recent times.

talk.start.para: —He was a good deputy chairman.

—As my colleague Senator Teague reminds me, the stimulation he has added to work on particular inquiries has not only enhanced his reputation in the foreign affairs area but also added to the high esteem of the Senate foreign affairs committee.

para.tab: When I think of the work that committee did, for example, in its inquiry into Australian-Indian relations—which is the only contemporary work that has been done by this Parliament on what is now an important relationship but will be a much more important relationship in the future—my view is that if that work had not been done by the foreign affairs committee, it would not have been done at all. That inquiry explored the potential for the relationship, the economic potential, and how the Australian foreign aid component in south Asia and India in particular might develop. It also looked at the defence aspects of the relationship, which have been of some concern to many Australians, and to some extent it put to rest some of those concerns, which were not well-founded in fact.

In other words, that particular inquiry performed a public service of providing information, ensuring that the debate within this country was better informed; and it also made very worthwhile recommendations to the Government, many of which have been picked up. Senator Teague might like to deal with some of those in greater detail, but I recall that the recommendation in relation to an Australian-Indian institute was accepted by the Government and has been implemented.

I think also of the inquiry the committee undertook into Australian-Latin American relations, which was the first inquiry of that type by the Australian Parliament. It explored the potential for growing relationships between Australia and the various Latin American states. When that report was brought down, all the heads of mission from Latin American states based in Canberra attended in this chamber. They gave high commendation to the work and the detail that had been put into the report by the Senate committee, particularly the work on the potential of the economic relationship, which has been largely unknown within Australia. Of course, that report was largely endorsed by the Australian Government in due course.

One could spend time—which I will not do—in going through a whole series of other important inquiries that have been undertaken by that particular Senate committee that have brought credit not only to itself but to this Parliament and that have made a very useful contribution to the foreign affairs debate within Australia. Just because the Australian Labor Party in the Senate has lost a couple of seats while at the same time increasing its frontbench representation, it now wishes to abolish that committee after more than 20 years of work. As no better reason has been given, I think that is a sad state of affairs.

I am really astonished that the Australian Democrats are so ready to be a party to the abolition of a Senate standing committee that has so well served Australian interests for so long. I understand the problem that faces the Australian Democrats in servicing all these committees. I have even suggested to them that if, say, Senator Bourne, who has an interest in foreign affairs and who might participate in particular inquiries, such as the inquiry on Australia-China relations, were to find that because of the pressure of her other work she was unable to participate in other inquiries of less interest to her, it would not be unreasonable that we should find a way of accommodating that difficulty on the part of the Democrats. That would be a much better solution to the problem we have before us today than simply abolishing the committee, which is the solution the Government put to the Australian Democrats and which, as I have said and as I understand it, they have so readily accepted.

The case has not been made out for abolition of these two committees. It is said by some that perhaps the foreign affairs work could be picked up by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. That is not possible. That committee is fully engaged with its own workload and, interestingly, there has not been duplication. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that the joint committee has expanded its role in recent years; it now has a subcommittee dealing with human rights, for example. There is no way that it would be able to pick up the work that has been done in recent years by the Senate foreign affairs committee.

Therefore, as I said a moment ago, if the Senate committee had not existed, the work would not have been done and the particular benefit to Australia from that work, which has been acknowledged time and time again by the Government, would not have been gained. I do not often reflect on Senator Gareth Evans's own book on foreign affairs, but I notice that in it he gives credit to the foreign affairs committees of this Parliament, and in particular to the Senate committee. He also might like to come in and participate in this debate and acknowledge publicly what he has previously said—that it is very worthwhile work in the Parliament's overall contribution to our international relations.

We will, therefore, oppose the abolition of these two committees. We hope that at this late stage the Australian Democrats will realise that what they intend to do is a mistake, join with us and vote down the Government's intention to abolish these committees.

The second issue that has been brought within this debate is our proposed reform that the chairmen of general purpose standing committees be shared around the chamber. It is true, as Senator Faulkner has said, that the practice in the past—and it is incorporated within the Standing Orders—has been that the government of the day chairs these committees. One suspects that it ended up in the Standing Orders in that form because it was assumed that the government of the day would have the majority in this place.

But I repeat what I said a moment ago: these committees are not committees of the government; they are committees of the Senate, and there is no logical reason why the government should chair all of them. Work done by legislative committees is brought back into this chamber for debate in the Committee of the Whole. At one stage we followed the practice of the Opposition providing the Chairman of Committees, the Deputy President. Nobody said that that system would not work because it was an opposition chair heading up the debate. The same logic applies to the work being done by the committees when they are operating in their separate state.

What we are proposing as a matter of reform is that the Standing Orders be changed so that senators other than government senators would have the opportunity to chair some of these committees and provide the benefit of their own unique backgrounds and experiences. In doing so, we are not in any way being pessimistic about our future opportunities in government. In fact, we see it as a reform of the Senate. We recognise that it would have to be a reform that was carried on if the numbers changed in the other place and we were in government. We believe that it is time that the Senate as a whole asserted itself properly in relation to the functioning of the committee process. We should not allow the government, in effect, to run the Senate's agenda in respect of this very important part of the Senate's work.

To be reasonable, we have suggested—and we did so on the basis of there being nine committees; but as I said, if the Democrats stand by what they have earlier said, we will end up with only seven—that four committees be chaired by a government senator, four be chaired by an opposition senator, the Opposition representing the largest block in this chamber, and that the ninth be chaired by a representative of the minor parties or Independents. Because of the Australian Democrat numbers, I am anticipating that the ninth one, on the current structure, would be chaired by a senator from the Australian Democrats.

So this proposition has the benefit of being fair. It has the benefit of a reform that gets away from what I think is the illogical practice, although it has long existed, that chairmen of these committees are automatically taken from the side which has the majority in the House of Representatives. I will, therefore, seek to move an amendment to bring about that reform. I hope that the Australian Democrats, who I know have been thinking about this issue for the last week and a half, might be prepared to support us on this occasion.

In the event that the committees are chopped back in the way the Government intends, we need to consider what is the best mix of departments to be serviced adequately within just seven standing committees. The Government has put forward a certain formula in its amendment. That has been given careful consideration on this side of the chamber.

Senator Panizza has circulated an amendment—it has been put to the Government and to the Australian Democrats for their consideration—which we think will provide a better mix. It has the effect of linking transport with the rural affairs committee of the Senate. We think there is some logical merit in that as it will allow better attention to be given to the transport area. It is a second-best option to the option of retaining the existing committee on transport, communications and infrastructure.

If it appears that the Government is going to be successful in cutting back the number of committees to seven, we will seek to amend the structure the Government is advocating in the form that I have just indicated which, as I said, is specifically covered by Senator Panizza's amendment. But I hope that will not be necessary. I hope that at this late stage the Australian Democrats have realised the error of unnecessarily cutting back the Senate committee system that has been built up over such a long period and that has such prestige and experienced staff. I hope that they will join us in throwing out this unnecessary change that is being suggested by the Government.

As I said, I hope that they will join us in supporting a well considered Senate reform to provide for a sharing of the responsibility of chairing these committees. I might say to the Democrat senators that this arrangement has already been incorporated within the British system. If they join with us, then Senator Panizza's amendment on restructuring will not be necessary.

talk.start.para: —Let us have a look at the situation relating to the nine Senate committees. I point out that we have had an extra committee added in the last year—the rural affairs committee. I certainly do not oppose the addition of that committee to the system. But in this instance the Government is starting from the position of having preferred three government senators and three other senators on a committee. That has not proved possible. One of the reasons it has not proved possible is that we did amend Senate procedure some time ago to refer far more Bills to these committees to be assessed on a legislative basis. So I can understand why Senator Bell and his colleagues would therefore want to participate in that process, whereas they may not normally have wanted to join some of these standing committees.

para.tab: We have a situation where on the majority of these committees the Government will be required to provide four members, the Opposition three, and the Democrats or Independents one other. From a numbers point of view, that does give the Government a difficulty. We have not tried to dodge that. I must congratulate Senator Hill on his contribution today. It was a far less cynical performance than trying to increase the number of committees, which is just an Opposition device to try to put pressure on us to supply bodies to committees. That sort of cynicism was lacking in his contribution today and I congratulate him for that.

Throughout all these debates we have heard a variety of interjections such as, `You are going to go down two seats in July. Serves you right'. I would have thought that some opposition senators on the other side would be delighted that the Senate now has 10 Ministers—that the Senate has been recognised as a chamber that can have one-third of the Federal Ministry and an almost disproportionate number of people in Cabinet.

talk.start.para: —It should be one-third.

—Whether one makes that mandatory or not, that is the existing situation. It is normal that governments—at least until today—provide the President of the Senate and sometimes his deputy. I think everybody knows what is going to happen in August in regard to that. But at a minimum we have 11 people who cannot serve on committees. Thanks to opposition intervention the other day, Senator Sherry now can serve on committees, and that is not all bad. Now that he cannot actually appear in front of estimates committees we welcome the fact that he is now able to serve on any committee.

para.tab: So we are close to a situation of having to commit to committees senators who have a much higher workload than opposition senators. That may well lead to a situation where they do not carry out their duties with due diligence or put in as much as everybody else. That is a great shame.

The only practical solution we can come up with is to reduce the committees by two. I have not read Senator Panizza's amendment, and no doubt the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (senator Faulkner) will give it due consideration. I do not think we on this side of the chamber would take a totally hardline position on the actual dividing up of which government departments go to which committee. I hope that some reasonableness appears on that level.

I return to the point about the Government having 30 senators and the Opposition having 36 in July. I took the trouble today, because I have heard all these interjections, to see what aggregate votes the various parties received in 1990 and 1993. It is quite an interesting reflection. The Liberal-National Party-CLP—I have added them all together—received 8,751,671 votes at the two elections. The Australian Labor Party received 8,454,673. In other words, the Liberal-National Party combined vote over those two elections comes to 42.5 per cent. Their Senate representation after July will be 47.4 per cent. The Labor Party's vote totalled 41 per cent combined over the two elections and we receive 39.5 per cent. The Democrats received 8.8 per cent of the vote over the two elections and get 9.2 per cent of the representation in this chamber. The Greens' aggregate vote is 2.4 per cent and they get 1.3 per cent in the chamber. Those who argue that this chamber is totally representative of votes cast and reflects those power realities are wrong.

I ask the Senate not to misunderstand me; I am not whingeing or complaining about this. The reasons are partly due to preferences, but not much. It is simply that in every Senate election there is a missing quota; that is, the total amount of votes are divided by seven and we have six successful candidates. The history of the 1990 election especially rather than this one is that the Labor Party had the missing quota. Therefore, we are substantially and proportionately under-represented in this chamber than the primary votes cast.

That could just as easily happen to the Opposition in any particular period. If one goes back through the past, I am sure it has been equally disadvantaged at some time. I put that on the record because of this sort of trite interjection: `This chamber is purely representative. You didn't get enough votes. Therefore, we don't care less that you are going to have difficulty in staffing the committees with senators'. A lot of luck is involved in this. I do not whinge and say that the system is bad, corrupt or biased. I do not say that at all. We have had the wrong end of the stick luckwise—especially in 1990—in terms of having the missing quota, as is reflected in this chamber.

Senator Hill went to the question of why the Senate foreign affairs and defence committee has gone. He should not have been surprised by that. I proposed that, but did not put it to the chamber, in 1987 and 1990. It is not as though it is a recent discovery. It was selected on the basis of looking down the list of committees to see which one has the least legislative role and which one can have its workload picked up by another committee.

Clearly, we believe that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—comprising about 30 parliamentarians and with enormous resources in terms of staff, et cetera—can adequately cover these issues. Where it cannot cover these issues, then another committee to which we move these responsibilities can take up the slack. Hence, if the Opposition insists on doing an inquiry, such as it did on India and produced an excellent report, that committee can still do it. But it also has to be said that committee members will only be able to devote probably half the time to those sorts of issues as they have in the past.

Let me move on to one of my long-term concerns. If in this chamber we continue to increase committees and their workload, we are going to move to the American system, which I abhor; that is, having 90 per cent of the work on committees done by staff and not by senators themselves. I have noticed a tendency over the last 11 years for that to increase. More and more reports are written by secretariats, rubber-stamped or altered slightly by chairmen, and then rubber-stamped by the committee members. Members do not have either the resources or the time, if their efforts are spread out over a number of committees, to go ahead and properly supervise the eventual report or adequately prepare questions to witnesses. I think this process of reducing committees by two will slightly help to stem that process.

Senator Hill said that when these committees were set up it was always assumed that the Government would have a majority. No-one here, other than maybe Senator Durack, could even comment on that. They were set up in 1971 precisely because the Government did not have a majority. The DLP, for once in its life, voted to reform the system and voted with the Labor Party. The basic point made by Senator Hill as to whether it was always assumed that government should chair these committees was based on the fact that the Government did not have a majority in the chamber. That was one of the checks and balances put in at the time when the rest of the powers of the committee were put in.

These committees have immense power and give the Opposition immense opportunities. The Senate in its wisdom in 1971 said, `How can we slightly counterbalance a disproportionate amount of influence and opportunity of the Opposition and not the Government?'. We agreed at the time that the Liberal coalition could provide the chairs of all these committees, the Estimates committees, et cetera. Now we hear some sweet and honeyed words about power sharing. Where was the power sharing in the day of the McMahon Government when the committees were set up?

There are two senators in the chamber who were here prior to 1980, during the Fraser Government. When did they bob up and say, `Look, Labor Party, we have just kicked you to pieces in an election. However, we want to get into power sharing. We want to give you committee chairmanships'. People tend to forget the pretty tough show that the Fraser Government ran in this chamber.

I hope Senator Teague has not forgotten the time when he went to an education and training meeting, slamming through a motion three all, and then using his casting vote to roll me. He should remember that very well. I admired him for it, frankly, even though I whinged at the time. We had a disagreement over a reference. Suddenly we fronted up at the committee; and bang, in came the numbers which made it three all, casting vote—`See you later Robert, you are wrong'. I just slotted that away in my memory and said, `We'll get our chance one day. We'll do almost the same thing', although it is not a preferable course on which to go.

talk.start.para: —And it was an unusual course then.

—It was a very unusual course. However, I might add for history that Senator Teague made a mistake in speaking on it in this chamber. It went to the bottom of the
Notice Paper
and then we negotiated it out. So we got square pretty quickly.
—Also you won the 1983 election and that was the end of it anyway.
—Senator Teague reminds me that we won the 1983 election.
—And the 1984 and the 1987 and 1990.

—And 1993, I thank Senator West. One might have to look beyond some of the reasons advanced so far on the record for taking committee chairmanship. One might think that Senator Faulkner's cynicism in suggesting that the reason why this proposition has come up now is that opposition senators want their turn in chairing a committee, which they have not had for the last 10 years and will not have for the next three years. There are greater cynics who say, `They are just trying to put their snouts in the trough to get the committee chairmanship'. I would be much more impressed if I heard from the opposition side now that this is really about power sharing and Senate symbolism and that they will not take any of the emoluments that go with chairs of committees. No, we do not have a volunteer for that at the moment.
—None of us here is in a position to be on those committees.
—I see, not one of those opposite can be on the committees. They will rush down here in a moment and all volunteer to give up the emoluments.
—They will come down.
—We will keep Senator Patterson to that promise, and I thank her for it.
—I have not promised. I have said they are not here to answer.

—Surely Senator Patterson, as a member of the Liberal Party, which believes in vanguardism and in leadership, could show some leadership on this question and her colleagues would naturally follow her. But, of course, no. We are a bit cynical as to why suddenly the coalition would want to be into power sharing to disrupt what was an original agreement in 1971, when in fact they control four State parliaments around this country. How much power sharing is done there? How often in Western Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales do opposition members chair committees in the Parliament? The answer is, absolutely never. I think this is just a big try-on.

para.tab: I will not waste too much time of the Senate. In summary, I make the point that the Government has come forward with this proposal to meet changed circumstances. The change is that, inevitably, most of these committees will now constitute eight senators rather than six. It means that if those opposite want a meaningful contribution from government senators and want to force them onto these committees—that is, to serve on two or three—they will not get the output from them.

Our response to that is that we will take two of the committees and merge them with other committees, which will still give the opportunity to the Democrats to exercise their rights, will still give the opportunity to all senators to pursue inquiries on these committees, and finally will enable them to activate senators actually to write the reports and deliver them themselves, rather than the secretariat doing it.

In relation to the chairmanship issue that Senator Hill raised, we remain a little cynical about this sudden surge of power sharing. We have heard nothing about it in the last 10 years. This sort of motion should always be debated three months before an election. When senators want to substantially change the Senate and the relativities between the Opposition and Government, three months before an election is the time to do it. Everyone has an eye on the weather then. We may think we are going to lose and think that power sharing is a good idea. Those on the other side can be held to it, because if they think they can win government they should not mind power sharing down. It is a rather cynical move to introduce this proposal when those opposite face three years, six years or whatever in the wilderness. I suggest that Senator Hill introduce that amendment in two years and eight months time. We can all have an objective look at it then, none of us knowing what the future holds.

On the question of the allocation of departments to committees, I still say that that is fairly negotiable around the traps, even if it is not settled here today. Readjustments can be made down the track. If we find that the current load is unbalanced or that the Opposition absolutely insists that one area move to another, we would not be blind to those particular recommendations. I recommend that the Senate support Senator Faulkner's proposal.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I have listened carefully to the arguments put forward by Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray for the Government's proposal, which I can interpret only as destroying the excellent record of the Senate committee system and, in particular, the committee I will address most, that is, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I will leave it to my colleague Senator Panizza to put his own experience and protest with regard to the Government's proposal to abolish the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

para.tab: All of the coalition members disagree that there be any reduction in the standing committees of this Senate. I support fully all that my colleague Senator Hill has said on this matter and I put as a last plea to Senator Bell from the Australian Democrats, who is in the chamber, and any other senators from the Democrats who are listening that we retain the structure of Senate committees, which has served this nation and the Parliament well over the last 22 years. I put the particular plea that this not be a swan song for an excellent committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, but rather a convincing speech for evaluating its record, seeing it to be excellent, and making sure that we do not lose the momentum and the established credibility we have in that committee, along with the others.

It has been mentioned already that standing order 25 outlines that at the beginning of each parliament there shall be nine standing committees of the Senate—legislative and general purpose committees—defined with much the same powers that have existed and have been to the greater effectiveness of the Senate over the last 22 years. The proposal before us is that standing order 25 be amended to remove four of the committees and to see an amalgamation such that there be two newly defined committees and that the total, instead of being nine, becomes seven.

The proposal is that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade be amalgamated with the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In my 15 years in the Senate I have regarded these two committees as the most achieving of the Senate standing committees. I do not wish to denigrate the excellent record of the others, but I draw to the attention of the Senate the work that has been undertaken by these two standing committees in the last Parliament. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
the references to these two committees, which appear on pages 73 to 76 of the
Notice Paper
for the last sitting day of the last Parliament.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The incorporated material shows that, starting with the legal and constitutional affairs committee, which had a membership of eight senators, there were 16 inquiries on which reports have been presented, and there are five current inquiries on a wide range of subjects. When I turn to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I see also a long list of very substantial national inquiries that have been undertaken. I have with me a pile of reports from the last parliament, and I am proud to have been associated with the work of the Senate committee in the establishment of these reports.

para.tab: Let me note what is now an international authority on the visit to any nation by nuclear-powered or armed vessels and the safeguards required. At the time this was a hot political issue in this country and many in the public regarded it as a genuine danger to civilians in port cities, and, more widely than that, that there were visits to our ports by nuclear-powered or armed vessels. This measure has taken all of the fire out of those concerns. There were some 50 recommendations which made sure that all of the arrangements were in good order. There was a change whereby some ships would not come to the Victoria Docks adjacent to the city of Hobart. All of the politics has gone from that issue.

Let me talk about the report Senator Hill has referred to, that is, the Senate committee's report on Australia-India relations. It addressed both strategic assessments of India in the subcontinent and trade prospects between Australia and India. When there was a major mistake made by the present Government in the sale of redundant aircraft to Pakistan—a mistake which is greatly regretted, I believe, even by the Ministers responsible—this report was at hand and was a fallback to repair and rebuild the damaged relations between Australia and India. The recommendation in this report that there should be an Australia-India council has been accepted. The essential text for the politics of the relationship between Australia and India—if one asks any of the academics and any of the business people involved in Australia-India matters—is this Senate report.

I refer to another useful report from the last Parliament—an evaluation of perestroika, or the Gorbachev policies with regard to Russia. A great deal has happened since then. This is still a relevant report because it called for a refreshing look at Australia's opportunities with regard to the emerging new states that had formerly made up the Soviet Union.

None of these reports of the Senate committee has been duplicated by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Another area of very real concern both to our foreign affairs interests in this country and to defence has been our increased involvement in United Nations peacekeeping. It was very appropriate that there be a careful study by politicians of United Nations peacekeeping in Australia. The more than 20 deployments of Australian service personnel and police to peacekeeping needs around the world and a whole body of recommendations to improve our decisions with regard to such deployments are carefully catalogued in this evaluation.

This is directly relevant to the major peacekeeping force serving in Cambodia, to the peacekeeping force now in Somalia and to others that were in the western Sahara, Lebanon and Cyprus and so I could go on. This report is most relevant and the Government's response to it is that it is instructive and, largely, that it will implement it. It is not duplicative of anything that has been done by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade or any other committee.

I turn to the major report brought down during the last Parliament, a report on Australia and Latin America, which I regard as one of the most significant, most constructive reports for Australia coming out of the 50 or so inquiries in which I have been involved in the past 15 years. I am very proud to have been associated with this report, as is Senator West who is in the chamber and, indeed, all eight of the senators who served in its determination. The President of the Senate has been glowing in his tribute to this report. He represented this Parliament last year on a visit to Colombia and found that everybody concerned with foreign affairs and trade matters he spoke to was aware of the Senate committee's report relating to all of the republics of Central and South America.

Senator Hill has referred to the enormous interest shown in this issue by the eight ambassadors in this city who represent Latin American countries and who have appeared as witnesses before our inquiry. They have followed it most carefully. Last Wednesday night, they very admirably held a dinner in honour of the chairman of the committee, Senator Maguire, as he will be retiring from the Parliament next month. They said, through the spokesmen that evening—the Ambassador of Chile, the Ambassador Colombia and our good friends—that the dinner was held in honour of the whole committee, and Senator Maguire took it in that way.

At a meeting of the Magellan Society at the Australian National University in three weeks' time there will be a complete follow-up of the implementation of this report. The Government has been so diligent in taking up the work of the committee that its response to this report has been published in booklet form. More than that, the committee has initiated a proposal—and the Parliament has agreed—whereby the seminal elements of our report on Latin America and the Government's response be bound together and published in Spanish and circulated in the countries of Latin America.

Not only will it be circulated through our ambassadors in that country but also through the efforts of the national governments in each place. It will be circulated not only to business but also to academia, to anyone involved in trade or anything to do with the relations between our countries—transport, airways and so on. The findings in the report indicate the prospect of Australian trade in the region increasing from the current level of one per cent to three per cent or even more. We should not be neglecting any one part of the world.

I repeat that I am thoroughly proud of this report. If, for the temporary convenience of some members of the Senate, we were to abandon the 22 years of achievement of such an important standing committee of this Parliament, we would be doing a great disservice to the Parliament and to Australia. I can only make the plea that Government and Democrat senators look beyond the convenience of their own arrangements in the next three years, actually concentrate upon the track record of excellence that has been achieved in this Parliament through such committees, and not abandon these achievements.

I draw to the attention of the Senate some of the supplementary papers that were generated by the Senate with regard to the Latin America inquiry. I know that these are now essential texts, not only in Australia, but also in the foreign capitals of the countries of Latin America. Let me give one example.

We had a full day's seminar at the department of Spanish studies at Flinders University which was opened by my good friend, John Lovering, the Vice Chancellor of the university. A State Minister spoke at the seminar in glowing terms about the initiative taken by the Senate in this report. Senator Maguire, Senator Crowley—who recently returned from leading a delegation representing the Parliament—and I also spoke at that seminar. We were seen to be senators making a relevant, practical and constructive contribution not only to the Parliament but also to the practical agenda of universities such as Flinders University. That is only one example.

While I am concentrating on Latin America, let me say that the members of the diplomatic corps in this city, some 80 ambassadors—at least all those who have heard of this possible move in the Senate—are lamenting that this move will be a huge loss to Australia's ability to build links with the nations of the world, especially those nations with which we have a direct trading, defence or other substantial relationship. I think of the ASEAN representatives in this city, the Latin Americans, the Americans, the Europeans; I could go through the whole diplomatic corps in this city. They know the value of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

I might be interpreted in these remarks as singing a swan song for a marvellous committee that we are now seeing disposed of to meet the temporary convenience of some senators. I will refer in my concluding remarks to those directly practical matters.

The proposal to have only seven Senate standing committees happens to match the number of Democrat senators. There are only seven Democrats in this chamber. I note that it is difficult for Democrat senators to attend more than one committee. Senator Spindler is a member of two standing committees, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

Am I being too cynical in saying that the proposal before us amalgamates the two committees on which Senator Spindler happens to be a member? Am I being too cynical in saying that it is the view of some Democrat senators that it would be very much to their personal convenience if there were one secretary and one agenda, and they could organise their lives that little bit better, whatever the losses to the Senate as a whole? In the future, when others look at this debate, and at the downgrading of the Senate committee system, they will see it as meeting no argument on merit, only the convenience of some senators, and they will see this as a very sorry day in the Senate.

I have been able to do the arithmetic—something to which Senator Ray referred. There will be only 30 Labor senators in the chamber. Ten are Ministers. I welcome the fact that one-third of the Ministry is drawn from this chamber. It should be so. One-third of the members of Parliament are in the Senate; one-third of the Ministers of the Government ought to be from the Senate. When we take those 10 into account, plus the President of the Senate—or if there should be other than a Government President, presumably a Government chairman of committees—this leaves only 19 senators to serve on the standing committees. If there are nine standing committees and three or four are required for each—even at the most, that is 36 places to be filled—each of those 19 senators would be required to serve on two standing committees. I understand that arithmetic but I do not believe that that is an argument that ought to sway this chamber to abandon standing committees of great worth.

I note in particular the loss of the resources that the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade would suffer in being only half a committee. At the moment we have considerable expertise in our own secretariat. It is clear that that secretariat would be halved through this amalgamation and we would see the dispersal of resources which have been of great value.

More than six years ago I was, for five years, a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I valued that time. But I have always seen the Senate standing committee as complementary—doing additional work of value to what the joint committee is able to undertake. There is a convenience, a concentration and a focus which senators bring to an all-senators committee which mean that it is a very achieving committee in the way that I have outlined in the reports that I have referred to. That will be lost if we see the loss of this committee.

As Senator Ray said, this proposal was put up three years ago and six years ago. Senator Ray was the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and was aware of pressures, even in those years, on Labor senators to service committees. It was at least informally put about that there might be some reduction. One of the committees discussed was the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. However, rightly, six years ago and three years ago that discussion led to the confirmation and retention of this very achieving Senate standing committee. Even at this eleventh hour, I still hope there will be the same outcome this time.

I now refer to a transition. Despite the views of coalition senators, if the proposal before us is successful and we see a reduction from nine committees to seven, I would ask that consideration be given to ensuring that there is no lapse of the three-quarters completed current inquiry into Australia's assessment of Japan and Japan's security concerns.

On 16 September last year the Senate referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for an inquiry and report on the matter of Japan's defence policy and current defence development and debates in Japan. A number of very valuable witnesses have appeared at our public hearings, including His Excellency the Ambassador of Japan. It would be of great discourtesy, not only to the senators who have three-quarters finished that task but also to our witnesses, including the Ambassador of Japan and through him the Government of Japan, if we were to not see the completion of that reference.

We have completed our public hearings. We have already developed a draft and it would be the wish of the committee for that to be completed by the end of June this year. I put the plea that, if there is going to be a loss of a committee, there be a certainty of transition such that this current inquiry, the only major current inquiry to be completed, is completed and reported to the Senate. There are two or three ways to do this. One is through retaining the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade at least until the end of June with its current membership. Another is to have a select committee, again with the membership of the current standing committee, that would have the precise task of completing that report on the same terms of reference and building upon the transcript of evidence and material that has been available to the Committee. A third is to ensure that in any amalgamated committee it be a priority reference and that there be sufficient personnel from the former committee continuing into that amalgamated committee to ensure that it is completed by June this year.

I see Senator Cooney in the chamber. I commend, as I did at the beginning of my speech, Senator Cooney's first-class record as chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Senator Hill has served in this area in the past, as has Senator Tate, former Senator Puplick, former Senator Missen and so on. There has been an enormously high regard for that committee. Yet the proposal that is before us is to take these two most eminent standing committees and amalgamate them so that there would be half the resources and half the ability to complete the good work of both committees. Even in this transition, I would see that the concerns of such persons as my good friend across the chamber Senator Cooney in legal and constitutional matters would have difficulty competing with the completion of a report such as that which I referred to with regard to Japan.

I make the plea that there be a certain transition so that that report can be completed by the end of June. I have taken a great deal of the time of the Senate in speaking for 25 minutes. I do not make any apology. I only say with every amount of sincerity that I can muster that we should not, for the temporary convenience of some senators, abandon a 22-year record of excellence of achievement in the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. talk.start.para: —I indicated some time last week that I would answer some of the points raised by Senator Patterson in her second reading speech, which I had not at that point read. I seek to do so today and to ask Senator Patterson if, in the light of the extraordinarily reasonable proposals that I will put, she might indicate that she will withdraw.
—This'll be good.
—One lives in hope—me more than most. Given that there is quite a bit of money at stake here—
—Like the other guesstimates in social security records, it is wrong.
—We were wrong in the case of deeming because we did not estimate that we would get that much. Senator Patterson's assertions about social security records are completely untrue.
—One swallow doesn't make a summer.
—No, but we have flocks of swallows. That is the difference—flocks.
—We know what they do when there are flocks of swallows about.
—I am not sure; I am feeling flocked, but I will continue with the speech nonetheless.
—I am not having anything to do with that.

—I did not think Senator Patterson would. The general point we were making last week was that, for some time now, shares have been treated concessionally as against other forms of investments. What we were seeking to do was to fix that anomaly. The underlying principle of the income test—
—What have you been doing?

—Senator Watson should take a deep breath. I do not have long; he should at least let me get through it. The underlying principle of the income test is to assess people's current need for income support based on the current financial resources available to them. The real truth is that capital gains on listed shares are readily available. Determining whether to access the capital gain or not is entirely up to the individual. Nevertheless, the gain is available, and that is the same across a whole range of investments. That is what underpins the whole income test, which the Opposition does not even seek to overturn.

para.tab: Senator Patterson supported the fundamentals of the change when it was announced in December 1992. A Democrat amendment proposed in December similar to this current proposal was not supported by Senator Patterson at that time either. Senator Patterson has suggested that savings will not be achieved because pensioners will sell their shares and invest in other areas.

talk.start.para: —Which is what they are doing.

—I think we should examine that claim. According to social security records, I am advised that, since the Budget last year when these measures were announced, the number of pensioners holding shares has risen from 81,000 to 107,000. So the suggestion that they have been flocking to sell shares—there is that word again—does not appear to be correct because the numbers have gone up very substantially since last August.
—But there are more pensioners.

—That is one of the more ridiculous interjections. It is not as good as Senator Macdonald's `You lost two seats' today, but it is not bad. It is in the same league, but not as good. The first point to make is that some pensioners may decide to get out of shares as a result of this measure. But it is pretty well certain that those who seek to do so will reinvest the money. When they do reinvest the money, because this is an anomaly, they will be caught under the income test anyway with those new arrangements.

para.tab: I answered the ridiculous claim about investing overseas the other day. The idea that Australia's pensioner population is flocking to invest in the New York stock exchange is, to say the least, bizarre. Pensioners do not have the arrangements in place to gain the benefit of doing that, and it is just not likely to happen.

The rules that will apply to shares have applied to managed investments for five years. Over that time, 128,000 pensioners have invested in managed investments. They do that because there is intrinsic merit in the investment. They will have to weigh up the intrinsic merit of the investment in shares as against managed investments and other forms of investment. As I said, even if some do sell their shares, they are pretty likely to reinvest in ways that are covered by the income and assets test anyway.

As I mentioned, the number of people affected by the change is around 60,000, and around 24,000 DVA pensioners are also affected. So we are talking about less than three per cent of the social security pensioner population. Those affected are mainly those with large shareholdings, including some with as much as $100,000 in shares. For those who have a small number of shares, this measure has so little effect that it does not matter anyway.

It is true that the new rules do not apply to non-listed shares, real estate, art works and antiques. There are pretty good reasons for that. Shares in non-listed companies are not part of the measure because they are not readily realisable in the way that shares in listed companies are. Therefore, capital growth cannot be readily utilised for income support purposes as it can be with shares in listed companies.

Real estate, antiques and art works are not part of the measure because the whole investment must be sold in order to gain access to the capital gain, whereas listed shares can be sold in small lots to realise gains as people consider them necessary to be realised. A pensioner does not need to sell the whole portfolio to access profits. If I were an antique dealer, I would not really believe that 100,000 pensioners would be marching down the street beating a path to my door this afternoon to invest in antiques. It simply is not going to happen. The truth is that pensioners may seek investments other than shares as a result of this measure—although I still think many will stay with what they have—but they will not be racing off to invest in antiques.

I think the other point we have to cover concerns comparisons between definitions in the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office. There is no sound reason why those two organisations should use the same method of assessing income. The social security income test serves a totally different purpose from the tax office assessment of income and it always has. Social security legislation provides a level of income support based on people's current needs and their current ability to meet the needs. The Australian Taxation Office assesses a person's income over the course of a full year to determine what he or she can contribute to the revenue of the community. So to suggest that social security income tests should mirror the tax definition of income ignores the intrinsic differences in the way the two organisations go about their tasks.

The criticism that the changes do not allow losses to be fully offset against gains is flawed, because if one says that, one does not understand the current nature of a social security income assessment. It presumes that past dollar losses should be offset against past dollar gains, but the income test seeks to establish the current earning capacity of a particular investment and the corresponding financial resources available to individual pensioners. This method of assessing current earning power has been in operation for many years, and it has been endorsed by the High Court of Australia as an appropriate way to administer the income test.

The assertion that identical managed and unmanaged investments will be assessed differently under the new rules is incorrect. Such anomalies are possible under the current rules. Currently, a pensioner who invests directly in the share market is assessed differently from a pensioner who invests indirectly in the share market through an equity trust. That is the kind of anomaly that the legislation seeks to correct. The change will remove the anomalies in assessment and ensure a fairer and more workable treatment of investments.

The claim that the Department of Social Security will apply arbitrary assessment dates is patently untrue. All clients will have their share portfolios assessed on the same day, using the same source information, when the change is introduced in September. The department will obtain updated information on share market performance every fortnight. Clients can seek individual reassessments of their share portfolios based on this information if they feel the need. Consistency of assessment will be maintained by automatic quarterly reassessments which will occur, again, using identical share market information for all clients.

The suggestion that pensioners investing in listed shares are disadvantaged compared to those who invest in non-listed shares shows little understanding of the difference between listed and unlisted companies. Obviously, this question of what one can realise and realise quickly—

talk.start.para: —We know that.
—If Senator Watson had realised it, he would not assume that realising shares in non-listed companies is the same as in listed companies.
—That's not the point.
—It is the point, Senator Watson has just not realised it.
—You are treating people differently.

—But we are treating people differently now. As I outlined a second ago, the problem is that if one invests in an equity trust which invests indirectly in shares, one is treated differently from someone who invests directly in shares. That is clearly an anomaly which we ought to fix. Otherwise, we go in the reverse direction. If Senator Watson is suggesting that we go in the reverse direction in order to eliminate the income test, he is swimming against the tide of his own party. Senator Watson has shown an occasional capacity to almost want to do that but he never quite maintains the courage to go the full step.
—Don't put incorrect words in my mouth.
—But Senator Watson's utterance of incorrect words is my problem, and not for the first time.
—Two wrongs do not make a right.
—Senator Watson, I suggest you wait till you receive the call.

—Pensioners are not going to gain benefit by moving capital out of Australia and investing in overseas shares, as has been suggested. I do not think that we really ought to worry about that because the changes apply equally to shares whether they are here or whether they are held overseas.
—They will put it in real estate.
—They will not be putting it in real estate.
—Where else will they put it then?

—There is a range of alternatives in which pensioners can invest. They will all examine the range of alternatives, that is certainly true. They will not all decide to sell shares. Since we announced this, the numbers of pensioners who hold them have gone up almost by half. So this assertion that there is a flood of pensioners trying to get out of shares is simply not true and will not be true for the future. In the light of that extraordinarily reasonable explanation of the Government's measure—the reasons for it, the effects of it and the effects on savings—I trust that Senator Patterson will reconsider.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: —I have to answer some of Senator Richardson's comments, and I am not going to reconsider. I do not think he gave me a very good argument. He said that the number of pensioners with investments had increased, but he did not give me any details as to the level of their investments in shares. He has not told me whether those people are full pensioners or not and whether they have investments at a rate which is low enough to entitle them to a full pension anyway. That figure really has not convinced me.

para.tab: Senator Richardson said that I went along with these matters before, when the legislation came through. But it was with reservations. Senator Richardson might remember that I said we would review that this year because of our concerns that the Government had it coupled with benefits. Had we suggested that we oppose that, Senator Richardson would have said, `We cannot pay for the benefits'.

As for the accuracy of the estimates of the savings, these have been questioned by the stock exchange. I also question the accuracy of the figure because when I asked in Estimates whether it took into account changes in pensioners' behaviour, the department said that it did not. I do not care what Senator Richardson says about the increasing number of people investing in shares, the fact is that financial advisers are telling pensioners to take their money out of shares. If Senator Richardson had read any of the material that goes out from investment advisers, he would see that that is what they are telling pensioners to do. That is what they are ringing my office and telling me that they are telling pensioners to do and that is what they will do.

Senator Richardson says that only three per cent of the population of pensioners are affected, but I point out that it is three per cent of two million. That is a lot of people. So to cast those people aside as not being relevant is, I think, not appropriate and it is an argument that we cannot accept.

I also want to know how much this will cost to administer. Senator Richardson has not told us how much it will cost to administer. He has told us the net savings, but, as always, the administration cost creeps up. The report,
Super—fiscal and social links
, which was the fourth report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, said:

speech.para: The Committee recommends that the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security form a working party to examine income tax and social security legislation with a view to maximising the consistency of definitions and treatment of matters of common concern to the two systems and that the report be tabled in Parliament by the end of 1993.

What we have been asking for is a total review of incomes and assets tests for pensioners. Tinkering at the edges in the way that Senator Richardson has done makes it even less fair and more uneven. It has not addressed the problems that are there, and I am in no way convinced that we ought to withdraw this Bill. I will proceed with it forthwith.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased that Senator Patterson is not convinced by the Minister's questions and assertions because I believe this particular measure of Senator Patterson's is, as was the private member's Bill introduced by Senator Lees and myself, thoroughly deserving of the support of not only the full chamber but also the rest of the Parliament of Australia, the House of Representatives.

para.tab: Senator Richardson made a number of assertions about what pensioners would and would not do, what moves could and could not be taken and the alternatives which exist. None of those assertions is in accord with the communication that I have had with pensioners in the community who are concerned about this. None of the answers given by the Minister is acceptable to those people who are concerned about this.

The very premise on which this move is based, as Senator Richardson has said to us several times, is the premise that we should be treating equally those who invest in management investment trusts and those who invest directly in the share market. If, in the way that the managed investment trusts are treated at the moment—and that is not to say that is correct—it is deemed that capital gains are income, that is a contradiction and an illogicality which should not be perpetuated over other investments. If it is, and if the Minister wants to extend that treatment in fairness to other areas, the gain in value that might accrue to antiques, as Senator Richardson mentioned—I did not hear the actual words he used but the implication was that one could not sell the corner leg off an antique table, that it was not as redeemable as a parcel of shares—or, as other people have suggested, to land, stamp collections, coins, art works or whatever, is a gain in capital value which is taxed as capital gains when the items are sold.

A portfolio of antiques or a portfolio of philatelic value has some degree of flexibility. I can sense an attitude that starts off with managed investment trusts extending through share markets to those other areas of alternative investment which I have mentioned. Just because we start with the thin end does not mean to say we should not resist the wedge coming through all the way. I think it is right to resist that wedge.

If this Government wants to deem that capital gains are equal to income, I will resist it, because that is just nonsense. It is illogical, it is inaccurate, it is unfair and it is not even good English—and we should always be on our guard against the misuse of the English language. Capital gains are not income, never will be, and should not be treated that way. The Minister has not yet explained why we should make this unfair, illogical, inaccurate and bad English attack on what people understand.

The fundamental of our laws is the language. If people understand that there is a capital gains tax to be applied when they sell things and when they have the money in their hands, that is how they behave. They organise their affairs accordingly—and organise their affairs they have, on the strength of what they understood to be plain English. Here we have this deeming business which defies all logicality as far as I am concerned—and that is not very good English either.

I turn to the other aspect of what financial advisers are and are not doing. There was one aspect of the Minister's response which concerned me greatly. I agree—in fact, it is a platitude—that those who will be most affected are those who have the biggest shareholdings. Wow, that is really enlightening stuff. Of course that will be the case. But those who are in that situation do not need us to leap to their defence. Of course, it is worth while for financial planning advisers to take the trouble to rearrange their affairs.

The people who will be most significantly affected are not those people at all. The significant effect will be felt by those people who have a part pension and who would have that pension compromised by the Government's deeming that their small capital gains are income and enough to take them off the pension entirely. Those people are not necessarily in the category of having large shareholdings; they are people who have a few shares, and they could well be people in what I think is the average range of seeing perhaps $700 to $1,000 accrue to their share portfolio over a year. It might be that $700 or $800 is taken off it by movements in the share market in a subsequent year. One year they are on the pension and the next year they are off the pension. One person who wrote to me said, `At my time of life, at 82 years of age, I do not need this hassle'.

talk.start.para: —I wish to respond to the comments made by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) in relation to the private member's Bill introduced by my colleague Senator Patterson. I regret that the Minister has left the chamber, because his speech was not really a very spirited defence of the Government's position. I am led to the conclusion that had he been the Minister last year, this private member's Bill may not have been necessary. But he has to defend the Government line, and defend it he does.

para.tab: The whole thrust of the problem that we as a Liberal-National party coalition foresee is that the Labor Party is treating people differently. True, there are differences between valuations of private company shares and public company shares, and it is more difficult to invest overseas for elderly people, but the whole problem is that the Government is treating people differently. It is making particular selections.

I ask Senator Collins what the next level will be. We have seen a progression. We have seen the introduction of a wealth tax on that section of the Australian community that can least bear this cost. With the increased value of their share or their investment bond, they lose a proportion of their investment because it comes off their pension. That is a wealth tax. The Government started off with friendly society bonds. Any increase in their value reduces the pension. Increases in management investment trusts reduce the pension. Now it is concentrating on increases in the value of shares. What is the next item the Government will be looking for? It will be the family home. Pensioners out there, beware, because this Government has a very bad track record. We have what is tantamount to a wealth tax. We are increasingly seeing evidence of this coming through.

We have legislation before us at present regarding eligible termination payments and the death benefit component which pass to a person who is not a member of the family. An increased value of tax will be applied, but it is being applied in a very discriminatory way. Taxes should be fair; they should be equitably distributed; and they should be borne by those who are in the best position to afford them. The Government is trying it out with the pensioners, and it may be the beginning of a wealth tax for all Australians.

During the debates on superannuation, the Government consistently implored Australians to save more. The whole thrust of the superannuation guarantee levy was that the increased amounts of money had to be put aside by employers on behalf of their employees to provide for their retirement; people had to be encouraged to save for their retirement. This very proposition discourages people from retiring, from investing and from hedging against inflation rather than putting their money under their beds.

What incentive is there in this? I support the proposition put by our shadow Minister. The Government has taken a very cynical line as to why we introduced this at the time. True, we were expecting to be in government. We undertook that when in government we would revise it, examine it and change it. Because we are not in government, we have had to do the second best thing. We have raised it as a private member's Bill, both here and in the other place, to ensure that those people in the community who can least afford to have their savings knocked back are not disadvantaged.

The need for this level of savings is written about constantly by every responsible financial journalist in this country. The problem with Australia is that our level of savings is too low. That is why we owe the rest of the world so much money. This move is a retrograde step in so many areas. I commend Senator Patterson for her initiative and for honouring the undertaking that we gave to the pensioners of Australia. Well done, Senator Patterson of the Liberal Party.
