talk.start.para: —I rise to oppose the motion moved by Senator Faulkner and to support the amendment which will be moved by Senator Panizza. The reason for the Government, and apparently the Democrats, wishing to cut the number of Senate committees is simply that as a result of the election on 13 March the Government has lost two senators and it simply does not have the people in this chamber to adequately service those committees. It is also relevant, I guess, that the Democrats are now down to seven on their way down to two, I suspect, after the next election.
—We are still seven.
—You were eight when I came here, Senator Kernot. You are now seven.
—Order! Please direct your comments to the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, when I came here the Democrats were eight. They had yet another leadership battle. They seem to have more leadership battles than all other parties put together. They have not, as far as I am aware, got a quota in any State. They only get there on the preferences of other minor groups. But they are down to seven and, conveniently, the proposal by the Government allows them just one senator per committee.

para.tab: I briefly want to draw attention to the very fine speech made by Senator Baden Teague in his plea to retain the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It was a committee that for a year or so I was privileged to sit on. I pay particular tribute to the work of Senator Maguire, who chaired that committee very well and, of course, to my colleague Senator Teague who, as deputy chairman, really did a lot of very fine work. Senator Teague, as we all know in this chamber, has a very great and sincere interest in foreign affairs particularly, which is well evidenced by his very great knowledge and understanding of foreign affairs, and his very close contacts with—I suspect I would be right in saying—all of the representatives of foreign countries who are resident here in Canberra.

talk.start.para: —Thank you. You are very kind.

—It is not just a question of being kind; it is very obvious. I do not think anyone in this chamber would in any way say anything different. Senator Teague did at some length indicate the reasons why that committee should be retained; I do not want to repeat them.

para.tab: However, I do want to draw attention to the inquiry by that committee—to which Senator Teague made rather lengthy reference—into Australia's relationships with Latin America. That was a first report; that was the first time any parliamentary group had made any in-depth study into our relationships with Latin America. As Senator Teague has rightly said, it has become almost the—I think `bible' might be taking it a bit far—principal reference book for anyone in Australia who might be interested in doing business with, or having cultural, sporting or other links with, the countries of Latin America.

As a result of that report on our relationships with Latin America, the committee received an enormous number of congratulatory remarks—very encouraging remarks—and a lot has eventuated from that it. It is a report that I think will long be referred to by people interested in dealings with Latin America. Certainly it was, as Senator Teague said, a report that had the very enthusiastic support of the diplomatic representatives of Latin American countries in Australia.

It is more than a shame, it is a tragedy, that the Government, because of its own inefficiencies, wants to get rid of that committee. Like so much that this Government does, there are other ways of correcting any perceived difficulties it has. One would be to manage the committees a bit better. Possibly the Government could make sure that the workload was not quite as heavy, but still retain those committees, particularly the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee, which has really carved out for itself a major niche in the parliamentary system. The Government could well retain that committee but look at lessening in some way the workload on it and on other committees.

talk.start.para: —We are willing to negotiate any practical lowering of the load on senators.

—Quite right. As Senator Teague says we, the Liberal and National parties, would be more than willing to negotiate with the Government on any suitable reforms that need to be made to make sure that all of the existing committees can operate effectively. Senator Panizza's motion, which has not yet been moved but will be, makes provision for the retention of that committee while coming to some other arrangements which, hopefully, the Government and the Democrats may find acceptable.

para.tab: I think Senator Bourne was a member of the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee and contributed substantially at times. I appreciate that when she became the Whip her time became a little more precious; she was not able to attend as often as she had previously. Senator Bourne is well aware of the fine work that that particular committee did. I ask Senator Bourne—as one who understands and has been part of that committee—to reconsider the proposal and not just simply go along with the Government willy-nilly. I ask her to have a look at other arrangement which may be able to be made which would allow those committees to remain in place, but possibly with a lesser workload.
As I have said, Senator Teague has canvassed those issues on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade very well. I will not proceed with it any further.

However, I do want to raise the other committee which is proposed to be abolished under these proposals by the Government, and that is the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I feel a little slighted; I have been on both committees which are intended to be abolished. I do not know whether that has something to do with me or whether it is just coincidence. That committee on transport, communications and infrastructure was and is a very substantial and important committee.

Mr Deputy President, you may well recall the work that that committee did on the very fast train proposal, an inquiry which was well under way when I came to the Senate three years ago, but which my colleague Senator Reid participated in very forcefully and very beneficially.

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht was on it, too.
—His contribution would not have been anything like Senator Reid's, I am sure, but no doubt he would have made some contribution to it.
—Look at where I am now.
—If you lie and cheat and bribe your way, you can get anywhere, Senator Schacht. That is why you are where you are now.
—Order! That remark is definitely out of order and you should withdraw it.

—I withdraw it, Mr Deputy President; that is no problem. Senator Schacht did not seem to take any undue umbrage at it. In fact, I understood from his reaction that he well agreed with it. But I will not indicate to Senator Schacht whether I was talking about his position on his Government's front bench or his position on that side of the chamber.

para.tab: The committee put a lot of effort into the very fast train proposal and all senators who participated in it got a much wider understanding of the issues involved. In that way, that committee assisted the work of this chamber and assisted in senators' understanding of the issues involved—what needed to be done, the costs and all those sorts of things—and made them much more aware.

The committee on transport, communication and infrastructure then conducted a major inquiry into satellite launching facilities in Australia. Senator Schacht participated in that occasionally and, when he did, he made sensible contributions. Senator Kernot also paid particular interest to that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

answer.to.qon.title: Arts and Administrative Services: Media Releases

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

para.tab: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister; if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The Department does not routinely circulate individual Ministerial media releases. The Department prepares a quarterly summary of Ministerial media releases which it sends to approximately 340 individuals and organisations to inform them of portfolio initiatives.
(2) In the past 18 months the printing and circulation costs of the media release summary is estimated at $816.00. Approximately 2040 copies were circulated in this period.
(3) The Department does not circulate copies of speeches made by the Minister.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

para.tab: With reference to Australia's growing link with Asia and, in particular, the need for an increase in the number of Japanese-speaking Australians to become guides for Japanese tourists:
(1) How many students are enrolled in Japanese language courses in Australian secondary and tertiary institutions.
(2) What is the breakdown of the number of students on a state by state basis.
(3) What level of proficiency is expected to be attained by a graduate from these courses.

(4) Apart from the Federal Government's training scheme at the Gold Coast and Brisbane TAFE colleges, is the Government funding Japanese language courses at any other Government or private educational facilities.
(5) How many Japanese language courses are being conducted by private institutions.
(6) How many students have graduated in the past 10 years from public and private Japanese language courses in Australia.

(7) What liaison does the Australian Government have with Australians who have taken part in Japanese exchange student programs, such as Rotary Clubs, etcetera, to ascertain how many of these students are available to work as tourist guides.
(8) Has the Government sought assistance of the Australian-Japanese Foundation (AJF) in its campaign to recruit more Australians to fill the role of tour guides to Japanese tourists.
(9) Has the Government approached Australian university students who have been awarded AJF scholarships in Japan to determine if they are willing to work as tourist guides.
(10) What remuneration is offered to Japanese-speaking Australians possessing the qualifications required to act as tourist guides.
(11) Is this remuneration sufficient to attract Australians to consider applying for tourist guide positions.

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) In 1992, secondary enrolment in Japanese is estimated to have been between 65,000 and 70,000. Latest figures available on enrolment in tertiary Japanese courses were for 1990 and indicated that there were 1998 EFTSU (Equivalent Full Time Student Unit).
(2) The break up by state/territory is:

(3) Courses vary considerably in content, objectives, duration, contact hours and, presumably, standard. Data is not readily available as to the levels of proficiency expected, but it has been estimated that the development of reasonable proficiency in Japanese requires between 2,000-2,500 hours of contact time.

(4) As far as the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) is aware, the Government is not making direct and specific funding available to support specific Japanese language courses. However, the Government has made funds available to support the learning and teaching of languages other than English in schools and other sectors. For example, under the Priority Language Incentive Element (PLIE) of the School Language and Literacy Program, funds are provided to encourage students to continue studying any eight of the priority languages at Year 12 level including Japanese, nominated in the Australian Language and Literacy Policy (estimated expenditure under this program in 1993 is $7 million); a 30% increase in funding (to $9.7 million in 1993) for language teaching through ethnic schools, and a provision of up to $4 million per year for innovative projects which aim to improve the quality of LOTEs teaching in schools, TAFEs and universities nationally.
(5) No statistics are available.
(6) No statistics are available.
(7) DEET is not aware of other Commonwealth departments or agencies' involvement in this area. However, DEET is providing funding to Monash University (Professor Helen Marriot) under the

answer.para: Innovative Languages Other Than English in Schools (ILOTES) Program to analyse the policies and programs of Australian bodies which organise in-country programs in Japan for Australian secondary students. The programs will also assess the benefit to students in terms of their language gain, motivation and commitment to further study at tertiary level and then use of their Japanese language skills for vocational purposes.

para.tab: (8) DEET has not taken any action in this direction and is not aware of any other Commonwealth departments or agencies' action in this area.
(9) DEET has not made any approach to these students and is not aware of any other Commonwealth departments or agencies doing so.

(10) Fieldwork conducted by DEET in 1992 in an analysis of the labour market for Japanese-speaking tour-guides in Australia suggested an average salary of $25000 ranging to $30000 for senior tour-guides with experience and specialised skills. In comparison, in the banking industry, entry salaries are linked to qualifications and fairly constant across sectors, with a pass degree attracting about $26500 and no loading for a second language.

(11) The casual nature of employment combined with remuneration in the industry may not be attractive to Australian tertiary graduates with Japanese language skills. In addition, the casual employment and small size of firms, common within the industry, tends to prevent any clearly defined career path. This may also act as a disincentive to Australians with Japanese language skills to apply for tourist guide positions.
